questions.text: In a couple undergoing in-vitro fertilization for 4 years, which resulted in the birth of a female child today, if a sample is drawn for investigation, at which stage of meiosis would the oocyte be?
questions.solution:
Option A: Prophase I

  • At the time of birth, the oocyte is dormant in the diplotene stage (resting stage during prophase I) in all females, regardless of the type of conception- natural/ IVF.
  • Stages of prophase- I
    • Leptotene
    • Zygotene
    • Pachytene
    • Diplotene
    • Diakinesis

Option B: Metaphase I

  • In metaphase I, the homologous pairs of chromosomes align on each side of the equatorial plate. The secondary oocyte is arrested in the metaphase-2 stage of meiosis II, which is completed when fertilization occurs.

Option C: Anaphase I

  • Anaphase I is the 3rd stage of meiosis I & follows prophase I & metaphase I.
  • Sister chromatids of every chromosome separate & start to move towards the opposite pole of the cell. The separation and the movement are because of the shortening of the kinetochore microtubules.

Option D: Telophase I

  • Telophase I is the last stage of meiosis 2 followed by telophase II. Four daughter cells are formed
  • Nuclear membranes form around each set of chromosomes & decondensation of the chromosomes occurs. Cytokinesis splits the sets of chromosomes into new cells, four haploid cells.

questions.text: The skin receptors are of two types- rapidly adapting and slowly adapting. The rapidly adapting receptor, found in the location as marked in the image below, is:
questions.solution:
Option B: Meissner's corpuscle

  •  Meissner's corpuscles are present in the dermo-epidermal junction. The marked area is the Dermo-epidermal junction.
  • MEISSNER's CORPUSCLE is present at the dermo-epidermal junction–it is rapidly adapting receptors and functions for 2-point discrimination.
  • Meissner's corpuscles are present in the hairless skin and are responsible for tactile sensations. These receptors can sense low-frequency vibrations (10-50 hertz).
  • The Meissner corpuscle is composed of three components:
    • Elongated Schwann cells.
    • Connective tissue capsule.
    • A central axon.
  • On light microscopy, Meissner's corpuscles appear as coiled, spring-like structures with their longitudinal end perpendicular to the skin surface. The touch sensitivity, size, and density of Meissner's corpuscles decline with age.

Option A: Merkel's cell

 

  • Merkel Cells: Slow adapting receptor
  • Involved in light touch sensation;
  • For e.g., detecting pencil in fingers
  • Helps in initial learning of Braille characters/words. Later Braille (sentences) are better read by Meissner’s corpuscle.

Option C: Pacinian corpuscle

  •  Pacinian corpuscle is present in the deep dermis
  • The function is that they detect pressure and vibration.
  • It is a rapidly adapting receptor.

Option D: Ruffini's receptor

  • It is a slowly adapting receptor.
  • Senses for dermal stretch and also as thermoreceptor.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented to the OPD with complaints of blurring of vision, severe headache, and ringing in the ears for 4 months. CT scan was done, and meningioma was diagnosed. While doing surgery for meningioma, left paracentral lobule got injured. This will lead to paresis of:
questions.solution:
Option C: Right leg and perineum

  • The paracentral lobule presents near the midline encroaching upon the medial surface of the hemisphere and is the continuation of the precentral and postcentral gyri.

  • The paracentral lobule is involved in controlling the motor and sensory innervations of the contralateral lower limb and part of the perineal region. It is involved in the control of the bladder and bowel (defecation and urination) function.
  • It also includes parts of the frontal and parietal lobes.
  • The anterior part of the paracentral lobule is a portion of the frontal lobe and contains a little portion of Brodmann's area 6.
  • The posterior part is considered a portion of the parietal lobe and deals with the somatosensory of the distal limbs.
  • Cerebral homunculus is a map along the cerebral cortex of where each part of the body is processed. The sensations occur all along the body. The impulses from the body will be sent into the spinal cord and eventually back to the brain to be processed.
  • Sensory Motor Homunculus: Representation of body on the cerebrum.
  • Upside-down representation in an oblique fashion [along the central sulcus].
  • Both motor & sensory.
  • Hand & face has more representation.
  • Lower & lateral: Face area.
  • Higher: Upper limb area.
  • Still higher: Pelvis perineum area.
  • On the medial surface: Lower limb area, part of pelvis & perineum.

Option A: Left face

  • The paracentral lobule governs sensory and motor sensations of the right limb and perineum.

Option B: Right neck and scapular region

  • The paracentral lobule governs sensory and motor sensations of the right limb and perineum.

Option C: Right shoulder and trunk

  • The paracentral lobule governs sensory and motor sensations of the right limb and perineum.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male, involved in a RTA a month ago, presents with diplopia and headache during focused gaze for the past 6 days. Neurologic examination reveals bilateral medial rectus paresis on lateral gaze, monocular horizontal nystagmus in the abducting eye, and unimpaired convergence. The lesion is located in which area?
questions.solution:
Option C: Mid Pontine tegmentum, dorsomedial zones, bilateral

  • The patient has bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia (BINO) due to the involvement of bilateral medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), located in the dorsomedial mid-pontine tegmentum.

  • The pontine tegmentum is situated within the Brainstem and is one of two portions of the pons, and the other is the ventral pons.
  • The pontine tegmentum can be defined with the basilar pons: basilar pons contains the corticospinal tract running craniocaudally and can be regarded as the rostral extension of the ventral medulla oblongata; however, basilar pons is distinguished from the ventral medulla oblongata in that it contains additional transverse pontine fibers that continue laterally to become the middle cerebellar peduncle.
  • The pontine tegmentum is all of the material dorsal from the basilar pons to the fourth ventricle. Along with the dorsal surface of the medulla, it forms a portion of the rhomboid fossa - the floor of the fourth ventricle.

Option A: Caudal midbrain tectum

  • The patient has bilateral internuclear ophthalmoplegia (BINO) due to the involvement of bilateral medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) located in the dorsomedial mid-pontine tegmentum.
  • It connects the cranial nerve nuclei III, IV, and VI and integrates movements directed by the gaze centers and information about head movement.
  • MLF syndrome is commonly seen in the case of multiple sclerosis and less often in vascular lesions.

Option B: Caudal pontine base

The basilar pons makes up two-thirds of the pons within the Brainstem.

  • It has a ridged appearance with a shallow groove at the midline. This groove is regarded as the basilar sulcus and is covered by the basilar artery, which feeds into the Circle of Willis and gives blood supply to the Brainstem and cerebellum.
  • The basilar pons appears due to the fibers that come from the pons and enter the cerebellum.
  • This part of the Brainstem has fibers from the corticospinal tract, pontine nuclei, and transverse pontine fibers.
  • The corticospinal tract carries neurons from the primary motor cortex in the brain to the spinal cord, helping in the voluntary motor movements of the body. In addition to passing through the basilar pons, corticospinal tract fibers go through the structures of the Brainstem, such as the crus cerebri and the internal capsule.

Option D: Rostral midbrain, basis peduncular

  • Cerebral peduncle" is frequently used synonymously with the crus cerebri alone but most traditionally refers to the cylindrical shaped combination of the crus cerebri, substantia nigra, and tegmentum (i.e., the entire midbrain ventral to the tectum).
  • The basis peduncular or crusta traditionally refers to the combination of the crus cerebri and substantia nigra but has also been used synonymously with the crus cerebri.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements regarding deep cervical fascia is correct?

choices.text: Axillary sheath is derived from B
Parotid sheath is derived from C

questions.solution:
Option C: C represents Pretracheal fascia

  • C in the diagram represents the pretracheal fascia.
  • Pretracheal fascia extends from the hyoid bone to the pericardium of the heart.
  • Posteriorly, it blends with buccopharyngeal fascia and laterally with carotid sheaths.
  • It supports the infrahyoid muscles, thyroid gland, trachea, and esophagus.

Option A: Axillary sheath is derived from B

  • The axillary sheath is derived from the prevertebral layer of deep cervical fascia and marked as A in the diagram.

Option B: Parotid sheath is derived from C

  • The parotid sheath is derived from investing layer of deep cervical fascia and is marked as B in the diagram, not C as the option says.

Option D: C covers the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid

  • Pretracheal fascia is labeled as C in the diagram. It does not cover trapezius and sternocleidomastoid.
  • Both these muscles are covered by investing layer of deep cervical fascia.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is brought to a local hospital in the village after an aspiration for a small toy. On examination, there is significant respiratory distress. An emergency tracheostomy is done after seeking consent. Any of the following can get damaged during the emergency tracheostomy, except?
questions.solution:
Option B: Inferior Thyroid Artery

  • Inferior thyroid arteries are less likely to be damaged during an emergency tracheostomy.
  • Tracheostomy is defined as the creation of an opening in the trachea.
  • Most tracheostomies these days are elective, the emergency tracheostomy is rarely done due to the complications.
  • Emergency tracheostomies are usually done in the case of acute upper airway obstruction.
  • The complications of emergency tracheostomy include damage to the midline structures, pneumothorax, subcutaneous emphysema, bleeding, the creation of a false lumen, and perforation of the trachea.
  • Emergency tracheostomy can damage midline structures that include:
    • Thyroid isthmus
    • Thyroid ima artery
    • Inferior thyroid vein
  • In contrast to the midline structures, the inferior thyroid artery lies laterally away from the midline and escapes injury.
  • The diagram below shows that the location of the inferior thyroid artery is far lateral away from the midline/trachea. So, it is least likely to be affected.

Option A: Isthmus of Thyroid

  • Emergency tracheostomy can damage any of the midline structures of the neck, and the isthmus of the thyroid is one of those structures at risk of getting damaged in tracheostomy.

Option C: Thyroid Ima Artery

  • The Thyroid Ima artery is located in the midline of the neck just at the inferior border of the isthmus of the thyroid and is susceptible to damage by emergency tracheostomy.

Option D: Inferior Thyroid Vein​​​​​​​

  • The inferior thyroid vein is more susceptible to damage in low tracheostomy that accompanies conservation laryngeal procedures.
  • Even a cricothyroidotomy is complicated by hemorrhage after a tear in the tributary of the inferior thyroid venous system.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents with complaints of pain and numbness in the perineal region, as well as difficulty with urination and defecation. Physical examination reveals decreased sensation in the perianal area and weakened anal sphincter tone. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Option A

  • The symptoms described are consistent with pudendal nerve neuropathy, which can result in pain and numbness in the perineal region, as well as difficulty with urination and defecation. Decreased sensation in the perianal area and weakened anal sphincter tone are also indicative of pudendal nerve dysfunction.

Why Others are Incorrect

  • Option B) Femoral nerve: The femoral nerve is responsible for innervating the anterior thigh muscles and skin, and does not supply the perineal region. If this nerve is injured, the patient would typically present with weakness of the thigh muscles, difficulty extending the leg, and sensory loss in the anterior thigh and medial leg. However, they would not experience perineal numbness or urinary incontinence.
  • Option C) Sciatic nerve: The sciatic nerve supplies the posterior thigh, leg, and foot, and does not innervate the perineal region. If this nerve is injured, the patient would typically experience weakness or loss of movement in the hamstring muscles, difficulty bending the knee or extending the hip and sensory loss in the posterior thigh and leg. However, they would not experience perineal numbness or urinary incontinence.
  • Option D) Obturator nerve: The obturator nerve supplies the medial thigh muscles and does not innervate the perineal region. If this nerve is injured, the patient would typically present with weakness of the thigh muscles, difficulty adducting the thigh, and sensory loss in the medial thigh. However, they would not experience perineal numbness or urinary incontinence.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe lower abdominal pain and back pain. He reports a history of hypertension and smoking. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg, heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute. He appears pale, sweaty, and agitated. Abdominal examination reveals diffuse tenderness and guarding with absent bowel sounds. A pulsatile mass is palpable in the midline of the abdomen. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics
Order an abdominal CT scan and consult vascular surgery
Administer morphine for pain relief and observe the patient
Transfer the patient to the ICU for hemodynamic support

questions.solution:
Option B

  • The most appropriate management for this patient is order an abdominal CT scan and consult vascular surgery. The presentation is consistent with a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA), a life-threatening condition that requires urgent surgical intervention. The presence of a pulsatile abdominal mass, diffuse abdominal tenderness and guarding, and signs of shock (pale, sweaty, tachycardic, and tachypneic) are all suggestive of a ruptured AAA.

Why Others are Wrong

  • Option A ) Initiating IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics may be part of the management for sepsis, but they are not the primary intervention for a ruptured AAA.
  • Option C) Administering morphine for pain relief and observing the patient is not appropriate in this case. A ruptured AAA requires urgent surgical intervention, and delaying treatment can lead to life-threatening complications.
  • Option D) Transferring the patient to the ICU for hemodynamic support may be necessary, but it is not the primary intervention for a ruptured AAA. Urgent surgical intervention is required to repair the aneurysm and prevent further bleeding.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to the emergency department with lower gastrointestinal bleeding and abdominal pain. After diagnostic workup, the child is diagnosed with a Meckel's diverticulum with the presence of gastric mucosa. The surgical team decides that surgery is necessary to address the issue, and the child is scheduled for immediate surgical intervention. During the surgery, the surgeon discovers that Meckel's diverticulum has become inflamed.. What is the most likely complication associated with this finding during the surgical intervention?
questions.solution:
Option D

  • Meckel's diverticulum is a common congenital abnormality of the gastrointestinal tract. It arises from the distal ileum and is a remnant of the embryonic yolk sac. The presence of gastric mucosa in the Meckel's diverticulum can lead to the secretion of acid, which can cause inflammation and subsequent perforation. During surgical intervention, the most likely complication associated with this finding is perforation, which can occur due to the inflamed Meckel's diverticulum. If left untreated, the perforation can lead to sepsis, peritonitis, or other life-threatening complications. Therefore, immediate attention is required to avoid further complications.

Why are other options incorrect

Option A

  • Although bleeding is a common symptom associated with Meckel's diverticulum, it is not the most likely complication associated with the finding of inflammation and perforation during surgical intervention. In this case, perforation is the most likely complication, which can lead to serious complications such as sepsis and peritonitis.

Option B

  • Obstruction, is incorrect because Meckel's diverticulum is located in the small intestine and an obstruction in this area would typically present with symptoms such as vomiting, abdominal distension, and constipation. In this case, the child presented with lower gastrointestinal bleeding and abdominal pain, which are not typical symptoms of an obstruction in the small intestine. The presence of gastric mucosa in the Meckel's diverticulum increases the risk of bleeding, inflammation and perforation during surgery further support the most likely complication being perforation rather than obstruction.

Option C

  • Inflammation is not the most likely complication associated with the finding of an inflamed Meckel's diverticulum during surgical intervention. While inflammation can occur in response to various factors such as infections, it is not the most common complication associated with an inflamed Meckel's diverticulum. Perforation, on the other hand, is a common complication that can occur due to the increased pressure caused by inflammation or infection, leading to rupture of the diverticulum. This can result in the leakage of its contents into the abdomen, leading to further complications. Therefore, option C is incorrect in this scenario.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, fever, and elevated white blood cell count. On examination, he has diffuse tenderness and guarding over the abdomen. CT scan reveals thickening and infiltration of the greater omentum. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B

  • The symptoms described in the scenario (severe abdominal pain, fever, elevated white blood cell count, diffuse tenderness, and guarding over the abdomen) suggest the presence of an infection. The CT scan findings of thickening and infiltration of the greater omentum are consistent with an abscess. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is a greater omental abscess (option B), which is an infection and collection of pus within the greater omentum.

Why Others are Incorrect

  • Option A: Greater omental torsion, is less likely to be the correct diagnosis based on the presented information. While greater omental torsion can present with symptoms similar to those described in the scenario, it is a rare condition that occurs when the greater omentum twists on itself, leading to ischemia and necrosis. The CT scan findings of thickening and infiltration of the greater omentum are more consistent with an abscess, which is an infection and collection of pus within the greater omentum. Therefore, option A is less likely to be the correct diagnosis in this case.
  • Option C: Greater omental hernia, is less likely to be the correct diagnosis based on the presented information. While greater omental hernias can cause abdominal pain, they are rare and often asymptomatic. Therefore, option C is less likely to be the correct diagnosis in this case.
  • Option D, Greater omental metastasis, is less likely to be the correct diagnosis based on the presented information. While thickening and infiltration of the greater omentum can be a sign of metastatic disease, it is less likely in a patient who presents with severe abdominal pain, fever, and elevated white blood cell count, which are more consistent with an infection. Therefore, it is less likely to be the correct diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals thickened gastric folds with nodular mucosa. Biopsy specimens show cystic dilation of the gastric glands with a lack of parietal cells and an increase in mucous cells. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals overexpression of transforming growth factor-alpha (TGF-α) in the gastric mucosa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C

  • Ménétrier disease, also known as giant hypertrophic gastritis, is a rare disorder characterized by the hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the gastric mucosa. The hallmark of Ménétrier disease is the presence of giant gastric folds, or rugae, which can lead to gastric outlet obstruction and malabsorption. Biopsy specimens typically show cystic dilation of the gastric glands with a lack of parietal cells and an increase in mucous cells. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals overexpression of transforming growth factor-alpha (TGF-α) in the gastric mucosa. The clinical presentation of Ménétrier disease includes epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss

 

Why others are incorrect

Option A) Gastric adenocarcinoma

  • Gastric adenocarcinoma can present with similar symptoms to Ménétrier disease, such as epigastric pain and weight loss, and can also cause thickening of the gastric folds. However, biopsy specimens of gastric adenocarcinoma typically show malignant cells, while Ménétrier disease is a benign disorder. Immunohistochemical analysis of gastric adenocarcinoma may show overexpression of HER2/neu, rather than TGF-α.

Option B) Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST)

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) can arise in the stomach and cause thickening of the gastric mucosa, but they typically present with features such as bleeding and obstruction rather than the diffuse hypertrophy seen in Ménétrier disease. Biopsy specimens of GIST may show spindle-shaped or epithelioid cells, rather than cystic dilation of gastric glands.

Option D) Zollinger-Ellison syndrome

  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is a condition characterized by the overproduction of gastric acid due to a gastrin-secreting tumor. This can lead to symptoms such as peptic ulcers and diarrhea, but it does not typically cause the diffuse hypertrophy of the gastric mucosa seen in Ménétrier disease. Biopsy specimens of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome may show gastrinoma cells, rather than cystic dilation of gastric glands.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a history of progressive swelling and pain in her right upper extremity. She has a history of thoracic outlet syndrome and was previously treated with physical therapy. A CT scan shows compression of the right brachiocephalic vein. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Compression of the brachiocephalic vein can occur due to various causes, including anatomical abnormalities, tumors, and fibrous bands. In this case, the patient has a history of thoracic outlet syndrome, which is often associated with compression of the brachiocephalic vein by a fibrous band. Symptoms of brachiocephalic vein compression may include pain, swelling, and discoloration of the affected limb.

Why other options are incorrect:

B) Subclavian artery aneurysm

  • Subclavian artery aneurysm can cause compression of adjacent structures, including the brachiocephalic vein, but it is a less common cause of brachiocephalic vein compression compared to fibrous bands.

C) Lymphadenopathy

  • Lymphadenopathy refers to the enlargement of lymph nodes and can cause compression of adjacent structures, including the brachiocephalic vein. However, in this case, the patient's history of thoracic outlet syndrome and CT scan findings suggest that a fibrous band is the more likely cause of her symptoms.

D) Vertebral artery dissection

  • Vertebral artery dissection is a rare but potentially serious condition that can cause symptoms such as neck pain, headache, and neurological deficits. It is not a common cause of brachiocephalic vein compression.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male presents with back pain, cloudy urine, and painful urination for 1 month. Ultrasound shows bilateral renal calculi and metabolic evaluation reveals marked hypercalciuria with normal calcium, magnesium, phosphate, uric acid, and creatinine levels, leading to a diagnosis of idiopathic hypercalciuria. What dietary management is appropriate?
questions.solution:
Option A: Low sodium diet

  • In this case, the patient presents with back pain, cloudy urine, and pain during urination for the last 1 month. Ultrasound shows bilateral renal calculi. His metabolic test shows the presence of marked hypercalciuria with normal levels of calcium, magnesium, phosphate, uric acid and creatinine. The doctor diagnoses him with idiopathic hypercalciuria.
  • The patient in this condition presents with kidney stones made up of calcium. It can cause various problems like urinary retention, urinary tract infection, irritability, lower belly pain, and excess calcium in the urine.
  • This disease greatly depends on dietary management to counter hypercalciuria. It involves various important steps.
  • Intake of low sodium diet is very important in this condition. Sodium restriction is important because urinary calcium excretion parallels sodium excretion.

Option B: Decrease water intake

  • Decreased water intake is not indicated in hypercalciuria. Instead, water intake is increased in this condition.
  • It helps to lower blood calcium levels and prevent the further formation of stones.

Option C: Reduce calcium intake

  • The dietary calcium restriction is not recommended because calcium is a critical requirement for growth, and no evidence supports a relationship between decreased calcium intake and urinary calcium levels.
  • It is particularly important given the association of hypercalciuria with reduced bone mineral density.

Option D: Eat meat protein

  • The intake of meat is prohibited in patients with hypercalciuria. Eating meat will worsen conditions.
  • The low-protein diet tends to decrease calcium absorption and lowers urinary calcium.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to an outdoor department with a history of decreased urine output, cola-coloured urine, and swelling of the face and hands for 2 days. On examination, he is hypertensive, has a puffy face, and pitting oedema of the lower limbs but is vitally stable. He has a history of skin lesions 4 weeks earlier. A diagnosis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is made. ASO titers, in this case, will be?

choices.text: Initially elevated, rapidly fall in 3-4 days

questions.solution:
Correct Answer Option A: Elevated

  • In case of Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN), antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers are typically elevated.

    Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a type of kidney inflammation that occurs following an infection with certain strains of group A Streptococcus bacteria. It most commonly develops after a streptococcal throat or skin infection, such as strep throat or impetigo.

    During the infection, the body produces antibodies, including antistreptolysin O (ASO), to fight the streptococcal bacteria. ASO is an antibody specifically directed against the streptolysin O toxin produced by the bacteria.

Option B: Not Elevated

  • It is false statement

Option C: Increased Progressively over 3 days

  • This option is incorrect

Option D: Initially elevated, rapidly fall in 3-4 days

  • The levels fall over 6 to 12 months to insignificant levels.

questions.text: A 17-year-old female is brought to the paediatric outpatient department by her mother due to the absence of menstruation. She had normal growth and development previously. Physical examination reveals the formation of breast tissue but no pubic hair. The clinician diagnoses it as a case of delayed puberty. Which of the following is the age beyond which puberty is defined as delayed in girls?
questions.solution:
Option B: 14 years

  • A lack of secondary sexual characteristics by 14 years is defined as delayed puberty in girls.
  • The absence of menarche by the age of 16 years or 5 years after pubertal onset also indicates pubertal delay.
  • It may be caused by defects in the hypothalamic-pituitary axis, ovaries, or genital tract.
  • Defects in the hypothalamic-pituitary tract are associated with low gonadotropin levels (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism).
  • Patients with anatomical defects present with amenorrhea and normal breast development.
  • Diagnosis is based on history, clinical examination, FSH and LH levels, prolactin and thyroid profiles, karyotyping, neuroimaging, and pituitary function tests.
  • Treatment is by replacement of hormones (estrogen and progesterone) after 12 years of age to avoid deleterious effects on height.

Option A: 12 years

  • Lack of secondary sexual characteristics beyond 14 years of age is delayed puberty.
  • 12 years is too young an age to be defined as delayed puberty.

Option C: 16 years

  • The age limit of 16 years is for the absence of menstruation/menarche (primary amenorrhea).
  • The absence of secondary sexual characteristics beyond 14 years is a for delayed puberty.

Option D: 18 years

  • 18 years is not the age for delayed puberty, as it is too late to develop secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Treatment should be started by the age of 14 years if puberty is delayed.
  • Waiting up to 18 years might lead to further complications of delayed puberty.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of excessive thirst and urination for the past few weeks. On examination, the child has dry mucous membranes. Vital signs are within normal limits. Laboratory investigations reveal low urine specific gravity and osmolality, along with hyperosmolality of the plasma. Lesions in which of the hypothalamic nuclei are responsible for the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
→ Vasopressin, a 9-amino-acid peptide, has both anti-diuretic and vascular pressor activity

→ It is synthesized in the paraventricular & supraoptic nuclei of the hypothalamus.

→ Deficiency of Vasopressin causes Diabetes insipidus.

→ DI results in Polyuria [ urine output > 5ml/kg/hr / >2L/m2/24 hr ] & polydipsia

→ serum hyperosmolality and hypernatremia seen in Diabetes insipidus

Satiety center Ventromedial nuclei (VMN)
Reward center Medial forebrain bundle
Circadian rhythm Suprachiasmatic nucleus
Oxytocin Paraventricular nucleus

questions.text: A 9-month-old male child is brought to the physician by his mother with complaints of short arms and legs. She further gives a history of the progressively enlarging head. There is no past personal or family history of any chronic illness. The examination of the patient shows macrocephaly, prominent brow bones, and short extremities. The muscle power is 3/5 throughout. An x-ray of the skull shows midfacial hypoplasia and frontal prominence. Which of the following can also be seen in the patient’s current pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Champagne glass pelvis

  • This is a case of achondroplasia in which the patient is brought to the physician with complaints of short legs and arms.

  • The patient is also having a progressively enlarging head.

  • The patient has no history of any chronic illness.

  • The examination of the patient shows macrocephaly, prominent brow bones and short extremities.

  • The muscle power of the child is 3/5 throughout.

  • An x-ray of the skull shows mid-facial hypoplasia and frontal prominence.

  • Achondroplasia- trident hand, short stature, champagne glass pelvis on x-ray.

Option A: Wrist splaying

  • Wrist widening or splaying is seen in rickets.

  • Fraying & cupping are also seen in rickets.

Option C: Marble bone disease

  • Marble bone disease is also known as osteopetrosis.

  • It is called marble bone disease because bone appears pitched white because of an increase in the density of the bone.

Option D: Wimberger sign

  • Wimberger sign is seen in scurvy.

  • Pencil-thin outline of the cortex and subperiosteal haemorrhage are also seen in scurvy.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with a complaint of muscle weakness in his legs and arms. He has difficulty eating food. On physical examination, the muscle strength is 3 out of 5 in bilateral arms and legs. Spinal examination reveals scoliosis. Muscle biopsy reveals rode-like inclusions in muscle fibres. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Nemaline myopathy

  • Nemaline disease: The patient in the scenario is suffering from Nemaline disease, which causes generalised muscle weakness

  • A most distinctive feature of Nemaline myopathy is the presence of rod-like inclusions in muscle fibres.

  • Mutations in the NEB gene encoding Nebulin are considered the most encountered cause.

  • More commonly involved muscles are of face, trunk, and neck. Arms and legs are also involved.

  • It can lead to scoliosis in some children.

  • Severe disease can lead to difficulty in walking even some children may need assistance like a wheelchair.

Option B: Central core disease

  • It is also a congenital disease as it is present at birth and is a disorder of muscular weakness

  • The infant is floppy at birth due to decreased muscle tone and many other muscular problems

  • Scoliosis may also be present in some children.

  • Affected Infants may show delays in milestones

Option C:  Myotubular (Centronuclear) myopathy

  • Rare genetic muscular disorder.

  • Characterised by muscle weakness involving different areas of the body

  • Derives its name from the central location of the nucleus of muscle fibres normally present on the periphery.

  • Symptoms can present at birth or later in life.

  • Can cause respiratory distress and swallowing difficulty if severe.

Option D: Fibre-type disproportion myopathy

  • It is also a rare genetic disorder

  • Symptoms include hypotonia and muscle weakness

  • Delays in motor development are seen.

  • Rod-like inclusions are not seen.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy with a mild intellectual disability visits a pediatric neurology clinic with his father. He has been experiencing several episodes of seizures and recently developed aggressive behavior. On examination, the neurologist noted skin lesions shown in the image, a reddish papular rash on the face, and pitted teeth. An MRI is ordered and shows the findings given in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Tuberous sclerosis

  • In this case, a child presents with intellectual disability, seizures, and aggression for 1 year to the pediatric neurology clinic. On examination, multiple skin lesions and pitted teeth are seen. The doctor advised MRI for the child. Based on the case and MRI, this scenario indicates that the child has tuberous sclerosis.
  • In this disorder, mutations in the TSC1 (Chr 9) or TSC2 (Chr 16) gene can cause tuberous sclerosis complex. Skin manifestations include ash leaf macules, adenoma sebaceum, cafe au lait spots and shagreen patches.
  • CNS manifestations include developmental delay, intellectual disability, seizures and autism.
  • The skin lesion shown in the picture is a shagreen patch with an orange peel-like appearance, and the MRI brain shows multiple subependymal nodules, which are seen in tuberous sclerosis.
  • Tuberous sclerosis is a rare multi-system disease in which non-cancerous tumours grow in different body organs, which are benign in nature.

Option A: Sturge Weber syndrome

  • In this syndrome, angiomas involve leptomeninges and face skin, typically in ophthalmic & maxillary division distributions of the trigeminal nerve.
  • The hallmark of SWS is facial cutaneous venous dilation, also referred to as a nevus flammeus or port-wine stain. Contralateral focal seizures, calcification of the cerebral cortex and glaucoma on the same side as skin lesions are also seen.

Option C: Neurofibromatosis

  • They are a group of genetic disorders that can cause tumours to grow on the nerve tissues. There are 3 types of neurofibromatosis which include neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1), neurofibromatosis 2 (NF2) and schwannomatosis. 
  • There is no particular cure for these disorders, but the sign and symptoms are treated conservatively.

Option D: Aicardi syndrome

  • It is a rare genetic disorder that exclusively involves females. It is congenital in nature and presents with a malformation in the brain, eyes and other parts.
  • This syndrome is characterised by agenesis of the corpus callosum, retinal colobomas, infantile spasms in girls, and intellectual disability.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male presents with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, including pneumonia and skin abscesses. Blood cultures reveal Staphylococcus aureus and Aspergillus fumigatus. A nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test shows decreased neutrophil oxidative burst. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option A

  • The recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, especially with Staphylococcus aureus and Aspergillus fumigatus, along with a decreased neutrophil oxidative burst on the NBT test, strongly suggest a diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). CGD is an inherited primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by recurrent and severe bacterial and fungal infections. In CGD, the neutrophils and macrophages are unable to produce the reactive oxygen species necessary for microbial killing, leading to persistent infections and granuloma formation. 

Why the other answers are incorrect:

B) Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), X-linked agammaglobulinemia, and DiGeorge syndrome are also primary immunodeficiency disorders, but they present with different clinical features and laboratory findings. SCID is characterized by severe and life-threatening infections, failure to thrive, and absence of T-cell function.

C) X-linked agammaglobulinemia is characterized by recurrent bacterial infections, absent or decreased serum immunoglobulin levels, and absent B cells. 

D) DiGeorge syndrome is characterized by thymic hypoplasia or aplasia, and T-cell deficiency leading to recurrent infections, cardiac anomalies, and hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man complains of sudden dyspnea, diaphoresis and palpitations while climbing the stairs. His past medical history is significant for hypertension for 15 years. He is not compliant with antihypertensive drugs. An ECG reveals left ventricular hypertrophy. Echocardiography shows an ejection fraction of 40%. Which of the following transcription factors is not associated with cellular hypertrophy?
questions.solution:
Option D: MLL1

  • The patient presents with dyspnea, diaphoresis, palpitations, and an ejection fraction of 40%, which are cardinal features of cardiac failure.
  • The patient also had a history of uncontrolled hypertension which led to left ventricular hypertrophy with concomitant heart failure.
  • Signalling pathways which trigger hypertrophy activate a set of transcription factors such as:
  • GATA 4
  • Nuclear factor of activated T-cells (NFAT)
  • Myocyte enhancer factor-2 (MEF2)
  • These transcription factors work in coordination to increase the synthesis of muscle proteins responsible for hypertrophy.
  • MLL 1 (Mixed lineage leukaemia protein-1) is a gene in acute leukaemia.

Option A: GATA 4

  • It is a family of zinc-finger transcription factors which promote cardiomyocyte survival and cardiac morphogenesis and maintains cardiac function in the adult heart.

Option B. NFAT

  • It is found mostly in immune-system cells, which play a role in the transcription of cytokine and other genes responsible for the immune response.
  • It is involved in cardiac, skeletal and nerve development.

Option C. Myocyte enhancer factor-2 (MEF2)

  • MEF2 codes for a transcription factor involved in the normal development of the following
    • Body's vascular (blood flow)
    • Heart 
    • Craniofacial
    • Brain
    • Immune systems.

questions.text: A disoriented 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency room. Jaundice, splenomegaly, and ascites are discovered on physical examination. ALT, AST, alkaline phosphatase, and bilirubin levels increase in the blood. Alcoholic hepatitis with Mallory bodies is shown by a liver biopsy. Mallory bodies have cytoplasmic structures made up of braided bundles of?
questions.solution:
Option C: Intermediate filaments

  • The eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion of alcoholic (Mallory) hyaline comprises intermediate cytoskeletal filaments (cytokeratins).
  • Alcoholic liver disease has three stages:
    • Stage 1 is hepatic steatosis
    • Stage 2 is alcoholic hepatitis
    • Stage 3 is alcoholic cirrhosis
  • Stage 1 and stage 2 are reversible but stay 3 is irreversible form.

Option A: α1-Antitrypsin

  • Alpha anti-trypsin is a protein that is produced in the liver.
  • It protects the body tissues from being damaged by infection-fighting agents released by the immune system.

Option B: β-Amyloid (Aβ)

  • Beta-amyloid peptide is a 42 amino acid peptide.
  • This protein plays an important role in the function of voltage-gated calcium and potassium channels at the surface of neurons.
  • It plays a key role in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease.

Option D: Prion protein (PrP)

  • Prions are the type of misfolded proteins.

  • They characterize several transmissible neurodegenerative diseases in animals as well as humans such as CJD (Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease).

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman loses her right kidney following an automobile accident. A CT scan of her abdomen 2 years later shows a marked enlargement of her left kidney. Kidney enlargement is an example of which of the following adaptations?
questions.solution:
Option D: Hypertrophy

  • Hypertrophy is an increase in the size of cells that increases the size of the affected organ.

  • It is caused by increased functional demand or stimulation by hormones and growth factors.

  • Hyperplasia of renal tubular cells may occur, but a kidney enlargement in this patient is best referred to as hypertrophy (i.e., increased organ size and function).

Option A: Atrophy

  • Atrophy is the reduction in the size of cell organelle tissue after attaining its normal mature growth.

  • For example muscle atrophy due to disuse of muscle

Option B: Dysplasia

  • Dysplasia is an abnormal and potentially reversible process where there is the organized growth and maturation of cells.

  • Dysplasia can be

    • Mild

    • Moderate 

    • Sever

Option C: Hyperplasia

  • Hyperplasia is an increase in the number of cells in response to stress in labile cells.

  • There are two types of hyperplasia:

    • Physiologic hyperplasia: Occurs in response to a normal stressor. Examples include the epidermis, epithelia of ducts, and hematopoietic stem cells.

    • Pathologic hyperplasia: Occurs in response to an abnormal stressor. Examples include the growth of adrenal glands due to excessive adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) production by a pituitary adenoma and the proliferation of endometrium due to prolonged estrogen stimulus.

questions.text: A 77-year-old Male with a history of falls from height complained of an inability to raise his right arm above the shoulder. On examination, redness, tenderness, warmth, and swelling are appreciated. No deformity and crepitus are noted. An X-ray is ordered, and an obvious bony injury is noted. The fifth clinical sign was added by?
questions.solution:
Option A: Claudius Galen

Functio laesa is a term used in medicine to refer to a loss of function or a disturbance of function.

It was identified as the fifth sign of acute inflammation by Galen, who added it to the four signs identified by Celsus (tumor, rubor, calor, and dolor)

Option B: Elie Metchinkoff

  • Metchnikoff described the process of phagocytosis.

Option C: Louis Pasteur

  • Louis Pasteur described pasteurization, the principles of vaccination and fermentation.

Option D: Robert Koch

  • Robert Koch identified the causative agents of tuberculosis, cholera, and anthrax

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents to the gynaecology department with complaints of recurrent abortions over the last two years. She is further evaluated, and it is revealed that chromosomal abnormalities caused the recurrent abortions. A study shows that when a chromosome splits along an axis, the axis is perpendicular to the conventional division axis. What is formed when a chromosome is applied along an axis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Isochromosome

  • The female mentioned above has been having recurrent abortions for the last two years. Further examination revealed that chromosomal abnormalities are the cause.
  • Isochromosome formation occurs when one arm of a chromosome is deleted while the other is duplicated.
  • This results in a chromosome with only two short arms or two long arms.
  • Genetic information in both limbs is morphologically identical.
  • The centromere misdivision is the cause of the creation of an isochromosome
  • Instead of dividing longitudinally to separate the two sister chromatids, the centromere undergoes a transverse split that separates the two arms.
  • Examples: Xq, 17q, 12p

Option A: Ring chromosome

  • A ring chromosome is an aberrant whose ends have fused to form a ring.

Option C: Acrocentric chromosome

  • An acrocentric chromosome is where the centromere is not central and is located near the end.
  • Humans generally have five pairs of acrocentric autosomes (chromosomes 13, 14, 15, 21, 22).
  • The Y chromosome is also acrocentric.

Option D: Subtelocentric chromosome

  • A sub-telocentric chromosome is a centromere between its middle and end but closer to the end.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought by his mother with a complaint of fever for the last two days. Upon examination, the child has short thumbs, short great toes, and hypospadias. He is evaluated, and a urine examination is requested, which shows pus cells. The child had a history of recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs). Name the gene responsible for the given condition.
questions.solution:
Option B: HOXA 13 gene

  • The given clinical scenario is a case of Hand-foot-genital syndrome (HFGS), which is caused by mutations of HOXA13.
  • HOX gene (Homeobox gene).
  • Normal morphogenesis during development includes:
    • Plays a role in forming limbs, vertebrae, and craniofacial structures.
    • It possesses retinoic acid response elements (RAREs), which are required to mediate retinoids' physiologic and pathologic effects.
    • Mutations of HOXD13 cause synpolydactyly in heterozygous individuals. Mutations of HOXA13 cause Hand-foot-genital syndrome.
  • Patients with this syndrome have abnormally short thumbs and first (big) toes, small fifth fingers that curve inward (clinodactyly), short feet, and fusion or delayed hardening of bones in the wrists and ankles.
  • The other bones in the arms and legs are normal.

Option A: FMR1 gene

  • A trinucleotide expansion mutation in the FMR1 gene causes hereditary mental retardation.
  • The given clinical scenario is a case of Hand-foot-genital syndrome (HFGS), which is caused by mutations of HOXA13.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option C: P-16

  • The most common genetic cause of intellectual disability in males, p16 p16/INK4a, binds to cyclin D–CDK4 promotes the inhibitory effects of RB p16, protects cells from uncontrolled mitogenic signals, and pushes cells along the senescence pathway.

Option D: PTEN

  • PTEN is a multi-functional tumour suppressor frequently deleted in human cancers, notably prostate cancer, glioblastoma, endometrial cancer, lung cancer, and breast cancer.
  • It's part of the PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathway, and mTOR inhibitors haven't proven very effective in treating patients with PTEN loss.

questions.text: A 67-years-old female presented to the clinic with intermittent abdominal pain and watery diarrhoea that had been present for 1 year. Symptomatic treatment temporarily alleviated the symptoms. The patient had no nausea, vomiting, melena, or tenesmus, and his medical and family histories were non-significant. Tenderness in the epigastrium was found on physical examination, but there was no rebound tenderness. There were no obvious changes in thyroid function or tumour markers. The gastrin level in the patient was abnormally high (864.19 pg/ml; normal range, 25–100 pg/ml). PTH and blood calcium levels were both within normal limits. No abnormalities were seen on CT or MRI scans. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor

  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) is a triad of pancreatic non-beta islet cell tumours (gastrinomas), hypergastrinemia, and severe ulcer disease.
  • Gastrinomas are the tumours of G cells.
  • There is significant hypersecretion of gastric acid and growth of the stomach mucosa due to persistent hypergastrinemia.
  • Clinical features include:
  • Gastro-oesophagal reflux disease
  • Diarrhoea
  • Abdominal pain
  • The propensity of tumour is for the duodenum, followed by the pancreas and intraabdominal sites such as the liver, stomach, biliary tract, mesentery, lymph nodes, and ovaries.
  • Investigations include:
  • The provocative secretin test is usually positive, with the criterion of a >120 pg/mL increase over the basal level
  • Fasting gastric pH <2 and fasting hypergastrinemia when off anti-secretory drugs.
  • Plasma-ionised calcium levels
  • Serum prolactin levels
  • Plasma parathyroid hormone and growth hormone levels
  • Increased basal acid output (BAO)
  • For primary tumour localisation in ZES, endoscopic ultrasonography is more accurate than portal venous sampling, which is more accurate than Octreoscan.
  • Octreoscan is the most accurate non-invasive technique for metastatic gastrinomas.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid

  • Medullary thyroid cancer is a tumour that develops from the thyroid gland's parafollicular cells or C cells.
  • Calcitonin is produced by medullary thyroid carcinoma, and a high calcitonin level is a crucial characteristic of this malignancy.
  • The thyroid's medullary carcinoma marker is calcitonin, and GIST is CD117 (c-kit).
  • It is generated from the neural crest-derived medullary C cells.
  • Recent advancements in molecular aetiology and genetic testing have resulted in patient risk assessment and the discovery of molecular targets for treatment.
  • Patients with mutations at high risk should have a prophylactic thyroidectomy.
  • Different tyrosine kinase inhibitors are licenced to treat advanced, metastatic medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Option C: Pheochromocytoma

  • Pheochromocytoma is a tumour that develops from chromaffin cells in the adrenal medulla or paraganglion cells.
  • It can cause nonspecific symptoms such as a headache (50%), palpitations (60%), and diaphoresis (50%), which might lead to a paroxysmal hypertensive crisis owing to elevated catecholamine production.

Option D: Gastrointestinal stromal tumour

  • GISTs originate in the soft mesenchymal tissue of the gastrointestinal system and result from the fast proliferation of interstitial cells (ICCs).
  • GISTs are the most frequent gastrointestinal tumours in the small intestine or stomach.
  • GISTs are most frequent in people between the ages of 40 and 70 and are uncommon in children and young adults.
  • Individuals suffering from these tumours may have abdominal swelling, discomfort, vomiting, nausea, appetite loss, weight loss, low blood cell counts, gastrointestinal bleeding (resulting in bloody or black faeces), weakness, and exhaustion.
  • The prognosis for these tumours greatly depends on tumour size and mitotic rate; however, roughly 60% of GISTs are benign.
  • The primary treatment strategy is surgery to remove the tumour; however, imatinib, everolimus, and rapamycin may soon be authorised as additional therapy and care options.

questions.text: A 64-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of chronic cough, weight loss and hemoptysis. Bronchoscopy and histopathological biopsy are shown below. What are the most specific markers for this type of cancer?
questions.solution:
Option A: Chromogranin

  • The histopathological picture above shows small, round, oval cells with a high nuclear/cytoplasmic ratio. The nuclei have finely dispersed or “salt and pepper” chromatin and absent nucleoli.
  • The above-shown histology points towards small-cell lung cancer.
  • It is the most aggressive type of lung cancer.
  • Small cell cancer of the lung originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells.
  • It can secrete polypeptide hormones.
  • There is a presence of neuroendocrine markers such as chromogranin, synaptophysin and CD57 in 75% of cases.
  • Parathormone-like and other hormonally active products are also secreted.
  • It has neurosecretory granules which release DNA material from the tumour cells resulting in the Azzopardi effect.

 

 

Option B: Cytokeratin

  • Cytokeratin is a sensitive and specific marker for epithelial tumours such as squamous cell carcinoma.

Option C: Desmin

  • Desmin is a particular marker for muscle tumours such as rhabdomyosarcomas.

Option D: Vimentin

  • Vimentin is a marker for mesenchymal tumours such as sarcomas and many other tumours such as endometrial, renal cell, and meningioma.

questions.text: Which transcription factor is responsible for the induction of apoptosis in response to DNA damage?
questions.solution:
Option A

p53 is the correct answer because it is a well-known transcription factor that plays a crucial role in the cellular response to DNA damage. p53 is activated in response to various types of stress, including DNA damage, and induces the expression of several genes that promote cell cycle arrest, DNA repair, and apoptosis. The induction of apoptosis by p53 helps to eliminate cells with severe DNA damage that cannot be repaired, preventing the propagation of damaged cells and reducing the risk of cancer development. In contrast, the other transcription factors listed in the options (NF-κB, STAT3, and c-Myc) do not have a direct role in the induction of apoptosis in response to DNA damage.

Why are Others Incorrect?

Option B

NF-κB is incorrect because it is a transcription factor that is primarily involved in the regulation of immune and inflammatory responses, as well as cell survival and proliferation. While NF-κB has been implicated in regulating apoptosis in certain contexts, such as during development and in response to some types of stress, its role in the induction of apoptosis in response to DNA damage is less well-established. Therefore, it is not the correct answer to the question.

Option C

 STAT3 is incorrect because it is a transcription factor that is mainly involved in regulating cell growth, differentiation, and survival in response to cytokines and growth factors. While it has been implicated in apoptosis in some contexts, it is not the primary transcription factor responsible for the induction of apoptosis in response to DNA damage. Therefore, it is not the correct answer to the question.

Option D

c-Myc is incorrect because it is a transcription factor that regulates cell growth and proliferation, and is involved in the development of many cancers. While it has been shown to promote apoptosis in certain contexts, such as in response to prolonged cellular stress or DNA damage, it is not the primary transcription factor responsible for the induction of apoptosis in response to DNA damage. Therefore, it is not the correct answer to the question.

questions.text: Karyolysis and karyorrhexis are two processes that can occur in cells. Which of the following accurately describes karyolysis?

choices.text: The fragmentation of a cell's nucleus
The dissolution of the chromatin within a cell's nucleus
The rupture of the cell's membrane
The clumping of nuclear material within a cell's cytoplasm

questions.solution:
Option B 

  • Karyolysis is a process that involves the dissolution or breakdown of chromatin within a cell's nucleus. Chromatin is the material that makes up a cell's chromosomes, containing DNA and various proteins. During karyolysis, the chromatin within the nucleus becomes disrupted and broken down. This process can occur in response to various factors, including cellular injury or death. It can be observed under a microscope as the nucleus's diffuse or "smudged" appearance.

Why Others are incorrect 

A. The fragmentation of a cell's nucleus - It describes karyorrhexis, not karyolysis. Karyorrhexis is a process where the nucleus of a cell ruptures or fragments, resulting in the formation of multiple small nuclear fragments. In contrast, karyolysis refers to the dissolution or breakdown of the chromatin within a cell's nucleus, leading to a diffuse or smudged nucleus appearance.

  • Therefore, option A is incorrect as it does not accurately describe karyolysis, and instead describes karyorrhexis, which is a different process.

C. The rupture of the cell's membrane - It does not describe karyolysis or karyorrhexis. Karyolysis and karyorrhexis are both processes that occur within the nucleus of a cell. In contrast, the rupture of the cell's membrane refers to a disruption or breakage of the cell's outer membrane.

D. The clumping of nuclear material within a cell's cytoplasm - It does not describe karyolysis, which is the process in question. Karyolysis involves the dissolution or breakdown of the chromatin within a cell's nucleus and does not involve the clumping of nuclear material in the cytoplasm.

 

  • Clumping of nuclear material in the cytoplasm can occur in certain situations, such as in viral infections or certain types of cancer.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with muscle weakness and atrophy, especially in the hands and forearms. On examination, there is wasting of the muscles with fasciculations and diminished reflexes. A muscle biopsy shows intranuclear inclusions and eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions. Immunohistochemical staining of the biopsy specimen shows aggregation of an intermediate filament protein. Which of the following is the most likely intermediate filament protein that is involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B

  •  It is the correct answer because the clinical scenario described is most consistent with desmin-related myopathy, which is a form of muscular dystrophy caused by mutations in the desmin gene. Desmin is an intermediate filament protein that is expressed in muscle cells and plays a critical role in maintaining the structural integrity of muscle fibers. In desmin-related myopathy, mutations in the desmin gene lead to abnormal aggregation of desmin protein in muscle cells, which in turn causes the muscle fibers to degenerate and leads to the clinical symptoms of muscle weakness, atrophy, and fasciculations seen in the patient described in the scenario. Therefore, desmin is the most likely intermediate filament protein involved in this condition.

 

Why the others are incorrect 

Option A

  • It is incorrect because keratin is an intermediate filament protein found in epithelial cells, not muscle cells. It is involved in maintaining the structural integrity of skin, hair, and nails. While mutations in keratin genes can cause a variety of skin and hair disorders, they are not typically associated with muscular dystrophies or muscle-related diseases. Therefore, it is unlikely that a patient with muscle weakness and atrophy due to a muscular dystrophy would have a mutation in a keratin gene.

 

Option C

  • It  is incorrect because neurofilaments are intermediate filament proteins found in neurons, not muscle cells. They are involved in maintaining the structural integrity of neurons and axons. Mutations in neurofilament genes can cause various forms of motor neuron disease, but they are not typically associated with muscular dystrophies or muscle-related diseases that lead to muscle weakness and atrophy. Therefore, it is unlikely that a patient with muscle weakness and atrophy due to a muscular dystrophy would have a mutation in a neurofilament gene.

Option D

  • It is incorrect because lamin A is an intermediate filament protein found in the nucleus of cells, not in muscle cells. It is involved in maintaining the structural integrity of the nuclear envelope and regulating gene expression. Mutations in the lamin A gene can cause various genetic disorders, including Hutchinson-Gilford progeria syndrome, but they are not typically associated with muscular dystrophies or muscle-related diseases that lead to muscle weakness and atrophy. Therefore, it is unlikely that a patient with muscle weakness and atrophy due to a muscular dystrophy would have a mutation in the lamin A gene

questions.text: What term describes the programmed cell death that is initiated in response to infection or cellular stress, is mediated by inflammasomes, results in the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines, and is characterized by cell swelling, plasma membrane rupture, and the release of cytoplasmic contents?
questions.solution:
Option C

  • Pyroptosis describes the type of programmed cell death initiated in response to infection or cellular stress, mediated by inflammasomes and characterized by the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines. Unlike apoptosis or autophagy, pyroptosis leads to the release of cellular contents and the induction of an inflammatory response, an important part of the host's defense against pathogens.

Why Others are incorrect 

A. Apoptosis is a different type of programmed cell death characterized by controlled cellular dismantling without inducing an inflammatory response. Unlike pyroptosis, apoptosis is a homeostatic process involved in normal physiological processes, such as tissue development and maintenance, and does not play a role in host defense against pathogens.

B. Necrosis is a type of uncontrolled cell death that occurs due to acute cellular injury or trauma. Unlike pyroptosis, necrosis is a pathological process that leads to the release of cellular contents and triggers an inflammatory response. However, the inflammatory response in necrosis is not mediated by inflammasomes, as in pyroptosis.

D. Autophagy is a cellular process that involves degrading cellular components in lysosomes. Unlike pyroptosis, autophagy is a mechanism for recycling cellular materials and maintaining cellular homeostasis, and it does not directly induce cell death. While autophagy can be triggered by cellular stress, it does not lead to the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines, which is a key characteristic of pyroptosis.

questions.text: What change in the blood picture is expected after a person climbs a mountain in an hour?

choices.text: Oxygen concentration of venous blood is high
Arteriovenous gradient of oxygen is high
Affinity of hemoglobin to oxygen increases
Shift to the right in the Oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve

questions.solution:
Option D

  • When a person climbs a mountain, there is a decrease in atmospheric pressure and oxygen tension. This leads to a decrease in the partial pressure of oxygen in the blood, which in turn causes a shift to the right in the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve. This shift allows for increased oxygen release to the tissues, which is necessary to compensate for the decreased oxygen tension.

Why the others are incorrect 

Option A

  • Oxygen concentration of venous blood is high, is incorrect because the oxygen concentration of venous blood is normally low, and climbing a mountain does not lead to an increase in venous blood oxygen concentration.

Option B

  • Arteriovenous gradient of oxygen is high, is incorrect because the arteriovenous gradient of oxygen is normally high and does not change significantly with mountain climbing.

Option C

  • Affinity of hemoglobin to oxygen increases, is incorrect because the affinity of hemoglobin to oxygen decreases with a shift to the right in the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve, which is what happens during mountain climbing.

questions.text: Which family of proteases is involved in programmed cell death and cleavage of cellular proteins, with different types having distinct mechanisms and functions in cellular processes such as inflammation and differentiation?
questions.solution:
Option C

  • Caspases are the correct option because they are a family of proteases that specifically cleave proteins during programmed cell death, leading to apoptosis. They play a critical role in regulating apoptosis and are activated in response to various stimuli, such as DNA damage or developmental cues. 

 

Why Others are incorrect 

Option A: Cytokines are signaling molecules involved in cell-to-cell communication and immune responses, but they do not directly role in programmed cell death. Cytokines can, however, indirectly influence apoptosis by regulating the expression of pro- and anti-apoptotic genes.

Option B: Lipases are enzymes that break down lipids, crucial in cellular metabolism and energy storage. However, lipases are not involved in programmed cell death or the cleavage of cellular proteins during apoptosis.

Option D: Kinases are enzymes that add phosphate groups to proteins, playing an important role in signaling pathways that regulate many cellular processes, including cell growth and division, metabolism, and apoptosis. However, kinases are not involved in the cleavage cellular proteins during programmed cell death, which is a critical function of caspases.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with muscle weakness and atrophy in his right arm, which has been gradually worsening over the past few months. On examination, it is noted that his right biceps muscle is visibly smaller than his left. An electromyography (EMG) is performed, which shows denervation in the right biceps muscle. What type of atrophy is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option B

  • Neurogenic atrophy is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms. The presence of denervation in the right biceps muscle on EMG suggests that the muscle is not receiving adequate nerve signals from the nervous system, leading to atrophy. Disuse atrophy is caused by lack of use or immobilization of a muscle and would not be expected in this patient, as he is experiencing weakness and atrophy in only one arm. Ischemic atrophy occurs when there is inadequate blood supply to a muscle, and hormonal atrophy occurs due to changes in hormone levels. Neither of these types of atrophy are likely to be responsible for the patient's symptoms.

Why the others are incorrect 

Option A

  • Disuse atrophy, is an incorrect answer because this type of atrophy is caused by lack of use or immobilization of a muscle, which is not the case in this patient. The patient is experiencing weakness and atrophy in only one arm, which suggests a localized problem rather than disuse of the muscle. Therefore, disuse atrophy is an unlikely cause of the patient's symptoms.

Option C

  • Ischemic atrophy, is an incorrect answer because ischemic atrophy occurs when there is inadequate blood supply to a muscle. However, in the scenario given, there is no indication of decreased blood flow to the affected arm. Additionally, the patient's symptoms of weakness and atrophy are localized to one arm, which suggests a nerve-related problem rather than a vascular problem. Therefore, ischemic atrophy is an unlikely cause of the patient's symptoms.

Option D

  • Hypertrophic atrophy, is an incorrect answer because hypertrophic atrophy is the increase in muscle size due to increased workload or exercise. This is the opposite of what is described in the scenario, where the patient is experiencing weakness and atrophy in one arm. Therefore, hypertrophic atrophy is an unlikely cause of the patient's symptoms.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions is caused by a genetic defect affecting fibrillin, leading to a weakened connective tissue and resulting in skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular abnormalities?

Histopathologic features of this disorder include disorganized elastic fibers in the aortic media and fragmentation of the tunica media. The diagnosis is typically made through a combination of clinical features, family history, and genetic testing.
questions.solution:
Option B

  • Marfan's syndrome is caused by a genetic defect affecting fibrillin, leading to weakened connective tissue and resulting in skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular abnormalities. Histopathologic features of this disorder include disorganized elastic fibers in the aortic media and fragmentation of the tunica media. The diagnosis is typically made through a combination of clinical features, family history, and genetic testing.

Why Others are incorrect 

Option A 

  • Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is incorrect because although it is also a genetic disorder that affects connective tissues, it is caused by a defect in the synthesis or processing of collagen rather than fibrillin.

Option C

  • Turner syndrome, is not caused by a defect affecting fibrillin, which is the protein affected in Marfan's syndrome. Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder that occurs in females due to the absence or partial absence of one X chromosome. This condition is characterized by short stature, delayed puberty, infertility, and a variety of other physical and medical features, but it does not involve the connective tissue abnormalities seen in Marfan's syndrome.

Option D

  • Down syndrome is a chromosomal disorder that occurs when there is an extra copy of chromosome 21. This leads to a range of physical and intellectual disabilities, but it does not primarily affect the connective tissues in the body. In contrast, Marfan's syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting connective tissues, leading to skeletal, cardiovascular, and ocular abnormalities.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with recurrent hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, growth retardation, and polyuria is found to have elevated glycogen levels in the liver and kidney. Further investigation reveals a mutation in the GLUT-2 transporter. Which of the following diseases is most likely associated with this GLUT-2 mutation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Fanconi-Bickel syndrome

  • Autosomal recessive condition caused due to allelic variants of GLUT-2 arisen due to mutations.
  • C/F
    • Resembles type I GSD (von Gierke’s disease) - Glycogen deposited in liver and kidney
    • Fasting hypoglycemia but postprandial hyperglycemia
    • Patients are usually dwarf, with rickets, aminoaciduria, phosphaturia, glucosuria, Proximal tubulopathy and hypercalciuria

Option A: Menke's disease

  • It is a condition of copper deficiency due to mutation in intestinal Cu transporter ATP7A
  • Cu stays in intestinal cells, unable to enter the blood, causing ↓ plasma Cu
  • It is characterized by:
    • Kinky hair
    • Greying of hair
    • Growth Retardation

Option C: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome

  • It is characterized by hemihypertrophy; one side of the body is significantly larger than the other.
  • Midface hypoplasia, macroglossia, omphalocele, and macrosomia may also present.

Option D: Dandy-Walker syndrome

  • It is a rare disorder affecting brain where cerebellum and fourth ventricle is mainly affected.
  • It is usually caused by chromosomal genetic condition causing impaired cell migration and division affecting development of the cerebellar vermis.

questions.text: A 1-month-old male child with nervous system abnormalities and lactic acidosis showed low pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) activity with low levels of thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP), but increased activity with high levels of TPP. Which one of the following statements concerning this patient is most correct?

choices.text: Elevated levels of lactate and pyruvate in the blood reliably predict the presence of Pyruvate Kinase deficiency.
The patient is expected to show disturbances in fatty acid degradation.
A diet consisting of high carbohydrate intake would be expected to be beneficial in this patient.
Alanine concentration in the blood is expected to be less than normal.
Administration of thiamine is expected to reduce his serum lactate concentration and improve his clinical symptoms.

questions.solution:
Option E: Administration of thiamine is expected to reduce his serum lactate concentration and improve his clinical symptoms

  • PDH is the enzyme of link reaction. In this patient, enzyme fails to bind TPP at low concentration, but shows significant activity at a high concentration of the coenzyme. So, the condition shows a Thiamine-responsive PDH deficiency.
  • It is also associated with elevated levels of lactate, Pyruvate and alanine
  • Patients shows:
    • Neuroanatomic defects
    • Developmental delay
    • Early death
  • Rx- diet low in carbohydrates

Option A: Elevated levels of lactate and pyruvate in the blood reliably predict the presence of Pyruvate Kinase deficiency

  • In pyruvate kinase deficiency, less pyruvate will be formed from glycolysis.
  • So, a low pyruvate will give rise to low lactate levels Hence both will be decreased not increased in PK deficiency.

Option B: The patient is expected to show disturbances in fatty acid degradation.

  • PDH is not involved directly in fatty acid degradation.
  • As the levels of acetyl CoA are decreased so one might think that FA degradation will be increased. But it generally does not happen as TG breakdown require increased glucagon and low insulin.
  • But levels of these hormones are not affected in PDH deficiency.

Option C: A diet consisting of high carbohydrate intake would be expected to be beneficial in this patient

  • High carbohydrate diet would lead to high pyruvate and lactate formation due to inhibition of link reaction. It will exaggerate the symptoms instead of giving any relief.

Option D: Alanine concentration in the blood is expected to be less than normal

  • As glucose-alanine cycle will not be working so alanine will accumulate in blood.
  • High pyruvate will be converted to form increased alanine by transamination.

questions.text:
A 15-day-old baby is brought to the clinic by his mother with the complaint of frequent vomiting. He has recently started feeding on breast milk. An appropriate diagnosis is made, and the patient is discharged after the resolution of the symptoms. A few days later, the baby presents to the clinic again with jaundice. On examination, there is hepatosplenomegaly. Ocular examination shows the following findings:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Galactosemia

  • The cataract shown is an Oil Drop Cataract, which is characteristic of Galactosemia.
  • These clinical manifestations of the liver affected when milk is the diet is typical of Classical Galactosemia.

Option B: Juvenile Diabetes Mellitus

  • In Juvenile Diabetes Mellitus, jaundice and hepatomegaly are observed, but cataract is never there.

Option C: Hereditary Fructose Intolerance

  • Bilateral cataracts rule out the possibility of Hereditary Fructose Intolerance, although other symptoms exist in both these diseases.

Option D: Gaucher's disease

  • Gaucher's disease is a sphingolipidosis due to deficiency of β-Glucosidase or β-Glucocerebrosidase with an accumulation of Glucosylceramide.
  • Clinical features include No mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, and osteoporosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of decreased vision in both eyes. His medical history is consistent with diabetes for the past 20 years.  A diagnosis of Snowflake cataract is made. Which of the following enzymes is responsible for this type of cataract?
questions.solution:
Option A: Aldose reductase

  • In diabetics, excess glucose freely enters the cells of the eye, which are highly permeable to glucose.
  • Here, glucose is reduced by the aldose reductase enzyme to produce sorbitol/polyol.
  • In other cells, this sorbitol is oxidized to keto sugar fructose by the enzyme sorbitol dehydrogenase, but this enzyme is absent in the eye, hence sorbitol accumulation.
  • Sorbitol is hygroscopic and absorbs water, causing swelling of the cells.
  • Swelling due to excess sorbitol in the lens ultimately leads to a snowflake cataract.

Option B: Galactose reductase

  • This enzyme does the same reaction as aldose reductase but works specifically on galactose to produce galactitol
  • The galactitol accumulation in eyes causes oil-drop cataract in galactosemic patients.

Option C: Fructose dehydrogenase

  • This is a bacterial enzyme and is not present in humans.
  • It performs 2 electron oxidations of D-fructose to 2-keto-D-fructose.

Option D: Alcohol dehydrogenase

  • Alcohol dehydrogenase is a common enzyme involved in the metabolism and detoxification of any alcohol.
  • It catalyzes the oxidation of any alcohol to its aldehyde form, e.g., ethanol to acetaldehyde and methanol to formaldehyde.
  • These relatively toxic aldehydes are further oxidized to their harmless acid form by respective aldehyde dehydrogenases.

questions.text: What is the primary explanation for the beneficial effect of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) in reducing the incidence of atherosclerosis?

choices.text: Transport of cholesterol from the liver to extrahepatic tissues

questions.solution:
Option D: Removes cholesterol from extrahepatic tissues

HDL

  • Good and bad cholesterol terminology was used earlier. Now, the terms' good' & 'bad' cholesterol are discarded.
  • HDL was called good cholesterol because of reverse cholesterol transport, i.e., it takes cholesterol from peripheral tissue to the liver.
  • HDL converts this cholesterol into cholesterol ester with the help of the LCAT–lecithin cholesterol acyl transferase. This enzyme transfers fatty acid from Lecithin (a phospholipid) to cholesterol. After losing fatty acid, Lecithin becomes lysolecithin.

Option A: Activates lipoprotein lipase

  • Lipoprotein lipase enzyme helps in removal of TG from chylomicrons and VLDL to be deposited in adipose tissues and used in peripheral cells
  • It is activated in fed state by insulin

Option B: Stimulate hepatic TGs synthesis

  • TG is synthesized in liver if excess dietary fats are consumed.
  • Insulin stimulate hepatic TG synthesis in fed state.
  • In alcoholics and diabetics, TG synthesis is enhanced in liver due to low NADH/NAD ratio causing fatty liver.

Option C: Causes transport to extrahepatic tissues

  • LDL transports cholesterol to extrahepatic tissues from liver.
  • It can transport both endogenous and exogenous cholesterol.

questions.text: Which electron transport chain complex is inhibited by rotenone, and what is the consequence of this inhibition?
