choices.text: Complex I is inhibited, leading to a decrease in NADH oxidation and ATP production.
Complex II is inhibited, leading to a decrease in FADH2 oxidation and ATP production.
Complex III is inhibited, leading to a decrease in cytochrome c oxidation and ATP production.
Complex IV is inhibited, leading to a decrease in oxygen consumption and ATP production.

questions.solution:
Explanation: Option A

  • Rotenone is a naturally occurring pesticide that is commonly used as an insecticide. It is also known to inhibit complex I in the electron transport chain (ETC). Complex I is responsible for oxidizing NADH and transferring electrons to the ETC, and its inhibition by rotenone leads to a decrease in NADH oxidation and a subsequent decrease in ATP production. Therefore, the correct answer is A. Complex II is not affected by rotenone, and its inhibition would not affect NADH oxidation or ATP production. Complex III is inhibited by antimycin A, not rotenone. Complex IV is inhibited by cyanide, not rotenone, and its inhibition would lead to a decrease in oxygen consumption rather than NADH oxidation.

Why Others are incorrect:

Option B

  • Option B is incorrect because rotenone inhibits Complex I in the electron transport chain (ETC), not Complex II. Complex II is also known as succinate dehydrogenase and is not affected by rotenone. Therefore, the inhibition of Complex II by rotenone would not affect NADH oxidation or ATP production.

Option C

  • Option C is incorrect because rotenone inhibits Complex I in the electron transport chain (ETC), not Complex III. Complex III is also known as cytochrome c reductase and is inhibited by antimycin A, not rotenone. Therefore, the inhibition of Complex III by rotenone would not affect NADH oxidation or ATP production.

Option D

  • Option D is incorrect because rotenone inhibits Complex I in the electron transport chain (ETC), not Complex IV. Complex IV is also known as cytochrome c oxidase and is inhibited by cyanide, not rotenone. Therefore, the inhibition of Complex IV by rotenone would not affect NADH oxidation or ATP production. Additionally, the inhibition of Complex IV by cyanide would lead to a decrease in oxygen consumption rather than NADH oxidation.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presents with developmental delay, seizures, and hepatosplenomegaly. She has a cherry-red spot on her macula and a coarse facial appearance. A urine analysis shows high levels of oligosaccharides. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option C:

  • The clinical presentation described in this question is consistent with Tay-Sachs disease, a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of hexosaminidase A. The symptoms of Tay-Sachs disease typically appear in infancy or early childhood and include developmental delay, seizures, cherry-red spot on the macula, and a coarse facial appearance. Hepatosplenomegaly and high levels of oligosaccharides in the urine are also characteristic findings in Tay-Sachs disease.

Why other options are incorrect:

A) Gaucher disease

  • Gaucher disease is another lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase. The clinical presentation may include hepatosplenomegaly, bone pain, and anemia, but it does not typically include seizures or a cherry-red spot on the macula.

B) Niemann-Pick disease type A

  • Niemann-Pick disease type A is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of sphingomyelinase. The clinical presentation may include hepatosplenomegaly, developmental delay, and failure to thrive, but it does not typically include a cherry-red spot on the macula.

D) Hurler syndrome

  • Hurler syndrome is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency of alpha-L-iduronidase. The clinical presentation may include developmental delay, coarse facial features, and hepatosplenomegaly, but it does not typically include a cherry-red spot on the macula or seizures. In addition, high levels of oligosaccharides in the urine are not characteristic findings in Hurler syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following mitochondrial DNA mutations is associated with the MELAS syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option A

MELAS (Mitochondrial Encephalopathy, Lactic Acidosis, and Stroke-like episodes) syndrome is a mitochondrial disorder characterized by a variety of neurological symptoms, such as seizures, migraines, and dementia. It is caused by mutations in the mitochondrial DNA, with the most common mutation being the m.3243A>G mutation. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

Why Others are incorrect:

Option B

  • Option B (m.8344A>G) is associated with the MERRF (Myoclonic Epilepsy with Ragged Red Fibers) syndrome. This mutation affects the tRNA gene for lysine, leading to impaired mitochondrial protein synthesis and resulting in the symptoms of MERRF syndrome, which include myoclonus, seizures, and ataxia. However, this mutation is not associated with MELAS syndrome, so option B is incorrect in the context of this question.

Option C

  • Option C (m.8993T>G) is associated with both the NARP (Neurogenic Ataxia and Retinitis Pigmentosa) syndrome and Leigh syndrome. This mutation affects the ATP synthase complex in the electron transport chain, leading to impaired ATP production and energy generation in affected cells. Although this mutation can cause a variety of neurological symptoms, including ataxia and seizures, it is not typically associated with MELAS syndrome. Therefore, option C is incorrect in the context of this question.

Option D

  • Option D (m.13513G>A) is associated with the LHON (Leber's Hereditary Optic Neuropathy) syndrome, a disorder that primarily affects the eyes and vision. This mutation affects genes that are involved in energy production in the mitochondria, leading to a loss of retinal ganglion cells and optic nerve atrophy, which can result in vision loss. While this mutation can cause neurological symptoms, it is not typically associated with MELAS syndrome, so option D is incorrect in the context of this question.

questions.text: Which vitamin is essential for the proper functioning of the nervous system and is commonly used in the treatment of pernicious anemia?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option C

  • Vitamin B12, also known as cobalamin, is a water-soluble vitamin that is essential for the proper functioning of the nervous system. It plays a crucial role in the synthesis of myelin, which is the protective coating around nerves that allows them to transmit signals efficiently. Deficiency of vitamin B12 can lead to pernicious anemia, which is characterized by symptoms such as weakness, fatigue, and neurological symptoms such as numbness, tingling, and difficulty with balance and coordination. Therefore, in clinical practice, vitamin B12 is often used to treat pernicious anemia and other conditions that affect the nervous system.

Why Others are incorrect:

  • (a) Vitamin C plays an important role in the body as an antioxidant and supports immune function. Still, it is not involved in the functioning of the nervous system or the production of red blood cells. Vitamin C is found in many fruits and vegetables, whereas Vitamin B12/Cobalamin is only found in animal-based foods or supplements. 
  • (b) Vitamin D is essential for bone health and calcium absorption. It is not involved in the functioning of the nervous system or the production of red blood cells. Vitamin D is mainly synthesized in the skin through exposure to sunlight, and it is also found in a few food sources such as fatty fish, egg yolks, and fortified dairy products.
  • (d) Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting and bone health. It is found in leafy green vegetables, such as kale, spinach, and broccoli, as well as in some animal-based foods, such as liver and egg yolks.

questions.text: Which of the following is a radiological feature commonly associated with scurvy?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option D

  • Scurvy is a condition caused by a deficiency of vitamin C, which is an essential nutrient for collagen synthesis. Along with the clinical symptoms of fatigue, weakness, and bleeding gums, scurvy can also cause various radiological features such as generalized osteopenia, periosteal reaction, hemarthrosis, Wimberger ring, and Pelkken spur on knee x-ray. Therefore, in a clinical scenario of knee pain with radiological features, scurvy should be considered as a potential underlying cause.

Why Others are incorrect:

  • Option A, sclerotic bone lesions, is not a radiological feature commonly associated with scurvy. Scurvy is caused by a deficiency of vitamin C, which is an essential nutrient for collagen synthesis. Without adequate vitamin C, the collagen matrix of bones and other tissues becomes defective, leading to various radiological features such as generalized osteopenia, periosteal reaction, and Wimberger ring. However, sclerotic bone lesions are not commonly seen in scurvy, and their presence would suggest a different underlying condition, such as osteopetrosis or Paget's disease of bone.
  • Option B, erosions of the joint, is not a radiological feature commonly associated with scurvy. Scurvy is caused by a deficiency of vitamin C, which is an essential nutrient for collagen synthesis. Without adequate vitamin C, the collagen matrix of bones and other tissues becomes defective, leading to various radiological features such as generalized osteopenia, periosteal reaction, and Wimberger ring. However, joint erosions are not typically seen in scurvy, and their presence would suggest a different underlying condition, such as rheumatoid arthritis or osteoarthritis.
  • Option C, increased bone density, is not a radiological feature commonly associated with scurvy. Scurvy is caused by a deficiency of vitamin C, which is an essential nutrient for collagen synthesis. Without adequate vitamin C, the collagen matrix of bones and other tissues becomes defective, leading to various radiological features such as generalized osteopenia, where there is a decrease in bone density. Therefore, increased bone density is not a typical finding in scurvy and would suggest a different underlying condition, such as osteopetrosis or hyperparathyroidism.

Option A: A-alpha

questions.text: Which among the following ions is responsible for the major currents of depolarization in Purkinje fibers of the heart?
questions.solution:
Option A: Na+

  • The above given is a case of aberrant conduction.
  • Purkinje fibre is a fast-response type or rapidly depolarising fibre.
  • The rapid depolarisation is due to a rapid influx of Na+ through the fast Na+ channels.
  • The major current for depolarisation in pacemaker cells is due to Ca++.
  • The action potential of the Purkinje fibres depends on four times voltage-dependent membrane currents: INa+ (not present in the SA and AV nodal cells), ICa++, IK, and If.
  • The maximum diastolic potential is −80 mV.
  • From that negative Vm, these cells produce very slow pacemaker depolarisation (phase 4) that depends on If.

Option B: Ca++

  • The major current for depolarisation in pacemaker cells is due to Ca++

Option C: K+

  • Na+ is the major current for depolarisation in Purkinje fibres due to the inward flow of Na+.
  • K+ channels are almost entirely closed.
  • K+ ions move out of the nerve membrane during repolarisation.

Option D: Cl–

  • Cl- increases the negative potential inside the cell, which cause the repolarisation of the cell.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to your clinic for consultation. The main concern is bleeding gums. The mother states several episodes of excessive bleeding previously from minor injuries. You find out that the maternal grandfather has a clotting disorder. Physical examination of the child reveals slight tenderness over the knee with fluid accumulation in the knee joint. Which of the following coagulation factors is likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Factor VIII:

  • A young man with a bleeding disorder and a history of bleeding disorders in the males of his family would lead one to suspect hemophilia A, a deficiency of factor VIII (because it is an X-linked disorder)
  • The physical examination suggests bleeding into the knee joint (hemarthrosis), frequently seen in hemophilia A.
  • Hemophilia A or Classic hemophilia is caused by factor VIII deficiency.
  • About 15% of cases of hemophilia are caused by deficiency of factor IX (Christmas factor)- Hemophilia B or Christmas disease.

Option A: Prothrombin activator

  • A young man with a bleeding disorder and a history of bleeding disorders in the males of his family would lead one to suspect hemophilia A, a deficiency of factor VIII (because it is an X-linked disorder)

Option B: Factor II

  • A young man with a bleeding disorder and a history of bleeding disorders in the males of his family would lead one to suspect hemophilia A, a deficiency of factor VIII (because it is an X-linked disorder)

Option D: Factor X

  • Vitamin K is an essential factor in liver carboxylase that adds a carboxyl group to glutamic acid residues on five of the important clotting factors: prothrombin, Factor VII, Factor IX, Factor X, and protein C.
  • Occurs in healthy persons as a result of the absence of vitamin K from the diet (except in neonates before they establish their intestinal bacterial flora). However, in persons with gastrointestinal disease, vitamin K deficiency often occurs as a result of poor absorption of fats from the gastrointestinal tract because vitamin K is fat-soluble and is ordinarily absorbed into the blood along with the fats. One of the most prevalent causes of vitamin K deficiency is the failure of the liver to secrete bile into the gastrointestinal tract (which occurs either as a result of obstruction of the bile ducts or as a result of liver disease). so it will depress the clotting system
  • There is no genetic transfer from parents to off springs

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be associated with prolonged bleeding time with normal PT and aPTT levels?
questions.solution:
Option C: Thrombocytopenia

  • BT (Bleeding time): After a small cut is used to test for several clotting factors but is especially prolonged by a lack of platelets (Thrombocytopenia).

Thrombocytopenia:

  • Thrombocytopenia means very low platelet count (i.e., platelet count <150,000/microL [150 x 109/L]) and may be associated with a variety of conditions, with associated risks that range from life-threatening to none.
  • Spontaneous bleeding occurs with counts <10,000/microL, and surgical bleeding with counts <50,000/microL.
  • The skin of such a person displays many small, purplish blotches, giving the disease the name thrombocytopenic purpura
  •  Rarely is thrombocytopenia associated with a risk of thrombosis rather than, or in addition to, bleeding.
  • Clinical manifestation of thrombocytopenia
    • Petechial hemorrhages
    • Easy bruising,
    • Mucosal bleeding such as menorrhagia in women, nasal bleeding, bleeding from gums, melaena, and haematuria. Intracranial hemorrhage is, however, rare.
  • Laboratory investigation-
    • Bleeding time is prolonged.
    • PT and aPTT are normal.
    • Bone marrow shows an increased number of megakaryocytes which have large non-lobulated single nuclei and may have reduced cytoplasmic granularity and the presence of vacuoles
    • Platelet survival studies reveal markedly reduced platelet lifespan, sometimes less than one hour, as compared with the normal lifespan of 7-10 days.

Bleeding time:

  • Bleeding time is a clinical laboratory test performed to evaluate platelet function.
  • It involves the creation of a standardized incision and timing the cessation of bleeding.
  • The historical indications were the pre-operative assessment of patients taking aspirin or NSAIDs and screening for von-Willebrand disease.
  • Unfortunately, it is insensitive and lacks reproducibility.
  • Platelet function assay (i.e., PFA 100) has largely replaced bleeding time.
  • Despite the standardization of methods, the sensitivity and specificity of the bleeding time for platelet-mediated coagulopathy are low.
  • Many hospitals and health systems have removed the test without any demonstrated harm.
  • In most cases, a thorough history and physical is the only workup needed for the pre-operative assessment of bleeding risk.
  • When the clinical effectiveness of platelet aggregation is desired, a modern platelet function assay can provide the necessary information.
  • This is being increasingly utilized in intracranial hemorrhage on various antiplatelet agents before pooled platelet transfusion.

Option A: Hemophilia A

  • Classic haemophilia or haemophilia A is the most common hereditary coagulation disorder occurring due to deficiency or reduced activity of factor VIII (anti-haemophilic factor). The disorder is inherited as a sex-(X-) linked recessive trait and, therefore, manifests clinically in males, while females are usually the carriers.
  • haemophilia A (classic haemophilia) is an inherited deficiency of factor VIII due to a mutation in the F8 gene
  • Clinical features-
    • Patients of haemophilia suffer from bleeding for hours or days after the injury. The clinical severity of the disease correlates well with the plasma level of factor VIII activity. Haemophilic bleeding can involve any organ but occurs most commonly as recurrent painful haemarthroses and muscle hematomas, and sometimes as haematuria. Spontaneous intracranial haemorrhage and oropharyngeal bleeding are rare, but when they occur they are the most feared complications.
  • Laboratory investigation-
    • Whole blood coagulation time is prolonged in severe cases only.
    • Prothrombin time is usually normal.
    • Platelet count is usually normal.
    • Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT or PTTK) is typically prolonged.
    • Specific assay for factor VIII shows lowered activity.
    • The diagnosis of female carriers is made by the findings of about half the activity of factor VIII, while the manifest disease is associated with factor VIII activity below 25%.

Option B: Hemophilia B

  • Inherited deficiency of factor IX (Christmas factor or plasma thromboplastin component) produces Christmas disease or haemophilia B. Haemophilia B is rarer than haemophilia A constituting about 20% of cases; its estimated incidence is 1 in 100,000 male births.
  • Laboratory investigation-
    • Whole blood coagulation time is prolonged in severe cases only.
    • Platelet count is usually normal.
    • Prothrombin time is usually normal.
    • Activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT or PTTK) is typically prolonged.

Option D: Coumadin use

This is false because:

  • PT (Prothrombin Time): Is used to test the extrinsic pathway (Coumadin/Warfarin use).

questions.text: A professor explains nephron physiology and the process of secretion and reabsorption. Tubular reabsorption is the process that moves solutes and water out of the filtrate and back into your bloodstream. This process is known as reabsorption because this is the second time they have been absorbed, the first time being when they were absorbed into the bloodstream from the digestive tract after a meal. Maximum absorption of HCO3- occurs in?

choices.text: Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.solution:
PCT

  • 80% of bicarbonate reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule.

DCT

  • All the filtered HCO3– in the renal tubules are reabsorbed. About 80% of it is reabsorbed in proximal convoluted tubule, 15% in Henle loop and 5% in distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct.

Collecting duct

  • 5% in distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct.

Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

  • 15% of bicarbonate reabsorption occurs in the thick ascending limb of LOH.

Learning Objective

Bicarbonate Mechanism

  • All the filtered HCO3– in the renal tubules is reabsorbed. About 80% of it is reabsorbed in proximal convoluted tubule, 15% in Henle loop and 5% in distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct. The reabsorption of HCO3– utilizes the H+ secreted into the renal tubules.
  • H+ secreted into the renal tubule, combines with filtered HCO3– forming carbonic acid (H2 CO3 ). Carbonic acid dissociates into carbon dioxide and water in the presence of carbonic anhydrase. Carbon dioxide and water enter the tubular cell.
  • In the tubular cells, carbon dioxide combines with water to form carbonic acid. It immediately dissociates into H+ and HCO3– . HCO3– from the tubular cell enters the interstitium. Simultaneously Na+ is reabsorbed from the renal tubule under the influence of aldosterone. HCO3– combines with Na+ to form sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3). Now, the H+ is secreted into the tubular lumen from the cell in exchange for Na+.
  • Thus, for every hydrogen ion secreted into lumen of tubule, one bicarbonate ion is reabsorbed from the tubule. In this way, kidneys conserve the HCO3–. The reabsorption of filtered HCO3– is an important factor in maintaining pH of the body fluids.
  • Filtered bicarbonate can be reabsorbed only when it combines with H+.

questions.text: A patient’s renal plasma flow (RPF) is estimated through Para Amino Hippuric acid (PAH) clearance measurement. The technician observes the procedures correctly but inadvertently uses the recommended dose of PAH thrice due to an error in the weighing. The RPF estimated is likely to be?

choices.text: False-high or false-low depending on the GFR
Correct and is unaffected by the PAH overdose

questions.solution:
Option B: False-low

  • The secretion shows a Tm value. Tm of PAH = 80 mg/min. At low PAH concentrations, the PAH will be completely secreted and thus removed from the plasma.
  • The Tm value is reached at high plasma PAH (> 30 mg/dl).
  •  The secretory process is saturated; now, urinary concentration cannot increase further, but plasma concentration will increase as it cannot be removed from the plasma by secretion.
  • Considering this into the clearance equation of PAH, if the technician gave a high dose of PAH, the denominator (plasma PAH) would be high.
  • Hence, the clearance value will be low. Thus, a falsely low value of RPF will be obtained.

Option A: False-high

  • In the clearance equation, the plasma concentration of PAH is in the denominator. Hence, increasing that value would decrease the clearance of PAH, and the RPF will be falsely low.

Option C: False-high or false-low depending on the GFR

  • The renal plasma flow value depends on the clearance of the PAH, not the GFR

Option D: Correct and is unaffected by the PAH overdose

  • In the clearance equation, the plasma concentration of PAH is in the denominator. Hence, increasing that value would decrease the clearance of PAH, and the RPF will be falsely low.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the respiratory centre in the brain stem. He observes that central and peripheral chemoreceptors and baroreceptors play a vital role in controlling respiration. Concerning the peripheral chemoreceptors, the true statement is?

choices.text: They respond to changes in the arterial PO2 but not pH
Under normoxic conditions, the response to changes in PO2 is very small
The response to changes in PCO2 is slower than for central chemoreceptors
They are the most important receptors causing increased ventilation in response to a rise in PCO2.

questions.solution:
Option B: Under normoxic conditions, the response to changes in PO2 is very small

  • Peripheral chemoreceptors respond to arterial PO2, but the response is poor during normoxia.
  • Oxygen has a minimal effect on the respiratory drive unless the arterial partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) drops below 60 mm Hg.
  • CO2 is the major stimulator of respiration under normal circumstances.
  • Central chemoreceptors respond to changes in PCO2.

Option A: They respond to changes in the arterial PO2 but not pH

  • Peripheral chemoreceptors respond to the changes in pH

Option C: The response to changes in PCO2 is slower than for central chemoreceptors

  • Peripheral chemoreceptors respond faster to changes in PCO2 than central chemoreceptors.

Option D: They are the most important receptors causing increased ventilation in response to a rise in PCO2

  • Central chemoreceptors are more important and cause increased ventilation in response to a rise in PCO2.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary mechanism of acidification in the stomach?

choices.text: Active transport of H+ ions into the stomach lumen
Diffusion of H+ ions into the stomach lumen
Secretion of bicarbonate ions into the stomach lumen
Binding of H+ ions to Cl- ions in the stomach lumen

questions.solution:
Option B

  • The primary mechanism of acidification in the stomach is the diffusion of H+ ions into the stomach lumen. These H+ ions are secreted by the parietal cells in the stomach and diffuse into the lumen, where they combine with Cl- ions to form HCl, the main component of gastric acid

Why other choices are wrong

Option A) is incorrect because while active transport of H+ ions into the stomach lumen does occur, it is not the primary mechanism of acidification.

Option C) is incorrect because the secretion of bicarbonate ions into the stomach lumen actually helps to neutralize the acid in the stomach, rather than contributing to acidification.

Option D) is incorrect because while H+ ions do bind to Cl- ions to form HCl, this is not the primary mechanism of acidification.

questions.text: Mr. J, a 50-year-old male, is brought to the emergency department with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) due to uncontrolled type 1 diabetes. His blood gas analysis reveals a pH of 7.20, bicarbonate (HCO3-) level of 10 mEq/L, and pCO2 level of 30 mmHg. Which buffer system is likely to be compensating for his acid-base imbalance?
questions.solution:
Option A

  • In DKA, there is an increased production of acidic ketones, leading to metabolic acidosis. The phosphate buffer system plays a crucial role in intracellular and urinary pH regulation, and in this case, it helps to compensate for the metabolic acidosis by releasing phosphate ions (HPO4-) into the blood, which binds to excess hydrogen ions (H+) to form phosphoric acid (H2PO4-), thereby buffering the excess acids and helping to restore the acid-base balance.

Why other options are incorrect

Option B) is incorrect because the hemoglobin buffer system operates primarily within red blood cells and is not the primary buffer system in the extracellular fluid, which is where DKA-related acidosis occurs.

Option C) is incorrect because while the bicarbonate-carbonic acid buffer system is the primary buffer system in the extracellular fluid, it is not the primary mechanism for compensation in DKA-related acidosis. Instead, the kidneys play a major role in compensating for metabolic acidosis by increasing the excretion of hydrogen ions and increasing the reabsorption of filtered bicarbonate ions.

Option D) is incorrect because the ammonia buffer system primarily operates in the renal tubules and is not the primary buffer system in the extracellular fluid, which is where DKA-related acidosis occurs.

questions.text: A patient who underwent a gastrectomy complains of feeling full after eating small meals, and also has episodes of vomiting. Upon examination, the patient's gastric pH is found to be elevated. Which of the following best explains these symptoms?

choices.text: Loss of the stomach's reservoir function

questions.solution:
Option D

  • After gastrectomy, there is a loss of the stomach's reservoir function, leading to rapid emptying of food into the small intestine, causing early satiety and vomiting. The stomach also secretes acid to help break down food, but since there is less stomach present, the pH is often elevated. 

Why other options are incorrect 

Option A) Increased gastrin secretion may lead to excessive acid secretion but does not explain the patient's symptoms. 

Option B) Decreased somatostatin secretion would actually lead to increased acid secretion and exacerbate the symptoms.

Option C) Reduced gastric mucosal blood flow may cause gastritis, but it is not the primary cause of the patient's symptoms.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with complaints of easy bruising and prolonged bleeding from minor cuts. Laboratory tests reveal prolonged clotting times and decreased levels of Factor VIII. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A

  • Hemophilia A is a genetic disorder that affects the clotting factor VIII, leading to prolonged clotting times and increased risk of bleeding. It is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern and predominantly affects males. Symptoms include easy bruising, prolonged bleeding from minor cuts, joint pain and swelling, and spontaneous bleeding into joints, muscles, or organs. Treatment includes replacement therapy with factor VIII concentrates.

Why other options are incorrect

Option B: Von Willebrand Disease is also a genetic bleeding disorder, but it affects the von Willebrand factor, which is necessary for platelet function and clotting factor VIII stabilization. It can present with similar symptoms to hemophilia A, but usually has less severe bleeding episodes. However, laboratory tests in this case indicate decreased levels of Factor VIII, making hemophilia A a more likely diagnosis.

Option C: Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) is a condition characterized by widespread activation of the clotting cascade, leading to excessive clotting and bleeding. It can occur in response to a variety of underlying conditions such as infection, trauma, or cancer. However, in this case, the laboratory tests suggest a deficiency in a specific clotting factor, making DIC less likely.

Option D: Vitamin K Deficiency can lead to impaired clotting factor synthesis, leading to increased bleeding times. However, this condition usually presents with other symptoms such as bruising, bleeding gums, and petechiae, which are not mentioned in the case. Additionally, vitamin K deficiency is typically associated with liver disease, malnutrition, or antibiotic use, which are not mentioned as risk factors in this case.

questions.text: A patient presents with excessive bleeding after sustaining a minor injury. The doctor suspects a coagulation disorder and orders coagulation studies. The results show a prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), but a normal prothrombin time (PT) and platelet count. Which of the following coagulation pathways is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A

  • The aPTT primarily assesses the intrinsic pathway of coagulation, which is activated by contact with negatively charged surfaces such as collagen or glass. The extrinsic pathway, on the other hand, is activated by tissue factor released from damaged cells. The common pathway is the final pathway of coagulation, in which fibrin is formed from fibrinogen. The fibrinolytic pathway is responsible for breaking down clots.

Why other options are incorrect

Option B) Extrinsic pathways can be ruled out as the PT is normal, indicating that this pathway is functioning properly. 

Option C) Common pathway is less likely as it would affect both the aPTT and PT, but only the aPTT is prolonged in this case. 

Option D) Fibrinolytic pathway is not indicated as the patient is presenting with bleeding, not clotting. Prolonged aPTT is typically seen in disorders affecting the intrinsic pathway such as hemophilia A and B, von Willebrand disease, or lupus anticoagulant.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with a history of recreational oxycodone use presents with irritability, nausea, and diarrhea, 48 hours after her last dose. Physical examination reveals mydriasis, rhinorrhea, and piloerection. Why does a drug similar to oxycodone, but without euphoria, provide different effects?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lower efficacy

  • Drug efficacy (correlates with Emax) is the maximum degree to which a drug activates receptors after binding and triggers a cellular response.
  • On an efficacy graph, the difference in efficacy of the two drugs is determined by the difference in the maximal effect exerted by each of them (shown on the y-axis); drugs with different efficacy will have different heights, with the difference in efficacy represented on the y-axis. 
  • Not related to potency (drugs with a high efficacy can have a low potency).
  • Partial agonists are less efficacious than full agonists.
  • A drug that acts as a partial agonist acts at the same site as a full agonist but has lower efficacy.
  • Administration of a partial opioid μ-receptor agonist like buprenorphine, which has lower efficacy than a full opioid μ-receptor agonist (e.g., morphine), can help alleviate the unpleasant side effects of opioid withdrawal without causing euphoria.

Option A: Lower bioavailability

  • Bioavailability is the ratio of a given drug reaching systemic circulation.
  • Regarding oral drugs, bioavailability depends on the first-pass effect (in the liver) and individual absorption rates. Intravenously administered drugs have a bioavailability of 1.
  • Orally administered drugs are not fully absorbed from the GI tract and undergo first-pass metabolism, which results in lower bioavailability than medications administered intravenously.
  • However, lower bioavailability would not explain why a partial opioid μ-receptor agonist like buprenorphine does not produce the same euphoric effect as a full opioid μ-receptor agonist.

  • The blue line shows the concentration of a substance administered intravenously (IV) over time, and the red line shows the concentration of a substance taken orally.
  • The ratio of the area under the curve (AUC) of the orally administered substance to the AUC of the IV substance yields a substance's bioavailability (F).

Option B: Lower potency

Potency (EC50):

  • The potency of a drug is measured as the concentration required to produce a pharmacological response of a specified intensity. 
  • Not related to efficacy (drugs with a high potency can have a low efficacy) but dependent on affinity.
  • EC50 = the effective concentration required to produce 50% of the maximum possible response (Emax).
  • A left shift of the curve is a sign of decreased EC50 and increased potency, meaning a lower concentration of the drug is needed.
  • EC50 is not to be confused with ED50; ED50 is the median effective dose that produces a desired beneficial effect in 50% of the population.
  • ED50 = 5 mg implies that the administration of 5 mg of the drug achieves the desired effect in 50% of the studied population

  • The same drug may have different ED50 values based on the indication (e.g., aspirin has different ED50 values for headache and for thromboembolism prophylaxis).

Option D: Lower affinity

Drug affinity:

  • Drug affinity is a measure of the tendency of a drug to bind to its receptor.
  • Most drug-receptor bonds are reversible.
  • Covalent drug-receptor bonds, which are less common, are almost always irreversible (e.g., the binding of aspirin to cyclooxygenase enzyme)
  • Affinity describes how well a drug is capable of binding to its receptor. A drug with low affinity for its receptor would require a higher dose to exert the same effect as a pharmacodynamically similar, high-affinity drug.
  • Lower affinity would not explain why a partial opioid μ-receptor agonist like buprenorphine does not produce the same euphoria as a full opioid μ-receptor agonist. Buprenorphine has an extremely high receptor affinity (higher than morphine), which causes it to displace other opioids.

questions.text: An investigator is studying the effects of different drugs on the contraction of cardiomyocytes. The myocytes can achieve maximal contractility with the administration of drug A. The administration of drug B produces the response depicted in the graph shown. Which of the following options best describes drug B?
questions.solution:
Option C: Partial agonist

  • A substance with some agonistic action at a receptor does not elicit a true agonist's complete response.
  • Act at the same site as the full agonist

  • A partial agonist can compete with and displace a true agonist from a receptor and thus act as an antagonist in certain situations; e.g., tolazoline, which is used to treat painful peripheral vasospasm, is a partial agonist at α1 receptors (α1 agonists cause peripheral vasoconstriction).

Option A: Competitive antagonist

  • Antagonist: a drug that binds to a receptor and prevents its activation.
  • Competitive antagonist
    • The agonist and the antagonist compete to bind to the same receptor.
    • Inhibition of the effect of the agonist in a dose-dependent fashion; thus, a higher concentration of the agonist is needed to achieve the same efficacy (e.g., there is a decrease in potency) 
      • Reversible competitive antagonists
      • Irreversible competitive antagonists 
  •  The inhibitory effect can be overcome by increasing agonist concentration.

Option B: Non-competitive antagonist

  • The drug binds at a site other than the agonist-binding site, changes the structure of the agonist-binding site, and decreases the affinity of the agonist. 
  • As a result, the efficacy of the agonist is decreased and increasing the agonist concentration does not achieve the same efficacy.
Agonist with Potency Efficacy Remarks Example
Competitive antagonist Decreased No change Can be overcome by increasing agonist concentration Diazepam (agonist) + flumazenil (competitive antagonist) on GABA receptor.
Non-competitive antagonist No change Deceased Cannot be overcome by increasing agonist concentration Norepinephrine (agonist) + phenoxybenzamine (noncompetitive antagonist) on α-receptors.
Partial agonist (alone) Independent Decreased Acts at the same site as a full agonist Morphine (full agonist) vs buprenorphine (partial agonist) at opioid μ-receptors.

 

Affinity Affinity Intrinsic Activity
Agonist High High
Partial agonist High Low
Inverse agonist High Negative
Antagonist High No

Option D: Inverse agonist

  • An inverse agonist binds to the same receptor as an agonist but not to the same active site. It elicits a response that is opposite to the agonistic response and has a negative efficacy.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the urology department with complaints of increased frequency of urination, especially at night, apart from the sensation of residual urine even after urinating for 15 days. The doctor ordered a few tests, which turned out to be normal. The doctor diagnoses benign prostatic hyperplasia and prescribes a drug that acts on alpha 1 receptors of the smooth muscle cells of the prostate, leading to apoptosis. Which of the following drug acts by this mechanism?
questions.solution:
Option A: Terazosin

  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia is a condition in which the prostate gland is enlarged. It is not cancerous and mostly present in older patients.
  • The prostate surrounds the urethra, which causes a blockage, difficulty while urinating, urinary urgency, and urinary incontinence.
  • Terazosin is a selective competitive blocker of the alpha-1 receptor. It is indicated for the treatment of BPH.
  • The smooth muscles of the bladder neck and prostatic urethra are constricted by sympathetic innervation via alpha1 adrenergic receptors. Terazosin being alpha1 receptor blocker reduces the dynamic component of urinary obstruction in benign hypertrophy of prostate, improves urinary flow and affords symptomatic relief.
  • The alpha1 adrenergic receptors also mediate reflex vasoconstriction in the lower extremity and trunk which occurs on standing up from a reclining position to maintain cerebral blood flow
  • Terazosin induces apoptosis in prostate smooth muscle cells in BPH. They tend to reduce tumour vascularity.

Option B: Tamsulosin

  • Tamsulosin is non-quinazoline 1 receptor antagonist. It is also used in the treatment of BPH.
  • Tamsulosin relaxes the muscle in the prostate and bladder, helping the urine to flow out easily. But it does not produce apoptosis.

Option C: Pseudoephedrine

  • It is a sympathomimetic drug that is used to relieve nasal congestion.
  • Pseudoephedrine is contraindicated in BPH as it tightens the muscles of the bladder and prostate. It worsens the condition and does not cause apoptosis.

Option D: Diphenhydramine

  • It is an antihistamine drug that is mainly used in the treatment of allergies.
  • Diphenhydramine should not be taken in case of BPH as it can cause urinary retention and is not helpful in apoptosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the enzyme cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2)?

choices.text: It is not inhibited by indomethacin
It generates cytoprotective prostaglandins in gastric mucosa
It is found only in fetal tissues

questions.solution:
Option B: It is inducible

  • Cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) enzyme is an inducible enzyme
  • COX-1 is a housekeeping enzyme responsible for the generation of gastroprotective prostaglandins.
  • COX-2 is normally present in insignificant amounts in tissues and is an inducible enzyme. Its production is markedly increased at inflammatory sites under the stimulation of cytokines, growth factors and other stimuli during an inflammatory response.
  • The eicosanoids produced by COX-2 lead to inflammatory reactions; however, some are produced in the kidney, brain and fetus, where they play physiological roles.
  • It is inhibited by COX inhibitors, e.g. aspirin, ibuprofen and indomethacin etc.

Option A: It is not inhibited by indomethacin

  • Indomethacin is a nonselective reversible inhibitor of both isoforms of COX, i.e. COX-1 and COX-2. Therefore, it is capable of inhibiting COX-2 effectively.

Option C: It generates cytoprotective prostaglandins in gastric mucosa

  • The COX-1 enzyme induces the synthesis of prostaglandins PGE2 and PGI2. These are involved in the production of mucus and bicarbonate ion secretion, which helps to promote gastric mucosal protection.

Option D: It is found only in fetal tissues

  • The COX-2 enzyme is normally present in insignificant amounts and in the kidney, brain, and fetal tissue, where it plays physiological roles.
  • It is inducible by cytokines, growth factors and other stimuli during the inflammatory response. The eicosanoids produced by COX-2 lead to inflammatory and other pathological changes.

questions.text: In nephrology class, the professor asks a question about the uses of vasopressin, and a brilliant student answers the question by explaining its use. The professor continues by asking specific indications of vasopressin with respect to the receptors it acts upon. Which of the following indications of vasopressin is based on stimulation of V1 receptors?
questions.solution:
Option D: Esophageal varices

  • Terlipressin is an analogue of vasopressin that selectively causes splanchnic and extra-renal vasoconstriction by stimulation of V1 receptors, which are predominantly located in the smooth muscle of the arterial vasculature in the splanchnic region and thereby reduces splanchnic blood flow and portal pressure.  

  • Mechanism of Action: Terlipressin acts as a potent vasoconstrictor by binding to V1 receptors in the vascular smooth muscle, resulting in vasoconstriction and increased systemic vascular resistance. This helps to reduce bleeding from esophageal varices.

  • Hemostatic Effect: Terlipressin helps to control bleeding by reducing portal pressure, which in turn decreases blood flow to the varices. This vasoconstrictive effect helps to achieve hemostasis and prevent further bleeding.

  • Administration: Terlipressin is typically administered intravenously. The initial dose is usually higher, followed by a maintenance dose, and then the dose may be titrated based on the patient's response and hemodynamic stability.

  • Combination Therapy: Terlipressin is often used in combination with endoscopic therapy, such as endoscopic variceal ligation (EVL) or sclerotherapy, for optimal management of esophageal variceal bleeding.

  • Side Effects: Common side effects of terlipressin include abdominal cramps, headache, and nausea. In rare cases, it can cause ischemic complications such as myocardial infarction or mesenteric ischemia.

Option A: Central diabetes insipidus

  • The V2 receptor is predominantly expressed on the distal convoluted tubule and collecting ducts of the kidney.
  • The binding of vasopressin to renal V2 receptors stimulates the recruitment of selective water channels (aquaporins), which allow the reabsorption of renal tubular water and concentration of urine.

Option B: Bedwetting in children

  • The binding of vasopressin to renal V2 receptors stimulates the recruitment of selective water channels (aquaporins), which allow the reabsorption of renal tubular water and concentration of urine.
  • This effect of vasopressin is used for nocturnal enuresis.

Option C: Von-Willebrand’s disease

  • Extra-renal effects of vasopressin by V2 activation include factor VIII release from hepatocytes and release of von Willebrand factor from endothelium.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the hospital for a diagnostic evaluation of the recent onset of chest pain 2 hours back. Three days before admission, he woke up in the middle of the night with a tight precordial pain of solid intensity, lasting for 20 minutes, radiating to the upper left limb and accompanied by dyspnea. The ECG at rest shows a sinus rhythm, a heart rate of 83 bpm, a PR interval of 170 ms, QRS duration of 100 ms, QT of 370 ms, left atrial enlargement, an ST segment flat in leads II, III and aVF and also elevated from V1 to V3 (increased convexity in V1 and increased concavity in V2 and V3), and positive and symmetrical T waves in leads V5 and V6. The doctor prescribes him drugs for the condition mentioned above. Which of the following could be the drugs prescribed?
questions.solution:
Option C: Organic nitrates

  • Signs and symptoms of chest pain, precordia pain, flattening of ST segment and symmetrical waves show that it's angina pectoris.
  • Nitrates act by increasing cGMP, and sildenafil inhibits the breakdown of this compound (by inhibiting phosphodiesterase).
  • Marked increases in cGMP levels may result in profound hypotension and reflex tachycardia.
  • The effects of organic nitrates (nitroglycerin, isosorbide dinitrate, and isosorbide mononitrate) take time to manifest because mitochondrial aldehyde reductase must first be activated.
  • The liver engages in considerable first-pass metabolism of oral nitrates

 

Option A: Calcium channel blockers

  • Calcium channel antagonists or calcium antagonists prevent calcium from passing through calcium channels.
  • Calcium channel blockers are prescribed to patients with hypertension as antihypertensive medicines, which lower blood pressure.

Option B: β adrenergic blockers

  • The class of drugs known as beta-blockers, often written as blockers is primarily used to treat irregular heartbeats and to prevent the heart from suffering a second heart attack after the first one.

Option D: Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors

  • A class of drugs known as angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitors is primarily used to treat heart failure and excessive blood pressure.
  • They function by forcing blood vessels to relax and blood volume to drop, which lowers blood pressure and reduces the heart's need for oxygen.

questions.text: A 63-year-old patient with hypertension and diabetes, previously on thiazide diuretics for five years, now presents with increased systolic blood pressure. Beta-blockers were prescribed, leading to normalized blood pressure but complaints of fatigue, sleep disturbance, and weakness. Which statement about beta-blockers is accurate?

choices.text: Nebivolol is a non-cardioselective beta blocker
Cardio-selective beta blockers are not safe for asthma
Beta-blockers are the drug of choice in acute CHF
Atenolol is contraindicated in renal failure

questions.solution:
Option D: Atenolol is contraindicated in renal failure

  • Beta-blockers such as atenolol, nadolol and sotalol have low lipid solubility and are not metabolized in chronic kidney disease; hence, their dose must be reduced in renal failure.
  • Theoretically, beta-blockers may reduce cardiac output and decrease renal perfusion pressure, thereby exacerbating renal dysfunction.
  • The sympathetic nervous system (SNS) is also activated in chronic kidney disease, and it is preferred to use lower doses and careful monitoring in chronic kidney disease patients to avoid side effects related to drug accumulation, which is a known factor in the progression of renal disease.

Option A: Nebivolol is a non-cardioselective beta blocker

  • Nebivolol is a cardioselective beta blocker drug that is used for the treatment of hypertension and angina.
  • It has vasodilatory effects, lacks sympathomimetic activity, and possesses a tolerability profile similar to other beta blockers.

Option B: Cardio-selective beta blockers are not safe for asthma

  • Cardioselective beta-blockers are safe for asthma.
  • Cardio-selective drugs act on the beta-1 receptors of the heart, on the other hand; there are beta-2 receptors in the lungs
  • So beta-1 selective drugs are comparatively safe in asthma.

Option C: Beta blockers are the drug of choice in acute CHF

  • Beta-blockers are contraindicated in congestive heart failure because of their negative inotropic activity.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with epilepsy and schizophrenia was admitted for difficulty walking, eye spasms, protruding tongue, extended neck, agitation, hand tremors, speech difficulties, and repetitive facial movements worsening over four weeks. She's been on carbamazepine and haloperidol for over a decade. Least likely to cause extrapyramidal symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option C: Carbamazepine

  • Carbamazepine is an anti-seizure medication used for monotherapy and adjunctive therapy in the treatment of patients with focal onset seizures and generalized onset seizures.
    • It is also used as monotherapy in the acute treatment of hypomania and mild to moderate mania or episodes with mixed features associated with bipolar disorder.
    • It is also used for the treatment of trigeminal or glossopharyngeal neuralgia.
  • In addition to anti-seizure effects, carbamazepine has anticholinergic, antineuralgic, antidiuretic, muscle relaxant, antimanic, anti-depressive, and antiarrhythmic properties; it may depress activity in the nucleus ventralis of the thalamus or decrease synaptic transmission or decrease summation of temporal stimulation leading to neural discharge by limiting the influx of sodium ions across the cell membrane, stimulates the release of ADH and potentiates its action in promoting the reabsorption of water; chemically related to tricyclic antidepressants.
    • Carbamazepine has no dopamine D2 antagonist activity, which is the basis for causing extrapyramidal symptoms; therefore, carbamazepine does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms.

Option A: Chlorpromazine

  • Being a first-generation antipsychotic and a dopamine D2 antagonist, chlorpromazine is more likely to produce extrapyramidal symptoms.

Option B: Fluphenazine

  • Being a first-generation antipsychotic and a dopamine D2 antagonist, fluphenazine is more likely to produce extrapyramidal symptoms.

Option D: Haloperidol

  • As a first-generation antipsychotic and a potent dopamine D2 antagonist, haloperidol is well-known for extrapyramidal side effects limiting its use in the clinical practice where better and safer alternatives are available.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with chronic gouty arthritis and is prescribed a purine inhibitor for long-term management. The patient has a history of severe liver disease, and the clinician must choose the appropriate medication. Which of the following is the most appropriate purine inhibitor for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option A

  • The most appropriate purine inhibitor for this patient with severe liver disease would be Febuxostat, as it is primarily eliminated through the kidneys, rather than the liver, and does not require dose adjustments in patients with hepatic impairment. Allopurinol, on the other hand, is primarily metabolized by the liver and may cause hepatotoxicity in patients with liver disease. Azathioprine and mycophenolate mofetil are not purine inhibitors, but rather immunosuppressant medications used in organ transplantation.

Why other options are incorrect:

B) Allopurinol is not the most appropriate choice for a patient with severe liver disease, as it is primarily metabolized by the liver and may cause hepatotoxicity in patients with liver disease.

C) Azathioprine is not a purine inhibitor but rather an immunosuppressive medication that is primarily used in organ transplantation.

D) Mycophenolate mofetil is not a purine inhibitor but rather an immunosuppressive medication that is primarily used in organ transplantation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of recurrent Streptococcus pneumoniae infections is brought to the hospital with a fever, cough, and shortness of breath. A sputum culture is obtained, and it shows growth of Streptococcus pneumoniae. The patient has previously received multiple courses of penicillin therapy, but the infection has not responded to treatment. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for this penicillin resistance?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option D

  • The most common mechanism of penicillin resistance in Streptococcus pneumoniae is the production of beta-lactamases, which are enzymes that hydrolyze the beta-lactam ring of penicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics. Increased expression of beta-lactamases confers high-level resistance to penicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics.

Why other options are incorrect:

A) Overexpression of PBPs is not a common mechanism of penicillin resistance in Streptococcus pneumoniae. PBPs are the target of beta-lactam antibiotics, and changes in PBPs can result in decreased binding of the antibiotic, leading to resistance. However, this mechanism is not commonly observed in S. pneumoniae.

B) Decreased expression of efflux pumps is not a mechanism of penicillin resistance in S. pneumoniae. Efflux pumps are membrane transporters that can pump out a variety of antibiotics, including fluoroquinolones, tetracyclines, and macrolides, but not beta-lactam antibiotics.

C) Reduced expression of beta-lactamases is not a common mechanism of penicillin resistance in S. pneumoniae. In fact, some strains of S. pneumoniae produce little or no beta-lactamases and are still resistant to penicillin due to other mechanisms such as alterations in PBPs.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female patient with rheumatoid arthritis presents to your clinic complaining of joint pain and stiffness. She has been treated with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) and corticosteroids in the past, but her symptoms have persisted. Her rheumatoid factor is positive, and imaging shows joint damage. After discussing the risks and benefits of various treatment options with the patient, you decide to prescribe a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD).

Which of the following statements about methotrexate is correct in this case?

choices.text: Methotrexate should be initiated at a high dose to achieve rapid control of symptoms
Methotrexate should be avoided in this patient due to the risk of liver toxicity.
Methotrexate should be administered with folic acid to reduce side effects
Methotrexate should be reserved as a last-line treatment due to the risk of bone marrow suppression

questions.solution:
Explanation: Option C

Folic acid supplementation is recommended when taking methotrexate to reduce the risk of side effects such as gastrointestinal symptoms, oral ulcers, and bone marrow suppression. 

Why other options are Incorrect:

A) Methotrexate is a commonly used DMARD in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It is usually initiated at a low dose and gradually increased to achieve a therapeutic effect. High doses can increase the risk of adverse effects such as liver toxicity, bone marrow suppression, and gastrointestinal symptoms.

B) Although methotrexate can cause liver toxicity, this risk can be minimized with monitoring and dose adjustments. Methotrexate is not contraindicated in this patient unless she has preexisting liver disease or elevated liver enzymes. 

D) Methotrexate is a first-line treatment for rheumatoid arthritis and should be considered early in the disease course to prevent joint damage. It should not be reserved as a last-line treatment option.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with a history of renal impairment is admitted to the hospital with a severe bacterial infection. Which of the following statements regarding the use of aminoglycosides in this patient is true?

choices.text: Aminoglycosides are safe to use in patients with renal impairment if the dosing is adjusted appropriately.
Aminoglycosides are contraindicated in patients with renal impairment due to the risk of nephrotoxicity
Aminoglycosides are the first-line treatment for bacterial infections in patients with renal impairment
Aminoglycosides should be used with caution in patients with renal impairment but can still be used at standard doses.

questions.solution:
Explanation: Option D

  • Aminoglycosides are known to be potentially nephrotoxic, especially when used at high doses or in patients with renal impairment. However, they can still be used in patients with renal impairment at standard doses with careful monitoring of kidney function. The dosing may need to be adjusted in some cases to avoid toxicity, but it is not necessary to avoid using aminoglycosides altogether.

Why the other choices are incorrect:

A) is incorrect because although aminoglycosides can be used in patients with renal impairment, dosing adjustment may be necessary to avoid toxicity.

B) is incorrect because aminoglycosides are not contraindicated in all patients with renal impairment, but caution and careful monitoring are needed to prevent toxicity.

C) is incorrect because aminoglycosides are not always the first-line treatment for bacterial infections, and other factors such as the type of infection and the susceptibility of the organism must be considered.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male is diagnosed with generalized anxiety disorder (GAD) characterized by excessive worry, restlessness, muscle tension, and difficulty concentrating. He has no history of allergies or adverse reactions to medications. The patient's medical history is unremarkable, and he is not currently taking any medications. Which of the following medications is the drug of choice for the initial treatment of generalized anxiety disorder?
questions.solution:
Explanation: The correct option is B) Sertraline.

In this case, the patient's symptoms are indicative of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD), a condition characterized by excessive and persistent worrying along with other related symptoms. The drug of choice for the initial treatment of GAD is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) or a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). Among the options provided, sertraline is an SSRI and is considered a first-line treatment for GAD. SSRIs help regulate serotonin levels in the brain, which can alleviate anxiety symptoms.

Option A) Alprazolam is a benzodiazepine that can provide rapid relief from anxiety symptoms. However, it is generally not recommended as a first-line treatment for GAD due to the risk of dependence, withdrawal, and potential side effects.

Option C) Methylphenidate is a stimulant commonly used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and would not be a suitable choice for GAD treatment.

Option D) Quetiapine is an atypical antipsychotic that may be used to augment treatment in severe cases of anxiety disorders, but it is not typically chosen as the initial drug of choice for GAD.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is the most effective for managing the symptoms of a 10-year-old boy with a history of attention deficit hyperkinetic disorder (ADHD) who is experiencing poor impulse control and disruptive behavior in school?
questions.solution:
Option D

  • ADHD is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity. Alpha-2 agonists such as guanfacine and clonidine are considered first-line medications for the management of ADHD symptoms, particularly those related to impulsivity and hyperactivity. These medications are thought to act by decreasing the release of norepinephrine and thus reducing overstimulation of the brain's prefrontal cortex, which is responsible for regulating attention and behavior.

Why other choices are incorrect:

  • Option A) SSRIs are not typically used for the treatment of ADHD, as they have limited effectiveness in managing the core symptoms of the disorder.
  • Option B) Dopamine agonists such as methylphenidate and amphetamines are also commonly used for the management of ADHD symptoms, but they may exacerbate behavioral problems such as impulsivity and aggression.
  • Option C) Benzodiazepines are not recommended for the treatment of ADHD, as they have a high potential for abuse and can cause sedation and cognitive impairment.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child is brought to a psychiatrist by his parents for evaluation of learning difficulties. On examination, the child has difficulty with reading, writing, and spelling. He often confuses similar-looking letters and reverses letters and numbers. Which of the following medications would be contraindicated in the treatment of this child?
questions.solution:
Option A

  • The child in the scenario is presenting with symptoms of dyslexia, a learning disorder that affects reading and spelling abilities. Methylphenidate, a stimulant medication commonly used in the treatment of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), is contraindicated in the treatment of dyslexia due to its potential to exacerbate learning difficulties and cause anxiety and agitation.

Why the other choices are incorrect:

  • Option B) Atomoxetine, a non-stimulant medication used in the treatment of ADHD, may be helpful in treating the child's symptoms of inattention and impulsivity, which can accompany dyslexia.
  • Option C) Clonidine, an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, is not typically used in the treatment of dyslexia. However, it may be helpful in managing co-occurring symptoms of anxiety or hyperactivity.
  • Option D) Modafinil, a wakefulness-promoting medication, is not indicated for the treatment of dyslexia. However, it may be useful in the treatment of excessive daytime sleepiness or fatigue in individuals with comorbid conditions such as narcolepsy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to her psychiatrist with complaints of low mood, loss of interest in activities, feelings of worthlessness, and recurrent thoughts of death. She has a history of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), which has been well-controlled with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) for the past 5 years. She denies any significant stressors or recent life changes. On a mental status examination, she appears tearful and her affect is flat. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's depression?

choices.text: Increase the dose of her current SSRI medication
Add an atypical antipsychotic to her current medication regimen
Switch to a different class of antidepressant medication

questions.solution:
Option C

  • The most appropriate treatment for this patient's depression is to switch to a different class of antidepressant medication. This is because the patient has been well-controlled on SSRI for her OCD, but it is not effective for her current depressive symptoms. Therefore, switching to a different class of antidepressant medication would be more effective in treating her current depressive symptoms.

Why other options are incorrect

  • Option A) Increase the dose of her current SSRI medication is incorrect because the patient's current medication regimen is not effective for her current depressive symptoms, so increasing the dose of the current SSRI medication may not improve her symptoms.
  • Option B) Add an atypical antipsychotic to her current medication regimen is incorrect because there is no evidence that adding an atypical antipsychotic to the patient's current medication regimen would be more effective in treating her depression. Atypical antipsychotics are primarily used as adjunctive treatment for psychotic disorders, bipolar disorder, or treatment-resistant depression.
  • Option D) Begin cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) for depression is incorrect because although CBT is an effective treatment for depression, it may not be sufficient as the sole treatment for this patient's depression. Additionally, switching to a different class of antidepressant medication would provide more immediate relief of symptoms.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man has been accused of rape by his 26-year-old female friend. The woman allegedly was lured by the man on a pretext of helping with an assignment but had later spiked her drink and raped her while she was unconscious. The team has taken swabs of his urethral lining to test for the presence of vaginal cells. The test that would be done for the same is?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lugol’s iodine test

  • Lugol’s iodine test is to detect vaginal epithelial cells containing glycogen.

Option B: Takayama test

  • Takayama test is to detect blood stains.

Option C: Florence test

  • Florence test is a test for seminal stain.

Option D: Precipitin test

  • Species identification is done by the precipitin test.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man was apprehended by the college officials after multiple students witnessed him forcefully pushing a girl to the floor and also attempting to remove her saree. He was rejected by the same girl after he proposed her for a relationship. The family of the girl and the college officials have decided to file charges under a section that deals with "Assault or use of criminal force against a woman with intent to disrobe". Which section is the man being charged under?
questions.solution:
Option C: 354 B

  • Any man who assaults or uses criminal force on any woman or abets such act with the intention of disrobing or compelling her to be naked is punishable with imprisonment for 3–7 years and a fine (Sec. 354-B IPC). It is a cognizable and non-bailable offense.

Option A: 354 D

  • Stalking involves following a woman or contacting such woman in spite of clear disinterest or monitoring her through the internet, e-mail, or any other form of electronic communication. It is punishable under Sec. 354-D IPC with imprisonment for up to 3 years and fine (cognizable and bailable) and imprisonment up to 5 years and fine for subsequent offense (cognizable and non-bailable).

Option B: 354 A

  • Sexual harassment is defined as physical contact and advances involving unwelcome and explicit sexual overtures, demanding sexual favors, showing pornography against her will, or making sexually colored remarks. It is punishable with (rigorous) imprisonment for 1–3 years with/without a fine (Sec. 354-A IPC). The offense is cognizable and bailable.

Option D: 354 C

  • Under Sec. 354-C IPC, voyeurism is a punishable offense. It states that ‘any man who watches or captures the images of a woman engaged in a private act (changing clothes, using lavatory or doing a sexual act) in circumstances where it is expected of not being observed or circulate such image is punishable with imprisonment from 1–3 years and fine (cognizable and bailable), and for 2nd offense, imprisonment is for 3–7 years and fine (cognizable and non-bailable).

questions.text: A body was found in a forest with multiple injuries. Examination of the body revealed a superficial injury on the skin caused by friction. Which of the following injuries is most likely to have caused this?
questions.solution:
Option A

  • An abrasion (gravel rash) is a destruction of the skin, which usually involves the superficial layers of the epidermis only. Thickness of skin is 1.6 mm. They are caused by friction against a rough surface or by compression.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Option B) Contusion is a type of injury caused by blunt force trauma, resulting in bleeding under the skin. 
  • Option C) Avulsion is a type of injury that occurs when a portion of the skin is forcibly removed from the body. 
  • Option D) Incised wound is a type of injury caused by a sharp object that results in a clean cut in the skin.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male is found dead. The autopsy reveals the presence of frothy fluid in the air passages and lungs, as well as acute pulmonary edema. There are no injuries or signs of violence. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Option A

  • The presence of frothy fluid in the air passages and lungs, as well as acute pulmonary edema, are consistent with a diagnosis of drowning. Drowning is the process of experiencing respiratory impairment from submersion or immersion in liquid, leading to suffocation.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Option B) Acute myocardial infarction is unlikely in the absence of any evidence of heart disease or a history of cardiac problems.
  • Option C) Hypothermia would not cause frothy fluid in the air passages and lungs or acute pulmonary edema.
  • Option D) Poisoning is unlikely without any signs of ingestion or other evidence of exposure to toxins.

questions.text: A forensic pathologist examined a gunshot wound on a cadaver and found that the bullet entered the chest, went through the liver and spleen, and exited through the back. The pathologist also observed that the wound was surrounded by extensive hemorrhage and that there were multiple bone fragments in the surrounding tissue. Based on these findings, which of the following firearms was most likely used in this incident?
questions.solution:
Option C

  • The extensive hemorrhage and multiple bone fragments around the wound suggest that a high-velocity round was used, which is typical of rifles rather than handguns or shotguns. The AR-15 is a common rifle used in many shooting incidents and has a high velocity.

Why the other choices are incorrect:

  • Option A) A .22 caliber handgun has a much lower velocity than a rifle and would not cause the extensive hemorrhage and bone fragments observed in this case.
  • Option B) A 12-gauge shotgun fires pellets or slugs, which are less likely to cause the extensive damage seen in this case.
  • Option D) A .38 caliber revolver has a lower velocity than the AR-15 and is less likely to cause the extensive hemorrhage and bone fragments observed in this case.

questions.text: A decomposed human body was found in a forest. The forensic team collected some skeletal remains for identification purposes. The forensic expert noticed that the pubic symphysis had completely fused and the auricular surface had a considerable amount of lipping. What method of identification is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
Option A

  • The complete fusion of the pubic symphysis and considerable lipping on the auricular surface are both indicators of aging. Forensic anthropology is a specialized field that can determine the age, sex, and ethnicity of skeletal remains, making it the most appropriate method for identification in this case. 

Why the other choices are incorrect:

  • B) Dental examination may not be suitable in this case since dental records may not be available or teeth may be absent in a decomposed body.
  • C) DNA analysis may be difficult or impossible due to the degree of decomposition and limited availability of soft tissue.
  • D) Radiography may be useful in determining skeletal injuries, but not age estimation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a known case of diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and pancreatic carcinoma with liver secondaries on palliative treatment. He is attending the pain clinic regularly and getting tablets of morphine for cancer pain. He was not able to come and get treatment for the past 3 days. Which of the following symptom will the patient suffer for using the drug involved in this case for 3 days?
questions.solution:
Option B: Abdominal cramps, vomiting, insomnia

  • The physical dependence on morphine usually requires about 25 days to develop but may occur sooner in emotionally unstable persons.
  • Abdominal cramps, nausea, vomiting & diarrhoea, reach their peak in 72 hours & then decline over the next 7 to 10 days.
  • The following are some of the most common side effects of morphine use: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and constipation are examples of gastrointestinal side effects.
  • Morphine opioid receptors are present in the gastrointestinal tract, and their activation may cause a slowing of gut movement, resulting in constipation.

Option A: Constipation, bradycardia, coma

  • Atropine is a prescription medication used to treat symptoms of low heart rate (bradycardia), to reduce salivation and bronchial secretions prior to surgery, and as an antidote for cholinergic drug overdose or mushroom poisoning.
  • Constipation, bradycardia, and coma are the side effects.

Option C: Hyperthermia, vomiting, restlessness

  • Several drugs or drug classes, including amphetamines, diuretics, cocaine, antipsychotics, metoclopramide, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs), and alcohol, can cause or contribute to hyperthermia disorders.
  • Calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum of muscle cells has been shown to increase with antipsychotic use, potentially leading to increased muscle contractility and rigidity, muscle breakdown, and hyperthermia, along with vomiting and restlessness.

Option D: Hypothermia, nausea, constipation

  • Hypothermia is a rare but potentially fatal side effect of antipsychotic medication (APD). Despite extensive research into the opposite condition, hyperthermia, in the context of the malignant antipsychotic syndrome, little is known about hypothermia caused by APDs.
  • Drugs can cause hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis dysregulation, resulting in an increase in core temperature.

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida with 32-week of gestation presents with severe bleeding per vagina, On examination altered sensorium, hypotension, tachycardia and cold and clammy peripheries. Immediate resuscitation measures started with blood and blood products, but the patient developed cardiac arrest. Resuscitation has been started based on the ACLS guidelines. Which of the following would be the time period for the aim for delivery in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: 5 min

  • Cardiopulmonary resuscitation in pregnancy:
    • Perform manual left uterine displacement.
    • Anticipate difficult airway management.
    • Obtain intravenous access above the diaphragm.
    • If the patient receives magnesium sulphate, discontinue magnesium infusion and administer calcium chloride or calcium gluconate.
    • Remove all fetal monitors before delivery; internal fetal monitors may be cut externally. Fetal monitor removal should not delay defibrillation
    • If we are resuscitating a pregnant female with cardiac arrest and there is no successful return of spontaneous circulation within 5 minutes, immediate resuscitative hysterotomy or cesarean delivery is to be performed if gestational age is 20 weeks or greater, aiming for delivery within 5 minutes of cardiac arrest.
    • Continue all resuscitation measures during and after cesarean delivery

Option A: 4 min

  • The delivery of the pregnant female should be carried out within 5 minutes.

Option C: 8 min

  • The time frame of 5 minutes is set as a target for the delivery of pregnant females.

Option D: 10 min

  • If delivery has waited for 10 minutes, the death of the fetus can be a consequence.
  • To prevent further complications, a time frame of 5 minutes is set.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department in an exhausted state. According to her husband, she has ingested 10-15 tablets of alprazolam. On examination, she is drowsy, arousable and obeys commands. Her blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, and her pulse is 60/minute. Her SpO2-96% with 10 litres of oxygen. Which of the following is the specific antidote for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Flumazenil

  • Flumazenil is the specific antidote for benzodiazepine poisoning.
  • Flumazenil is a specific and exclusive benzodiazepine antagonist. It acts in a dose-dependent manner and reverses all the agonist effects of benzodiazepines.
  • Flumazenil is the first benzodiazepine antagonist approved for clinical use to reverse the effects of benzodiazepines. It is a competitive antagonist at the benzodiazepine receptor and produces reversible antagonism. It is rapidly metabolically cleared, however, the proportion of receptors occupied by the agonist then increases again, and the potential for rebound sedation and respiratory depression occurs.
  • This is less likely to occur when it is used to reverse the midazolam as it has more rapid clearance than other benzodiazepine agonists. A smaller dose of flumazenil attenuates CNS depression for extremely large doses of agonists. Large doses of flumazenil in the presence of small doses of agonist completely reverse the agonistic effects.
  • It is completely metabolized in the liver(99%) and rapidly cleared from the plasma.
  • Uses and dosage of Flumazenil: Flumazenil is used for the diagnostic and therapeutic reversal of benzodiazepine receptor agonists.
  • Reversal of benzodiazepines-0.2 mg repeated up to 3 mg
  • Diagnosis in coma-0.5 mg repeated up to 1 mg
  • It produces a rapid and dependable reversal of unconsciousness, respiratory depression, sedation, amnesia, and psychomotor dysfunction.
  • It successfully reverses the effects of midazolam, diazepam, lorazepam, and flunitrazepam and reverses chloralhydrate and cannabis intoxication, carbamazepine, alcohol, and antihistamine overdose.
  • It may cause benzodiazepine withdrawal symptoms(seizures) when administered in patients with large doses of benzodiazepines.
  • It has high safety of margin and no organ toxicity.

Option A: Zaleplon

  • Zoleplon is a non-benzodiazipine medication.
  • It affects the sleep cycle less than typical benzodiazepine.

Option C: Naloxone

  • Naloxone is used to reverse opioid toxicity.

Option D: Atropine

  • Atropine is used for beta-blocker overdose.
  • It is not used for benzodiazepine toxicity

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe shortness of breath. On examination, he has decreased breath sounds on the right side and a chest X-ray reveals a large right-sided pleural effusion. Thoracentesis is performed and 1.5 liters of fluid is drained. Despite the drainage, the patient's respiratory distress worsens, and his arterial blood gas shows a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 150. Which of the following best explains this finding?

choices.text: The thoracentesis caused the lung to collapse, leading to decreased pulmonary compliance.
