The pleural effusion caused compression atelectasis and decreased pulmonary compliance.
The patient has developed pulmonary edema secondary to fluid overload.
The patient has developed a pulmonary embolism, leading to decreased pulmonary compliance.

questions.solution:
Explanation: Option B: 

  • Pulmonary compliance is a measure of how easily the lungs expand and contract with changes in pressure. A decrease in pulmonary compliance indicates that the lungs are stiff and more difficult to inflate, which can lead to respiratory distress. In this case, the patient presented with a large pleural effusion on the right side, which is a collection of fluid outside of the lung that can compress the lung tissue and lead to decreased pulmonary compliance. Thoracentesis was performed to drain the fluid, but despite the drainage, the patient's respiratory distress worsened. This finding is most likely due to compression atelectasis, which is the collapse of lung tissue due to compression by the pleural effusion. This can lead to decreased lung volume and increased difficulty in breathing, even after the fluid has been drained.

Why other options are incorrect

A) The thoracentesis caused the lung to collapse, leading to decreased pulmonary compliance.

  • This option is incorrect because thoracentesis is a procedure that involves draining fluid from the pleural space and should not cause lung collapse unless it is done incorrectly or if the patient has underlying lung disease.

C) The patient has developed pulmonary edema secondary to fluid overload.

This option is incorrect because pulmonary edema is a condition in which fluid accumulates in the lung tissue, causing respiratory distress. It is unlikely to occur in a patient with a large pleural effusion, and the patient's symptoms are more consistent with compression atelectasis.

D) The patient has developed a pulmonary embolism, leading to decreased pulmonary compliance.

  • This option is incorrect because a pulmonary embolism is a blood clot in the pulmonary circulation that can lead to decreased oxygenation and respiratory distress. However, this is not the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms given the presentation of a large pleural effusion and the lack of other signs and symptoms of pulmonary embolism, such as chest pain or coughing up blood.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presented with sudden visual loss affecting the right temporal region. Ultrasound of the globe demonstrated right-sided retinal detachment with a well-defined flat echogenic mass. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ocular melanoma

  • Choroidal melanoma is adults' most common primary intraocular malignancy and accounts for 80% of all uveal melanomas.
  • The incidence of this tumor increases with age.
  • Clinical presentation may range from no symptoms over various visual disturbances to visual loss.
  • Ultrasound is an excellent modality for examining the globe and can visualize small plaque-like or discoid uveal melanoma with a thickness of less than 3 mm, which are usually difficult to assess on CT or MRI.
  • Typical USG Features include hypo-to-isoechoic "collar button" or "mushroom" shaped lobulated mass with internal vascularity.

Option A: Choroidal metastases

  • Choroidal metastases are the most frequent malignant intraocular tumor. In most cases, they arise after identifying the primary tumor and are associated with the involvement of other organs.
  • Less frequently, the ocular lesion may be the first presentation of a primary tumor or relapse of a primary disseminated tumor.
  • Enhanced choroid imaging allows a better understanding and precise diagnosis of choroidal metastases.
  • If the primary remains unknown, tumor biopsy may help identify the primary and guide treatment.
  • To date, fractionated radiotherapy remains the treatment of choice for choroidal metastases.

Option B: Orbital hematoma

  • Orbital hematomas may occur spontaneously due to vascular anomalies, or they may be induced by trauma or occur following paranasal sinus surgery.
  • The retrobulbar hematoma requires special attention because its potential optic nerve compression may compromise vision or cause blindness.
  • Orbital hematoma has been described as a rare complication of trans-nasal endoscopic sinus surgery (<0.4% cases).
  • Other causes were .trauma, vascular malformation, orbital neoplastic or non-neoplastic lesions, bleeding disorders, and barotrauma during anesthesia.

Option D: Ocular hemangioma

  • A hemangioma can grow red to the red-purple raised lesion on the skin and sometimes get very large.
  • When hemangiomas grow on the eyelids, the eye surface, or the eye socket, they can interrupt the normal development of vision. Hemangiomas can affect vision in several ways.
  • These conditions can be life-threatening if they are large or affect a child's airway or another organ.
  • A hemangioma can also be serious if it has uncontrollable bleeding.
  • Where a child's growth is located may cause physical problems.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old female presents with intermittent episodes of crampy abdominal pain and constipation for the past 3 months. She denies any rectal bleeding or weight loss. She has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Physical examination reveals distended abdomen with diffuse tenderness. Laboratory studies show no significant abnormalities. Radiological findings are as below.



What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option C

  • The barium enema findings of "beak-like" narrowing of the sigmoid colon with proximal dilation is suggestive of colonic volvulus. Colonic volvulus is a condition where the colon twists on itself, causing obstruction and dilation of the proximal colon.

Why the other options are incorrect

  • A. Barium enema findings in Hirschsprung's disease typically show a transition zone between the normal and dilated colon.
  • B. Colonic diverticulosis is a condition where small outpouches form in the colon wall, and barium enema findings may show multiple, small, round, or oval contrast-filled pouches protruding from the colon wall.
  • D. Colorectal cancer may present with different findings on imaging studies, such as CT scan or colonoscopy, including masses, polyps, or irregularities in the colonic mucosa.

questions.text:
A 2-day-old male neonate presents with failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, and vomiting. An abdominal X-ray shows the following findings:



Image A: X-ray

 

The histopathological examination of the myenteric plexuses is as follows:



Image B: Histopath of myenteric plexus 

What is the most likely radiological diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option A

  • Clinical presentation of failure to pass meconium, abdominal distension, and vomiting, along with radiological findings of a distended colon with a fecal mass on X-ray and absence of ganglion cells on rectal biopsy, suggests Hirschsprung's disease. It is a congenital disorder characterized by absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon, leading to functional obstruction.

Why the Others are Incorrect:

  • B. Intestinal atresia - Absence of ganglion cells in the submucosal and myenteric plexuses is not characteristic of intestinal atresia on radiological imaging.
  • C. Necrotizing enterocolitis is a condition that affects premature infants and is characterized by inflammation and necrosis of the intestinal wall. Absence of ganglion cells is not a characteristic feature of necrotizing enterocolitis.
  • D. Meconium ileus is a condition in which an obstruction of the ileum by thick meconium is seen, but absence of ganglion cells is not a characteristic feature of meconium ileus.

questions.text:
A 2-month-old male infant presents to the emergency department with cyanosis and labored breathing. Physical examination reveals clubbing of the fingers and toes. The infant's mother reports that he has been experiencing poor feeding and decreased energy over the past few weeks. The chest X-ray is as follows:

 



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option C

  • Tetralogy of Fallot is the most likely diagnosis. The symptoms of cyanosis, labored breathing, clubbing of the fingers and toes, and boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray are all indicative of Tetralogy of Fallot. 

Why the other choices are incorrect:

  • A) Ventricular septal defect may present with similar symptoms but do not exhibit the characteristic boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray. VSD may also show features of pulmonary edema, pleural effusion and increased pulmonary vascular markings. VSD shows gross Cardiomegaly with prominence of both ventricles, the left atrium, and the pulmonary artery.
  • B) Atrial septal defect typically presents with enlargement of right atrium and ventricle on the x ray. Dilatation of the pulmonary artery and its branches may also be seen in the x ray. A wide and fixed split of S2 can also be heard on auscultation but may not always be present.
  • D) Patent ductus arteriosus may present with similar symptoms but do not exhibit the characteristic boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray. It generally presents with cardiomegaly (predominantly left atrial and left ventricular enlargement). Obstruction of aortopulmonary window and pulmonary edema may also be seen.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents with a history of fever, malaise, and a painful rash on his trunk and extremities that rapidly spread to involve his mucous membranes, including his oral cavity, eyes, and genitals. The rash started as small blisters that coalesced and formed large, flaccid blisters that easily detached, leaving behind denuded areas of skin. Biopsy results showed full-thickness epidermal necrosis with minimal inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option C

  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) is a rare but severe cutaneous adverse reaction characterized by widespread epidermal detachment and mucosal involvement. It usually presents as a flu-like illness with a painful rash that rapidly spreads and involves the mucous membranes, including the oral cavity, eyes, and genitals. The rash starts as small blisters that coalesce and form large, flaccid blisters that easily detach, leaving behind denuded areas of skin. Biopsy results show full-thickness epidermal necrosis with minimal inflammation.

Why other options are incorrect:

 

A) Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune disease that causes intraepidermal blistering due to the production of autoantibodies against desmoglein-3, a protein that helps to bind the epidermal cells together. However, it typically does not involve the mucous membranes, and the biopsy results show suprabasilar acantholysis with a sparse inflammatory infiltrate.

B) Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune disease that causes subepidermal blistering due to the production of autoantibodies against basement membrane antigens, such as BP180 and BP230. It typically does not involve the mucous membranes, and the biopsy results show a subepidermal blister with an eosinophilic infiltrate.

D) Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) is a less severe form of TEN that involves less than 10% of the body surface area and is characterized by epidermal detachment with minimal mucosal involvement. The biopsy results also typically show inflammation, with a mixed inflammatory infiltrate in the dermis and epidermis.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is typically used to treat a pruritic rash with subepidermal blistering and granular deposits of immunoglobulin A (IgA) in the papillary dermis?
questions.solution:
• Dapsone is a medication that has been used for several decades to treat dermatitis herpetiformis, and it remains the first-line treatment for this condition. It is a sulfone antibiotic that has both anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties, and it is believed to work by suppressing the inflammatory response that leads to the characteristic rash and blisters in dermatitis herpetiformis.

Why Others are Wrong

A) Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a systemic immunosuppressive agent that is used to treat a variety of autoimmune diseases. However, it is not typically used as a first-line treatment for dermatitis herpetiformis.

B) Azathioprine: Azathioprine is another systemic immunosuppressive agent that is used to treat autoimmune diseases. However, it is not typically used as a first-line treatment for dermatitis herpetiformis.

D) Prednisone: Prednisone is a corticosteroid that is used to treat a variety of inflammatory conditions. However, it is not typically used as a first-line treatment for dermatitis herpetiformis, and may actually worsen the symptoms of the condition in some cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presented with complaints of chronic diarrhea, weight loss and skin rash. She also reports bloating, abdominal pain, and fatigue. Laboratory studies show iron-deficiency anemia and positive serology for anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. Upper endoscopy with duodenal biopsy reveals subtotal villous atrophy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Empiric treatment for irritable bowel syndrome

questions.solution:
Explanation: Option A: 

  • This patient's presentation, laboratory studies, and biopsy findings are consistent with celiac disease, an autoimmune disorder that is triggered by the ingestion of gluten-containing foods. The most appropriate next step in the management of this patient is a trial of a gluten-free diet, which is the cornerstone of treatment for celiac disease. The diet should be strictly adhered to, and a follow-up evaluation should be performed to assess response to the diet.

Why Others are Wrong:

Option B) Referral for genetic testing may be useful in the diagnosis of celiac disease, as most patients with celiac disease have the HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 genotype. However, a positive genetic test does not confirm the diagnosis, and a negative test does not rule it out.

Option C) Colonoscopy with biopsy is not indicated in the evaluation of celiac disease, as the condition primarily affects the small intestine.

Option D) Empiric treatment for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is not appropriate in this case, as the patient's symptoms and laboratory findings are not consistent with IBS. Additionally, a trial of a gluten-free diet is warranted given the positive serology and biopsy findings

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding bullous diseases?

choices.text: Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune disease that primarily affects the elderly and presents with tense blisters on the trunk and extremities.
Pemphigus vulgaris is a bacterial infection that causes blistering and is commonly seen in children.
Erythema multiforme is a fungal infection that presents with small, itchy blisters on the arms and legs.
Dermatitis herpetiformis is a viral infection that causes large, fluid-filled blisters on the face and scalp

questions.solution:
Option A

  • Bullous pemphigoid is a chronic autoimmune disease that primarily affects the elderly and presents with tense blisters on the trunk and extremities. The blisters are usually itchy but not painful. 

Why other choices are incorrect:

B)Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune disease, not a bacterial infection, and causes blistering of the skin and mucous membranes. 

C) Erythema multiforme is not a fungal infection, but rather a hypersensitivity reaction to medications, infections, or other triggers, and presents with target-shaped lesions on the arms and legs. 

D) Dermatitis herpetiformis is not a viral infection, but rather an autoimmune disease associated with gluten sensitivity, and causes intensely itchy blisters on the elbows, knees, scalp, and buttocks.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man with 20 pack-year history of smoking presents to the physician's office with a complaint of hoarseness of voice for the past few months. On laryngeal examination, there was an outgrowth covering the vocal cords bilaterally, and the biopsy sample was taken. He was diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma of stage T4a and subsequently underwent a total laryngectomy. Which of the following statements are true about total laryngectomy?

1. Usually done for carcinoma larynx

2. Speech difficulty present

3. High tracheostomy is done in total laryngectomy

4. After total laryngectomy, the patient presents with dysphagia
questions.solution:
Option B: 1, 2, 3 and 4 are correct  

This man presents a complaint of hoarseness of voice and a 20-pack-year smoking history with a biopsy of the laryngeal lesion showing stage T4a laryngeal carcinoma. The most appropriate treatment is total laryngectomy.

  • Total laryngectomy involves the removal of the entire larynx, including the hyoid bone, pre-epiglottic space, strap muscles, and one or more trachea rings. The pharyngeal wall is repaired, and the lower tracheal stump is sutured to the skin for breathing.
  • Total laryngectomy with or without post-operative radiotherapy offers the best chances for a cure for carcinoma larynx.
  • It is associated with a significant reduction in quality of life and functional sequela:
    • Loss of normal speech quality and quantity
    • Loss of airway protection, ineffective coughing, and inability to strain.
    • Loss of nasal air conditioning, sense of taste and smell, normal nasal homeostasis, and immunity.
    • Defective swallowing
    • Psychological problems due to Body image issues with the stoma
    • A high tracheostomy is done and following laryngectomy, the patient breathes through the permanent tracheostomy (so loss of smell).
  • Therefore, it is reserved for advanced T4a stage tumors or in cases of locally recurrent disease after radiation treatment.

Option A: Only 1, 2, and 3 are correct.

  • As it involves high tracheostomy and speech difficulty, total laryngectomy is only done for laryngeal carcinoma. Also the patients present with dysphagia due to loss of pharyngeal constrictors.

Option C: Only 1, 2, and 4 are correct.

  • A high tracheostomy is done, which is permanent as well as loss of pharyngeal constrictors which leads to dysphagia; therefore, it is only done for laryngeal carcinoma.

Option D: Only 1 and 4 are correct.

  • It is usually done for laryngeal carcinoma as it can result in complications such dysphagia due to loss of pharyngeal constrictors and therefore not used for early stages.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the physician's office with a complaint of hoarseness of voice for the past six months. He is a chronic smoker and has a 50-pack-year history of smoking. On physical examination, neck lymph nodes are not palpable; however, laryngoscopy shows a large, infiltrating, fungating, soft papillary lesion. Two biopsies taken from the lesion proper show be­nign appearing papillomatosis with hyperkeratosis and acanthosis infiltrating the subjacent tissues. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Verrucous carcinoma

The squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor affecting the head and neck region (oropharynx, oral cavity, hypopharynx, larynx, and sinonasal tract). The head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) has many morphological variants.

Verrucous carcinoma:

  • Typically occurs in the oral cavity, rarely said to occur in the larynx, hypopharynx, sinonasal tract, and nasopharynx.
  • Verrucous carcinoma has a warty, exophytic lesion that arises from a broad base with a superficial spreading growth but can be deeply destructive by extending into the muscle, bone, and cartilage.
  • Slowly growing and locally aggressive well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, which does not metastasize.
  • Accounts for 1–2% of laryngeal carcinomas.
  • HPV 16 and 18 are associated with this lesion.
  • The larynx is the second most common site after the oral cavity
  • Presents as an exophytic and fungating carpet-like lesion that is hard to distinguish macroscopically from hyperkeratosis.
  • Significant inflammation surrounds the lesion & leads to enlarged inflammatory neck nodes.
  • Biopsy shows papillomatosis with hyperkeratosis and acanthosis infiltrating the subjacent tissues.
  • Biopsies are often repeated before adequate diagnosis. The diagnosis of VC is established by close communication between surgeons and pathologists.
  • Surgery is considered the treatment of choice.

Option A: Adenocarcinoma

  • Adenocarcinoma of the head and neck involves the salivary glands, not the laryngeal vocal cords.
  • Histology will show the presence of glanduloductal elements instead of hyperkeratosis and papillomatosis.

Option B: Sarcoma

  • Spindle cell carcinoma (sarcomatoid carcinoma) is a subtype of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.
  • It occurs mostly in the upper respiratory tract or less commonly in the oral cavity.
  • Patients are elderly males with previous radiation exposure.
  • Microscopically show polypoidal, exophytic configuration with either a broad base or narrow pedicle.
  • The tumor appears to be bi-phasic, with lesions showing areas of squamous cell carcinoma associated with bizarre spindle cell and/or giant cell proliferation of sarcomatoid appearance.

Option C: Adenosquamous carcinoma

  • Adenosquamous carcinoma is an uncommon variant of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Considered aggressive and associated with a poor prognosis.
  • Predominantly affects males in the sixth or seventh decade.
  • The larynx and hypopharynx is the most commonly affected site.
  • Macroscopically the tumor resembled squamous cell carcinoma; however, microscopically, it is characterized by the presence of squamous cell carcinoma admixed with a variable proportion of glanduloductal elements.
  • Histochemistry of mucin and keratin is seen.

questions.text:
A group of medical students gives a presentation on the musculature of the larynx. They describe the muscles of the larynx, their origin and insertion, their action, and innervation. Which of the following laryngeal muscles is/are innervated bi-directionally?


	Vocalis
	Posterior cricoarytenoid
	Lateral cricoarytenoid
	Interarytenoid
questions.solution:
Option D: Only 4 is correct

Interarytenoid muscle is innervated bidirectionally by the superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) and recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN)

  • Interarytenoid muscle is an unpaired muscle in the centre between the 2 arytenoid cartilages and is innervated bidirectionally.
  • Transverse and oblique interarythenoids adduct the vocal folds
  • Transverse interarythenoids might receive visceral motor fibers from the internal branch of SLN

Option A: 1,2,3, and 4 are correct

  • This option is not the correct answer because 1,2 and 3 are incorrect
  • Vocalis or Thyroarytenoid muscles are innervated by the recurrent laryngeal nerve, a branch of the vagus nerve (CN X).
  • Posterior cricoarytenoid is innervated by RLN/inferior Laryngeal nerve.
  • Lateral cricoarytenoid is innervated by RLN.

Option B: Only 2 & 3 are correct

  • Posterior cricoarytenoid and lateral cricoarytenoid are supplied by RLN. They do not have a bidirectional nerve supply.

Option C: Only 1 is correct

  • Vocalis is supplied by RLN. It does not have a bidirectional nerve supply.

AP= Arytenoid plexus

CA= Cricoid communication.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female of low socioeconomic status visits the hospital with complaints of difficulty swallowing for the last 2 months. On further examination, the patient has spoon-shaped nails. Laboratory investigations reveal microcytic hypochromic anemia. Which of the following is the most probable site of carcinoma in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Post cricoid region

Plummer-Vinson Syndrome/ Patterson-Kelly-Brown Syndrome

Consists of the following triad:

  • Post cricoid webs- dysphagia
  • Iron Deficiency Anemia (Glossitis/ Angular cheilitis)
  • Koilonychia (Spoon shaped nails)

The post-cricoid webs are premalignant and lead to Squamous cell carcinoma formation in post-cricoid areas in females suffering from Plummer–Vinson syndrome.

Option C: Medial wall of Pyriform sinus

  • The lateral aspect of the aryepiglottic folds forms the medial wall of the pyriform sinus.
  • It is present on either side of larynx.
  • This region is not involved in Plummer-Vinson Syndrome.

Option D: Lateral wall of Pyriform sinus

  • The thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane form the lateral wall of the Pyriform sinus. This region is not involved in Plummer-Vinson Syndrome.

Option A: Posterior pharyngeal wall

  • It extends from the hyoid bone to the level of the cricoarytenoid joint. This region of the hypopharynx is not involved in Plummer-Vinson Syndrome.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presents to the clinic due to fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing for 3 days. He has a history of tonsillitis, and this is the sixth episode in the past two years. The patient undergoes a tonsillectomy to relieve the symptoms. The patient presents to the clinic again on the seventh day of surgery with bleeding from the surgical site. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s bleeding?
questions.solution:
Option C: Secondary infection

Indications for tonsillectomy

They are divided into:

A. Absolute

  • Recurrent infections of the throat. This is the most common indication. Recurrent infections are further defined as:
    • Seven or more episodes in a year, or
    • Five episodes in a year for 2 years, or
    • Three episodes in a year for 3 years, or
    • Two weeks or more of lost school and work in a year.
  • Peritonsillar abscess: In children, tonsillectomy is carried out 4–6 weeks after an abscess has been treated. In adults, the second attack of peritonsillar abscess forms the absolute indication.
  • Tonsillitis causes febrile seizures.
  • Hypertrophy of tonsils causing
    • Airway obstruction (sleep apnea),
    • Difficulty in deglutition and
    • Interference with speech.
  • Suspicion of malignancy. A unilaterally enlarged tonsil may be lymphoma in children and an epidermoid carcinoma in adults. An excisional biopsy is done.

B. Relative

  • Diphtheria carriers are not responding to antibiotics.
  • Streptococcal carriers may be the source of infection to others.
  • Chronic tonsillitis with bad taste or halitosis is unresponsive to medical treatment.
  • Recurrent streptococcal tonsillitis in valvular heart disease patients.

C. As part of another operation

  • Palatopharyngoplasty is done for sleep>Glossopharyngeal neurectomy. The tonsil is removed first, and then the IX nerve is severed in the tonsil bed.
  • Removal of the styloid process.

Contraindications

  • Hemoglobin level less than 10 g%.
  • Presence of acute upper respiratory tract infection and acute tonsillitis. The acute infection leads to more bleeding.
  • Children under 3 years of age. They are poor surgical risks.
  • Overt or submucous cleft palate.
  • Von Willebrand disease. Bleeding disorders, e.g., leukemia, purpura, aplastic anemia, hemophilia, or sickle cell disease.
  • At the time of the epidemic of polio.
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g., diabetes, coronary artery disease, hypertension, or asthma.
  • Tonsillectomy is avoided during menstruation.

Postoperative care requires keeping a watch for bleeding from the nose and mouth. Hemorrhage is one of the postoperative complications. It is categorized as:

Primary               Reactionary            Secondary  

Intraoperative bleed at the time of surgery.

Venous bleedingThe most common source is the paratonsillar vein.

Treatment: Ligation, electrocoagulation of vessels.

Occurs within 24 hours.

Due to slippage of ligature or clot formation preventing clipping of the artery.

Treatment: Application of pressure/ vasoconstrictor, removal of the clot, and lastly, if all measures fail, ligation of vessels.

Between 5-10 postoperative days.

Due to secondary infection (sepsis) or premature separation of membranes.

  

Option A: Slippage of ligature

It is an incorrect option because:

  • Slippage of the ligature is the cause of reactionary hemorrhage.
  • Reactionary hemorrhage usually occurs within 24 hrs.
  • It does not lead to bleeding on the 7th postoperative day.

Option B: Clot formation

It is an incorrect option because:

  • Clot formation leads to reactionary hemorrhage within 24 hours of the surgery.
  • Clot prevents the clipping action of superior constrictor muscle on the vessels that pass through it, leading to hemorrhage.
  • It does not lead to bleeding on the 7th postoperative day.

Option D: Venous bleed

It is an incorrect option because:

  • Venous bleed is a cause of primary hemorrhage.
  • Primary hemorrhage occurs during surgery.
  • It does not lead to a bleed 7 days after the surgery.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent episodes of epistaxis. On examination, you find anterior nasal bleeding that has not responded to conservative measures. Which of the following is the best management option?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option D

  • Epistaxis is a common condition that can be managed with conservative measures in most cases. However, in cases of recurrent or severe bleeding, more aggressive management may be necessary. Endoscopic arterial ligation involves identifying the bleeding vessel and ligating it under direct visualization using an endoscope. This technique has a high success rate and can provide long-lasting relief of symptoms.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • A) Direct cauterization of the bleeding site can be effective for anterior nasal bleeding but may not address the underlying cause and can cause scarring, which may increase the risk of future bleeding episodes.
  • B) Nasal packing with gauze can be effective for controlling bleeding, but it is uncomfortable for the patient and can lead to complications such as infection or tissue necrosis.
  • C) Application of vasoconstrictor agents such as phenylephrine or oxymetazoline can be effective for mild bleeding but may not be sufficient for more severe cases and can have adverse effects such as rebound congestion or hypertension.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with nasal congestion and stuffiness for several weeks. He has been using nasal decongestant sprays frequently for relief. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option D

  • Rhinitis medicamentosa is a condition that occurs due to overuse of nasal decongestant sprays. The continuous use of these sprays can cause rebound nasal congestion, leading to symptoms similar to chronic rhinosinusitis or allergic rhinitis. In this scenario, the patient's history of frequent use of nasal decongestant sprays and the absence of other symptoms suggest a diagnosis of rhinitis medicamentosa.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • A) Chronic rhinosinusitis may present with nasal congestion and stuffiness, but the patient would typically have additional symptoms such as facial pain or pressure, nasal discharge, or decreased sense of smell. These symptoms are not present in this scenario.
  • B) Allergic rhinitis may also present with nasal congestion and stuffiness, but the patient would typically have additional symptoms such as sneezing, itchy nose, or watery eyes. These symptoms are not present in this scenario.
  • C) Nasal polyps may cause nasal obstruction, but the patient would typically have additional symptoms such as decreased sense of smell or a sensation of pressure in the face. These symptoms are not present in this scenario.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with progressive hoarseness of voice and stridor. The child has a history of recurrent respiratory infections since birth. On examination, a congenital laryngeal web is observed. What is the most appropriate treatment modality for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option B

  • Congenital laryngeal web is a rare condition that occurs due to abnormal fusion of the vocal cords during embryonic development. It can lead to respiratory distress, recurrent respiratory infections, and voice changes. The treatment of choice for this condition is surgical repair, which involves dividing the web and reconstructing the airway. Tracheostomy may be considered in severe cases or if there is a risk of airway obstruction. Voice therapy and antibiotics are not effective in treating this condition.

Why the other choices are incorrect:

  • A) Tracheostomy may be considered in severe cases or if there is a risk of airway obstruction, but it is not the primary treatment modality for congenital laryngeal web.
  • C) Voice therapy is not effective in treating congenital laryngeal web, as it is a structural abnormality that requires surgical intervention.
  • D) Antibiotics are not effective in treating congenital laryngeal web, as it is not an infectious condition.

questions.text: A sixty-five-year-old presents to your clinic with the complaint of decreased vision in both eyes. The loss of vision was gradual, and he has not experienced any pain in his eyes. Examination findings reveal a bilateral cataract. Cataract surgery is scheduled. The patient is informed that the left eye will be operated on first, and the right eye will be done 1 week after that. An intraocular lens (IOL) is placed in the eye during the surgery. Which type of lens is shown below?
questions.solution:
Option D: Multifocal Posterior chamber IOL

  • Image in the question shows a multifocal posterior chamber IOL.
  • An intraocular lens (IOL) is implanted in the eye in place of the crystalline lens that gets opacified in a cataract.
  • An IOL consists of an optic and haptics.
  • Posterior chamber IOL is the most commonly used IOL after cataract surgery.
  • Multifocal IOLs may be refractive or diffractive.
  • Refractive IOLs mainly provide intermediate and distance vision.
  • Diffractive IOLs provide brilliant reading vision and a decent distant vision.
  • There are various rings in the optic zone of a multifocal IOL.
  • This allows the patient to see at various distances according to the multiple focal lengths.
  • Side effects include:
    • Unavoidable halos
    • Glare.

Option A: Crystalens

  • Crystalens is a type of accommodative IOL that is also placed in the posterior chamber.
  • Elastic haptics are present that change the position of the optic when a person tries to accommodate.
  • No rings are present in the optics, helping reduce glare and halos.

Option B: Anterior Chamber IOL

  • A Complicated surgery, with a rupture of the posterior capsule, may necessitate alternative positioning of the IOL.
  • In this scenario, anterior chamber IOLs are used.
  • In the anterior chamber, IOL the haptics supported in the angle.
  • The position of the anterior chamber requires a specific type of lens.
  • Complications include:
    • Uveitis
    • Glaucoma
    • Hyphema

Option C: ICL

  • An Implantable Collamer Lens (ICL) is a Posterior chamber phakic intraocular lens.
  • Posterior chamber phakic intraocular lenses are used as refractive surgery in patients unsuitable for corneal refractive surgery.
  • Has communication ports to allow passage of aqueous from the posterior chamber to the anterior chamber and posterior vault (the gap between ICL and the anterior surface of the crystalline lens).

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology OPD with a complaint of gradual painless vision loss for the last 3 months. He is unable to read a newspaper, particularly in bright sunlight. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Posterior subcapsular cataract:

  • This patient, with a gradual loss of vision and difficulty reading a newspaper in bright light, likely has a posterior subcapsular cataract.
  • Reading a newspaper in bright sunlight requires visual accommodation; thus, miosis occurs.
  • This allows only central rays of light to pass through the lens. However, the presence of a posterior subcapsular cataract makes it difficult for these light rays to pass through the lens.
  • This results in decreased vision in bright light.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nuclear cataract:

  • A nuclear cataract causes index myopia and increased refractive power of the lens.
  • This improves near vision but worsens far vision.
  • Reading a newspaper requires near vision, which would be good for a patient with a nuclear cataract.

Option B - Cortical cataract:

  • Cortical cataract causes problems in night vision as the pupil dilates at night, exposing the cataractous lens.
  • The rays of light cannot pass through the lens's peripheral part.
  • Cortical cataract is not associated with difficult vision in bright light.

Option D - Coronary Cataract:

  • Coronary cataract is an extremely common developmental cataract occurring during puberty.
  • It involves the adolescent nucleus or the deeper layer of the cortex.
  • Since the opacities are situated peripherally, vision is usually unaffected.
  • Sometimes, the associated large punctate opacities may marginally reduce the vision.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female presents to the OPD with gradual painless vision loss in both eyes over the past three months. She is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis and has been on steroid treatment for the past two years. Her IOP is within normal limits. The red reflex is absent in both eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Cataract

  • This patient, with gradual loss of vision, absent red reflex and a 2-year history of steroid therapy for rheumatoid arthritis, likely has a steroid-induced cataract.
  • Steroids cause hyperglycemia which increases the risk of lens opacification.
  • Long-term steroid use is associated with cataract formation.

Option A: Open-angle glaucoma

  • It presents with a gradual but painful loss of vision.
  • The patient has pain and redness in the eye.
  • The IOP is raised.
  • The red reflex is present.

Option B: Age-related macular degeneration

  • It presents with gradual painless loss of vision.
  • There is macular degeneration and central loss of vision.
  • The red reflex is present.
  • Peripheral vision is normal.

Option C: Diabetic retinopathy

  • It also leads to gradual painless loss of vision.
  • There is macular edema and retinal neovascularization.
  • The red reflex is present.
  • There is a history of severe, uncontrolled diabetes.

questions.text: Foreign body sensation is usually caused by poor lubrication and irritation of the normal structures of the eye, which is often associated with dry eyes and blinking disorders. Which of the following is the most highly innervated structure of the eye?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cornea

  • The highest innervated structure of the eye.
  • Anatomy of the cornea:
    • Transparent
    • Avascular structure
    • Refractive power – 45 D
    • Refractive index – 1.37
    • Thickness (least in the centre): 530-550 μm
    • Diameter: 10.5-12.5 mm.
    • Vertical diameter < Horizontal diameter.

Option A: Iris

  • The iris sphincter muscle receives its parasympathetic innervation via the short ciliary nerves, which leads to pupillary constriction (miosis) and accommodation.
  •  The parasympathetic fibres that serve the sphincter muscle originate from the Edinger-Westphal nucleus of cranial nerve III.
  • But it is not the most innervated structure of the eye.

Option C: Retina

  • Optic nerve, the second cranial nerve, which carries sensory nerve impulses from the more than one million ganglion cells of the retina toward the visual centres in the brain.
  • The retina is supplied by the central retinal artery and the short posterior ciliary arteries.
  • The central retinal artery travels in or beside the optic nerve as it pierces the sclera and then branches to supply the layers of the inner retina (i.e., the layers closest to the vitreous compartment).

Option D: Sclera

  • Sensory innervation to the anterior sclera is provided by the long posterior ciliary nerves, derived from the ophthalmic nerve.
  • The posterior sclera is innervated by the short posterior ciliary nerves that branch from the ciliary ganglion to enter the sclera close to the optic nerve.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician for an annual physical examination. He reports that his vision has progressively improved over the past 6 months, and he no longer needs the glasses he used while driving. He has hypertension and types 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include glyburide, hydrochlorothiazide, and enalapril. Examination shows 20/20 vision bilaterally. Fundoscopy shows a few microaneurysms of retinal vessels. Which is the most likely explanation for this patient's improved vision?
questions.solution:
Option B: Denaturation of lens proteins

  •  It leads to the loss of lens elasticity seen in presbyopia, a classic condition associated with ageing.
  • This patient is experiencing the phenomenon of “second sight,” in which presbyopia corrects a long-standing case of myopia, resulting in improved visual acuity due to lens changes.

Option A: Decreased susceptibility to glare

  • It can be seen in darker-coloured eyes compared to lighter-coloured ones.
  •  However, it is an unlikely pathology.
  •  Increased susceptibility to glare is a finding of normal ageing, most likely due to the effects of intraocular light scatter.
  •  It is increased in patients with cataract and would not present with an improvement in myopia in middle age.

Option C: Liquefaction of the vitreous humour

  • This would cause a worsening in the patient's vision (e.g., floaters, photopsia, scotoma), not an improvement.

Option D: Increased ciliary muscle tone

  • It is a mechanism that causes the decreased diameter of the ciliary muscle, leading to constriction and accommodation of the pupil.
  • It also induces the opening of the trabecular meshwork and drainage of aqueous humour.
  •  It would be a mechanism for decreasing intraocular pressure in an ocular emergency like glaucoma, but it would not improve myopia during middle age. Furthermore, ciliary muscle tone tends to decrease with ageing.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to an outdoor ophthalmology department with a history of severe dull pain and redness of both eyes for the last two days. She also complains of discomfort in both eyes while driving at night. A typical butterfly rash on the face spares nasolabial folds on physical examination. Upon further inquiry, the ophthalmologist knows she is a known case of SLE and taking Hydroxychloroquine. The ophthalmologist counsels her that she is suffering from scleritis, which is the inflammation of the white of the eye. Concerning the anatomy, the sclera is the thinnest and thickest, respectively, at which part of the eyeball?

choices.text: Under insertion of recti & Posterior pole of the eye
At the limbus & Posterior pole of the eye
Anterior to attachment of rectus & at the limbus
At the equator & Anterior to attachment of the rectus

questions.solution:
Option A: Under insertion of the recti & Posterior pole of the eye

  • The above given is a case of scleritis.
  • Dull pain, redness in eyes and difficulty driving at night are suggestive.
  • The sclera is thinnest at posterior to rectus muscle insertions (0.3 mm), and the posterior pole is the thickest area (1 mm).
  • Scleritis is a condition characterized by inflammation of the sclera.
  • Causes piercing eye pain (typically worse at night and with eye movement) and diffuse, bright red injection. Complications include keratitis, uveitis, cataract formation, and glaucoma.

Option B: At the limbus & Posterior pole of the eye

  • At the corneal scleral limbus, the mean scleral thickness is approximately 0.5 mm decreasing to 0.4 mm near the equator and 1 mm near the optic head.

Option C: Anterior to attachment of rectus & at the limbus

  • Its thickness is 0.6 mm anterior to rectus attachment.
  • The rectus arises from a fibrous ring that encircles the optic nerve at the optic foramen, the opening through which the nerve passes, and is attached to the sclera, the opaque portion of the eyeball, in front of the equator, or widest part, of the eye.

Option D: At the equator & Anterior to attachment of the rectus

  • The thickness of the sclera decreases to a minimum at the equator.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a most common organism for the image given below?
questions.solution:
Option D

  • The condition seen in the image is ophthalmia neonatorum. Occurs in newborns within the first 28 days of life. Presents with conjunctival swelling, redness, discharge. 
  • Commonly caused by sexually transmitted infections by common organisms such as, chlamydia trachomatis, neisseria gonorrhoea, HSV.  Streptococcus pneumoniae is not the most common causative organism.

Why other options are incorrect?

  • Option A: Chlamydia trachomatis:  most common organism, sexually transmitted infection, acquired as a result of normal vaginal delivery in an infected mother 
  • Option B: Neisseria gonorrhoea: is one of the most severe causes of neonatal conjunctivitis, requiring prompt diagnosis and treatment, sexually transmitted infection, acquired as a result of normal vaginal delivery in an infected mother 
  • Option C: Herpes simplex virus:Streptococcus pneumoniae is not a common causative organism for Ophthalmia neonatorum

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the ophthalmologist with complaints of dryness and irritation in his eyes. On examination, it is found that his tear film is unstable and there is decreased tear production. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D

  • The autonomic nervous system regulates tear production, and dysfunction in this system can lead to decreased tear production, unstable tear film, and dryness in the eyes. Therefore, autonomic dysfunction is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms.

Why are the other options incorrect?

Option A

  • The sympathetic nervous system (SNS) does have a role in regulating tear production, but its function is to decrease tear production, not increase it. Dysfunction in the SNS can lead to dry eyes, but in this scenario, the patient is experiencing decreased tear production and unstable tear film, which is more likely due to dysfunction in the autonomic nervous system. Therefore, option A is not the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms.

Options B

  • The parasympathetic nervous system (PNS) is responsible for increasing tear production, not decreasing it. Dysfunction in the PNS can lead to excessive tearing or tearing that is not properly regulated, but in this scenario, the patient is experiencing decreased tear production and unstable tear film, which is more likely due to dysfunction in the autonomic nervous system (ANS). Therefore, option B is not the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms.

Option C

  • The somatic nervous system (SNS) does not play a direct role in tear production or regulation. The SNS is responsible for voluntary muscle control and sensory perception, but it does not have any direct control over the lacrimal gland, which produces tears. In this scenario, the patient is experiencing decreased tear production and unstable tear film, which is more likely due to dysfunction in the autonomic nervous system (ANS). Therefore, option C is not the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with pain and swelling in the thigh. On a further query, he states that he was injured in a road traffic accident two years back and had a compound fracture. His medical history has been consistent with type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for the past 5 years. His X-ray is shown in the image given below. What is the finding which makes you arrive at the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Sequestrum

  • It is a complication (sequela) of Osteomyelitis.
  • The pathological process is as follows:
  • Infection in the bone leads to an increase in intramedullary pressure due to inflammatory exudates
  • The periosteum becomes stripped from the ostium, leading to vascular thrombosis
  • Bone necrosis follows due to a lack of blood supply
  • Sequestrum is formed
  • The sequestrum is surrounded by sclerotic bone, which is relatively avascular (without a blood supply).
  • Within the bone itself, the Haversian canals become blocked with scar tissue, and the bone becomes surrounded by thickened periosteum.

Option B: Cloacae
 

  • Cloacae are the perforations in the involucrum.
  • Pus and tiny spicules of bone may be discharged through them.

Option C: Involucrum
 

  • The involucrum is the dense new sclerotic bone surrounding the sequestrum.
  • It is formed from deep layers of stripped periosteum.

Option D: Brodie's abscess

  • It is due to subacute Osteomyelitis characterized by an intraosseous abscess; it commonly affects the distal femur and proximal tibia.
  • Sub-Acute Osteomyelitis> Chronic Osteomyelitis
  • Location: upper end of tibia
  • Lytic lesion with sclerotic margin
  • Seen in Immunocompetent host

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with a complaint of hip pain for the past 6 months. He also complains that hip pain is mild, and it does not radiate. On examination, no visible swelling is noted. The range of motion is limited. An X-ray of the hip is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Giant cell tumor

This patient’s radiographic findings often are diagnostic for the giant cell tumor.

The characteristic x-ray findings of giant cell tumors are:

  1. Eccentric
  2. Expansile
  3. Lobulated
  4. Lytic
  5. Metaphyseal
  6. NO matrix calcification of periosteal new bone formation

Option A: Giant cell tumor

  • A benign but locally aggressive tumor composed of giant cells that arise from the bone marrow
  • Peak incidence between 20 and 40 years
  • Clinical features:
  • Found in the epiphysis or metaphysis of long bones (especially the knee region)
  • Pathological fractures
  • Local pain and swelling
  • Limited range of motion
  • It is the only tumor to involve the joint.
  • Diagnostics :
  •  X-ray: multicystic osteolytic lesions (soap-bubble appearance)
  • Histopathology:
  • Mononuclear, RANKL-expressing cells (neoplastic)
  • Multinucleated giant cells (are reactive and resemble osteoclasts)
  • Treatment: curettage and bone grafting or en-bloc resection to minimize recurrence rate
  • Prognosis: risk of malignant degeneration increases with age; it may spread to the lungs

Option B: Simple Bone Cyst

  • Also known as unicameral Bone Cyst
  • Filled with straw-colored fluid
  • Radiological finding: Trapdoor sign and Fallen leaf sign (Fallen fragment sign)

Option C: Adamantinoma

  • The part affected: Diaphysis

Option D: Ewing's sarcoma

  • The part affected: Diaphysis
  • Origin: marrow cells (marrow biopsy useful to see the extent of the disease)

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with painful nodules on the distal interphalangeal joints of both hands. She reports difficulty with fine motor tasks and discomfort when gripping objects. She has no history of trauma to her hands. Radiographs reveal bony outgrowths consistent with Heberden's nodes. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C

  • Heberden's nodes are bony outgrowths that develop on the distal interphalangeal joints in patients with osteoarthritis. They can cause pain and difficulty with fine motor tasks, as well as discomfort when gripping objects. The most appropriate treatment for this patient is acetaminophen for pain relief.

Why Other Options are Incorrect

Option A. Surgical excision of the nodules: Not typically recommended, as it does not address the underlying arthritis and can lead to complications.

Option B. Intra-articular corticosteroid injection: May provide temporary pain relief, but are associated with a risk of joint infection and can exacerbate joint damage.

Option D. Colchicine therapy: Typically used for the treatment of gout, which is not the underlying cause of Heberden's nodes.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with left hip pain that worsens with activity and at night. She reports a history of steroid use for rheumatoid arthritis. On examination, she has limited range of motion and pain with internal rotation of the left hip. MRI shows bone marrow edema and subchondral collapse of the femoral head. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D

 

  • The clinical features and MRI findings in this patient are consistent with avascular necrosis of the femoral head. Given that the disease appears to be in its early stages, the most appropriate initial treatment is physical therapy and pain management. This approach may involve nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or other pain medications, as well as physical therapy to maintain range of motion and prevent muscle atrophy. If the disease progresses despite conservative management, surgical options such as core decompression or total hip replacement may be considered.

Why Others are Wrong

Option A) Total hip replacement is a more invasive surgical option that is usually reserved for more advanced cases of avascular necrosis where significant bone damage has occurred. This option is not appropriate for early-stage disease.

Option B) Core decompression is a minimally invasive surgical technique used to treat early-stage avascular necrosis. However, it is not typically the first-line treatment for the disease and may be reserved for cases that do not respond to conservative management.

Option C) Bisphosphonates are medications that can be used to slow the progression of avascular necrosis. However, they are typically used in conjunction with other treatments and are not the first-line therapy for the disease.

questions.text: A 5-month-old male infant is brought to the physician by his mother with complaints of failure to thrive, progressive muscular weakness, and poor head control. The mother states that she feeds the baby soy-based formula sweetened with honey. The baby is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient's current pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option A: Clostridium botulinum

  • This is a case of Floppy baby syndrome in which the patient presents with complaints of failure to thrive, poor head control and progressive muscular weakness.
  • It is caused due to C. botulinum.

Infant botulism/Floppy child syndrome

  • By ingesting contaminated food (usually honey) with spores of C. botulinum in children ≤ 1 year of age.
  • Spores germinate in the intestine, releasing the toxin.
  • Manifestations include:
    • Inability to suck and swallow.
    • Weakened voice.
    • Ptosis.
    • Floppy neck.
  • The botulinum toxin is the most potent toxin causing disease in humans.
  • Blocks the release of acetylcholine from motor nerve endings at the neuromuscular junctions leading to descending flaccid paralysis.
  • Other species that can cause botulism- are C. baratii, C. butyricum, and C. argentinense.

Other Options

Option B: Clostridium difficile

  • It causes pseudomembranous colitis, an advanced form of Clostridium difficile-associated disease (CDAD).

Option C: Clostridium perfringens

  • In clostridium perfringens, 13 major & minor toxins are present.
  • Toxins: Type A - E
  • Most infections are caused by Type A/α toxin.

Option D: Clostridium tetani

  • It produces the following toxins:
    • Tetanolysin
    • Tetanospasmin: presynaptic inhibition of glycine / GABA.

questions.text: The Obstetrician Mr. Malik, sees a pregnant patient who was exposed to rubella virus in the eighteenth week of pregnancy. She does not remember getting a rubella vaccination. Which of the following is not true about Rubella?

choices.text: Caused by DNA virus of Toga family
There is no known carrier state for postnatally acquired rubella
Rubella vaccine is live attenuated with strain RA 27/3
Risk of transmission and severity maximum in 1st trimester of pregnancy

questions.solution:
Rubella:

  • Rubella is caused by RNA virus of Toga family.
  • Source-only case. No carrier.
  • Infectivity period → 1 Week before ← RASH → 1 week after
  • Once infected provides life long immunity.

Clinical features:

  • FORCHHEIMER SPOTS are seen
  • BLUE BERRY MUFFIN RASH Seen over UVULA.

Congenital infection :- Risk of transmission and severity is maximum in 1st trimester of pregnancy. After 5th month, the risk is negligible.

Timing of fetal infection determines the extent of teratogenic effect in fetus:

1st two months
  • Abnormalities in 65-85% cases,
  • Multiple congenital defects (cataracts, deafness and heart defects)
  • Spontaneous abortion
3rd month of fetal life:
  • 30% to 35% chance of developing a single defect,
  • Deafness ,CHD.
During the 4th month
  • 10% risk for a single congenital defect
Beyond the 4th month
  • No risk to fetus

Congenital rubella :- classical triad -

  • C→ cataract
  • H → Heart Disease [PDA]
  • D → Deafness [sensorineural]

Vaccination:- RA27/3 live attenuated .

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient presents signs and symptoms suggestive of meningitis which has been resistant to antibiotics for his current illness for the last 02 weeks. His MRI brain is revealing ventriculomegaly and a brain abscess. Importantly, he has a pathognomic feature of fungal infection. Later he is suspected of having a fungal disease. His sample was sent for staining and further processing to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following is a correctly matched stain in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: India Ink-Cryptococcus

  • Based on signs and symptoms patient is suffering from cryptococcus neoformans, which stains India Ink.
  • Entry to the CNS is a vital step in cryptococcal pathogenesis. Various reports revealed that internalised and free cryptococci enter the blood-brain barrier to reach the brain, either by transcytosis through barrier epithelial cells or between them via the break of the tight junctions.
  • The best-studied virulence factor of C. neoformans is its polysaccharide capsule.

C. Neoformans capsule images:

  1. Top row: Negative stain with India ink; quick-freeze deep-etch electron micrograph of a portion of the cell wall with capsule fibres extending to the left); thin section electron micrograph of three cells.
  2. Bottom row: Immunoelectron micrograph of a portion of a cell (capsule fibres extending upwards) stained with gold-conjugated anti-capsule antibody; differential interference contrast micrograph of a budding cell; confocal immunofluorescence micrograph with the capsule stained blue and the cell wall stained green.

 

  • A modified technique employs 2% chromium mercury and India ink. This technique identifies some external and internal structures of the organism.

 

 

Option B: Lactophenol cotton blue– Candida

  • Candida is a commensal of the human body and an opportunistic pathogen frequently responsible for hospital-acquired bloodstream infections.
  • Candida cells can merge with bacteria within biofilms, especially through chemical or metabolic indirect interactions and direct physical contact involving the yeast or hyphal form of the fungal cells.
  • Lactophenol cotton blue is a mixture of methyl blue and lactophenol (a solution of phenol, lactic acid, and glycerol in water).

 

Option C: Methanamine silver – Aspergillus

  • The major species known to cause disease in humans are found in five Aspergillus species: 
    • Fumigation
    • Flavi
    • Nigri
    • Terrie
    • Nidulante
  • In humans, Aspergillus fumigatus is the mainstream and life-threatening airborne opportunistic fungal pathogen, which is particularly important among immunocompromised patients.
  • Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) with methenamine silver stain is commonly used to detect pneumocystis carinii and fungal organisms as causes of infectious pulmonic disease in immunosuppressed patients.

 

 

Option D: Gram’s stain– Pneumocystis carinii

  • Whether P carinii is a fungus or a protozoan is not yet established. Antigenic differences have been found in strains derived from the various mammalian hosts.
  • Tachypnea, dyspnea and cough, and fever—are the usual symptoms of Pneumocystis pneumonia.
  • In normal individuals, asymptomatic infection of the lungs occurs in early life. The organism remains inactive or latent unless the host becomes immunocompromised. Organisms add to the alveolar septal wall resulting in diffuse alveolitis and impaired oxygenation.
  • A Gram stain is a test that denotes bacteria at the site of a suspected infection, such as the throat, lungs, genitals, or in skin wounds. Gram stains may also identify bacteria in certain body fluids, such as blood or urine.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with a complaint of irregular fever with chills. He gives the history that he feels a fever spike every 3rd day. He also has a history of being diagnosed with malaria in the summer of 2 years back. The physical examination shows hepatosplenomegaly and pallor positive. On complete blood count examination, there is Hb 10.5 g/dL. This type of relapse is common with which type of plasmodium species?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer

Option C: Plasmodium vivax and ovale

  • The above-given case is malaria caused by the Plasmodium parasite, which is transmitted by the Anopheles mosquito.
  • It can be a life-threatening disease.
  • It causes anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and hepatosplenomegaly and shows inclusion bodies on a peripheral blood smear.
  • The symptoms include nausea, vomiting, and fever every 3rd day with chills.

Relapse:-

  • The resting forms are called Hypnozoites.
  • It is seen in P.vivax and P.ovale.
  • From time to time, some are activated to become schizonts and release merozoites, which go on infecting RBCs producing clinical relapse.

Recrudescence:-

  • However, small numbers of erythrocytic parasites persist in the bloodstream, and in due course of time, they multiply to reach significant numbers resulting in clinical disease.

Other Options

Option A: Plasmodium malariae and vivax

  • In Plasmodium malariae, the initial tissue phase disappears completely, and no Hypnozoites are found.
  • Plasmodium malariae causes quartan malaria.

Option B: Plasmodium falciparum and vivax

  • Hypnozoites are also absent in P. falciparum.
  • There is an irregular fever spike in P. falciparum.

Option D: Plasmodium ovale and malariae

  • There is a fever spike after 72 hours.
  • It is usually less severe.

questions.text: Which of the following microscopic findings is most likely to be observed in a clinical sample from a patient suspected of having a Candida infection?

choices.text: Septate hyphae with parallel walls and right-angle branching
Filamentous fungi with branching at acute angles and conidia

questions.solution:
Explanation: Option C: 

  • Microscopic examination of clinical samples is a common method for diagnosing Candida infections. In Candidiasis, budding yeast cells with pseudohyphae are the most characteristic finding. Other findings may include germ tubes, chlamydospores, and true hyphae.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • A) Septate hyphae with parallel walls and right-angle branching are characteristic findings in Aspergillosis.
  • B) Filamentous fungi with branching at acute angles and conidia are characteristic findings in Zygomycosis.
  • D) Gram-negative rods with peritrichous flagella are commonly seen in Escherichia coli.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms, commonly found in the excreta of certain avian species, is an obligate aerobe that can form both yeast and filamentous forms, and is characterized by the presence of a large polysaccharide capsule that can evade host defenses?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option C:

  • Cryptococcus neoformans is a capsulated yeast-like organism that can cause severe disease in immunocompromised individuals. It is commonly found in the excreta of certain avian species and can be transmitted to humans through inhalation of contaminated particles. It can form both yeast and filamentous forms, and its large polysaccharide capsule can evade host defenses, making it particularly virulent.

Why the other choices are incorrect:

  • A) Candida albicans is a yeast that is commonly found in the normal flora of humans and can cause opportunistic infections in immunocompromised individuals. It does not form a capsule and is not commonly associated with bird excreta.
  • B) Aspergillus fumigatus is a filamentous fungus that is ubiquitous in the environment and can cause severe respiratory infections in immunocompromised individuals. It is not associated with bird excreta and does not form a capsule.
  • D) Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus that can cause a respiratory infection called histoplasmosis. It is commonly found in soil contaminated with bat or bird droppings but is an obligate intracellular pathogen and not an obligate aerobe. It does form a capsule, but it is much smaller than the capsule of Cryptococcus neoformans.

questions.text: In microbiology, MacConkey Agar is a selective and differential media commonly used for the isolation and identification of enteric bacteria. Which of the following statements about MacConkey Agar is true?

choices.text: MacConkey Agar is a type of blood agar that is used to differentiate between different types of Streptococcus bacteria.
MacConkey Agar is a selective media that only allows for the growth of Gram-negative bacteria.
MacConkey Agar contains bile salts and crystal violet, which inhibit the growth of non-enteric bacteria.
MacConkey Agar can be used to identify Staphylococcus aureus based on the presence of coagulase.

questions.solution:
Explanation: Option B:

  • MacConkey Agar is a type of selective and differential media used for the isolation and differentiation of enteric bacteria, particularly Gram-negative bacteria such as Escherichia coli, Salmonella, and Shigella. The media contains bile salts and crystal violet, which inhibit the growth of Gram-positive bacteria, allowing for the selective growth of Gram-negative bacteria. Additionally, lactose and neutral red are added to the media, which allows for the differentiation of lactose-fermenting bacteria from non-lactose fermenters.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • A) is incorrect because MacConkey Agar is not a type of blood agar, and it is not used to differentiate between different types of Streptococcus bacteria.
  • C) is incorrect because MacConkey Agar does not contain crystal violet and bile salts to inhibit the growth of non-enteric bacteria, rather it is specifically designed to inhibit the growth of Gram-positive bacteria.
  • D) is incorrect because MacConkey Agar cannot be used to identify Staphylococcus aureus based on coagulase. Coagulase test is used for the identification of Staphylococcus aureus on blood agar, not on MacConkey Agar.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a history of HIV infection presents with complaints of cough and shortness of breath for the past two weeks. On physical examination, fine crepitations are heard in the lung fields. A chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The patient's CD4+ count is found to be < 200/mm3. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option A:

  • The patient's history of HIV infection, low CD4+ count, and clinical presentation of cough, shortness of breath, and diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest x-ray are all indicative of Pneumocystis Carinii pneumonia (PCP), a common opportunistic infection in patients with AIDS. Fine crepitations on physical examination may also be present due to the accumulation of fluid and inflammation in the lung tissue.

Why the other choices are incorrect:

  • B) Tuberculosis can also present with similar symptoms and infiltrates on chest x-ray, but the patient's low CD4+ count and history of HIV infection make PCP more likely.
  • C) Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a non-infectious condition characterized by respiratory failure and is less likely in this case given the patient's history of HIV and low CD4+ count.
  • D) Aspergillosis is another opportunistic infection that can affect patients with AIDS, but it typically presents with more localized lung lesions and cavitations, which are not seen in this case.

 

Note:

  • The fungus is transmitted through airborne droplets and primarily affects the lungs, causing pneumonia-like symptoms.

questions.text: What staining technique is used to visualize Nocardia nova?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option B: 

  • Nocardia nova is an acid fast bacteria, thus Ziehl-Neelsen staining can be used. This technique uses a strong dye called carbol fuchsin, which is retained by acid-fast bacteria due to their high lipid content. Counterstaining with methylene blue helps to visualize the acid-fast bacteria against a blue background.

Why are other options incorrect

  • A) Gram staining is used to differentiate bacteria based on the structure of their cell walls. It is not used to visualize acid-fast bacteria.
  • C) Wright staining is a type of Romanowsky staining, used to visualize blood cells and microorganisms in blood smears. It is not used to visualize acid-fast bacteria.
  • D) Giemsa staining is another type of Romanowsky staining, used to visualize blood cells, malaria parasites, and certain bacteria. It is not used to visualize acid-fast bacteria.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a fever of 103°F, nausea, vomiting, and a diffuse erythematous rash. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg and her heart rate is 120 beats per minute. She reports having used a menstrual cup for the first time during her last menstrual period. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's illness?
questions.solution:
Explanation

  • This patient's presentation is consistent with Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS), which is most commonly caused by toxin-producing strains of Staphylococcus aureus. Risk factors for TSS include recent surgery, burns, childbirth, and tampon use. In this case, the use of a menstrual cup may have introduced S. aureus into the vagina, where it was able to produce toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), leading to the patient's symptoms.

Why the other choices are incorrect:

  • A) Streptococcus pyogenes is not a common cause of TSS, although it can cause other types of invasive infections.
  • B) Escherichia coli is not a common cause of TSS and is more commonly associated with urinary tract infections and sepsis.
  • D) Klebsiella pneumoniae is not a common cause of TSS and is more commonly associated with hospital-acquired pneumonia and urinary tract infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for adjuvant chemotherapy after mastectomy?

choices.text: Presence of malignant cells in biopsy
There is no indication for adjuvant chemotherapy

questions.solution:
Option B: Size > 1cm & lymph node positive

  • Chemotherapy given after mastectomy is called adjuvant Chemotherapy.
  • Not all patients with breast cancer need Chemotherapy, but several factors play a role in deciding Chemotherapy.
  • Indications of Adjuvant therapy:
    • Size > 1cm
    • Lymph node positive
    • Size > 0.5cm and lymph node negative with adverse prognostic factor
  • Adverse prognostic factors are
    • High histological grade
    • Lymphovascular
    • HER-2-NEU positive.

Option A: Presence of malignant cells in biopsy

  • The presence of malignant cells in biopsy is indicative of neoplasm.
  • It gives no clue whether the patient will benefit from adjuvant Chemotherapy.

Option C: Family history of breast cancer

  • Multiple family members with a history of breast cancer indicate familial breast cancer.

Option D: Adjuvant Chemotherapy is not advisable for this patient

  • Adjuvant Chemotherapy is indicated in patients with positive lymph nodes post-surgery.
  • It is also indicated in patients who are at high risk for recurrence.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female comes to the outpatient department with complaints of redness, warmth, and a progressive increase in the size of her right breast for the last 4 weeks. After thorough investigations, the diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma with metastases is established. Further testing reveals estrogen and progesterone receptor positivity as well as HER-2-neu negativity. The patient has been prescribed a recently approved drug as the initial treatment. Which of the following drugs was most likely given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Palbociclib

  • This postmenopausal patient who has been diagnosed with metastatic ductal carcinoma, with estrogen and progesterone receptor-positive and HER-2 receptor-negative status, was most likely prescribed Palbociclib as the initial treatment.
  • Palbociclib is a third-generation non-steroidal aromatase inhibitor that has recently been approved for adjuvant treatment of metastatic hormone receptor (estrogen and progesterone) positive and HER-2 negative breast cancer.
  • The endocrine therapy for estrogen receptor (ER) positive and HER-2 negative breast cancer in postmenopausal females includes aromatase inhibitors.
  • The aromatase inhibitors can be non-steroidal (anastrozole and letrozole) or steroidal (exemestane).
  • Palbociclib has recently been approved as adjuvant therapy in combination with letrozole because the combination has better outcomes than letrozole alone.
  • Palbociclib works by inhibiting cyclin-dependent kinase 4/6 (CDK4/CDK6).
  • Activation of the CDK4/CDK6 signaling pathway is associated with mediating endocrine resistance. Blockage of these pathways by Palbociclib results in a better prognosis.
  • Other examples of this class of drugs include Ribociclib and Abemaciclib.
  • These drugs are used along with fulvestrant (selective estrogen-receptor down regulator).

Option B: Ipatasertib

  • Ipatasertib is an AKT (Protein kinase B) inhibitor, a key component of the PI3K/AKT pathway.
  • It can be used for the treatment of metastatic triple-negative breast cancer.

Option C: Herceptin

  • Herceptin/Trastuzumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody directed against the extracellular component of the HER-2 receptor.
  • It is used for the treatment of HER-2-neu-positive breast cancer.

Option D: Buparlisib

  • Buparlisib is a Phosphatidyl-inositol 3 kinase (PI3k) inhibitor that is still in trial stages for the treatment of metastatic breast cancer.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the emergency department complaining of excessive drowsiness and decreased oral intake for the past 3 days, along with difficulty getting up from the squatting position, combing her hair, and dressing. She complained of weight gain in the last few months, increased sensitivity to cold, skin dryness, hair loss, hoarseness of voice, and easy fatigability. She also had no family history or any major illnesses. On physical examination, periorbital puffiness and dry, coarse skin were noted. No tremors or fasciculations were elicited. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hypothyroidism

  • These symptoms are suggestive of hypothyroidism. A deficiency in circulating levels of thyroid hormone leads to hypothyroidism.
  • Hypothyroidism signs and symptoms may include:
    • Easy fatigability
    • Increased sensitivity to cold (cold intolerance)
    • Constipation
    • Dry skin ( due to reduced conversion of carotene to vitamin A)
    • Weight gain
    • Patients with severe hypothyroidism or myxedema develop characteristic facial features due to the deposition of glycosaminoglycans in the subcutaneous tissues, leading to facial and periorbital puffiness.
    • Hoarseness of voice
    • Muscle weakness (thyroid myopathy), Muscle aches, tenderness, and stiffness
    • Elevated blood cholesterol level
    • Heavier than normal or irregular menstrual periods
    • Infertility
    • Thinning hair and loss of outer two-thirds of eyebrow
    • Enlarged thyroid gland (goiter)
    • Cardiovascular changes include bradycardia, cardiomegaly, pericardial effusion, reduced cardiac output and pulmonary effusion.
    • Hypothyroidism in children leads to cretinism and characteristic facies

Option B: Hyperthyroidism

  • Hyperthyroidism presents with weight loss despite increased appetite, heat intolerance, tremors, gastrointestinal symptoms (diarrhea), and warm moist palms. Such findings are not seen in this patient.

Option C: Anemia of unknown cause

  • A patient with anemia presents easy fatigability, excessive drowsiness, dry skin, and dry/damaged hair; however, patients with anemia do not show periorbital puffiness, cold intolerance, and hoarseness of voice. Such symptoms are suggestive of hypothyroidism.

Option D: Underlying malignancy

  • A patient with malignancy will present with weight loss, decreased appetite, and easy fatigability gradually progressively. However, periorbital puffiness, dry, coarse skin, weight gain, and cold intolerance are signs of hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presented with progressively increasing midline swelling for 2 months. On physical examination, there was a 3cm × 2cm × 2cm swelling on the right side of the neck, extending from the midline to the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid. On palpation, it was firm and mobile. She also had enlarged lymph nodes in levels II and III on the right side, measuring 1cm × 1cm each. Serum calcitonin was 100 times above normal. USG of the neck revealed the presence of two hypoechoic lesions in the right lobe of the thyroid with macrocalcifications. Which of the following is an incorrect statement regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: Both hematogenous and lymphatic spread are seen

questions.solution:
Option C: It is dependent on TSH

  • The diagnosis is medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC). MTC is TSH independent, so it does not take radioactive iodine (hence, radioactive iodine ablation is not effective for MTC)
  • Thyroid gland parafollicular 'C' cells are the source of medullary cancer. It is a calcitonin-secreting structure that originates from the ultimobranchial bodies and is situated at the superolateral region of the thyroid lobes. As a result, while calcium levels are normal, calcitonin levels are elevated in medullary thyroid cancer.
  • Most cases are sporadic; however, occasionally, it is part of the MEN 2A and MEN 2B syndrome, whereby the patients have a positive family history.

Sporadic

Familial
  • 80% of cases
  • 20% of cases

 
  • Associated with MEN/ Non-MEN
  • If associated with MEN, it is MEN 2A/2B
  • Seen in 6th decade
  • Young patients
  • Single
  • Multiple
  • Unilateral
  • Bilateral

→ The similarity between sporadic and familial MTC - Both have RET Proto-oncogene mutation

Option A: It arises from Parafollicular ‘C’ cells
