  • Medullary thyroid carcinoma arises from the parafollicular 'C' cells of the thyroid gland.

Option B: Both hematogenous and lymphatic spread is seen

  • It spreads by local invasion, hematogenous and lymphatic routes causing disease propagation; distant metastasis is most frequently seen in the liver, bone, and lungs.

Option D: Most cases are sporadic

  • Medullary thyroid cancers are mostly sporadic, as up to 80% of cases are sporadic and just 20% of cases are familial in origin. The sporadic cases arise in the sixth decade and most present as unilateral masses.

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of intrahepatic presinusoidal portal hypertension?
questions.solution:
Option D: Schistosomiasis

  • The most common cause of intrahepatic presinusoidal portal hypertension → Schistosomiasis.
  • Schistosomiasis:
    • The risk factor is swimming or bathing in contaminated freshwater.
    • It causes an enlargement of the liver and spleen. In the liver, it causes inflammation, Fibrosis, and Portal hypertension.
    • Snails are the intermediate hosts.
    • It can also cause pulmonary hypertension and bladder cancer.

Option A: Budd-Chiari syndrome

  • Budd-Chiari syndrome causes post-hepatic post-sinusoidal portal hypertension, so this option is wrong.

Option B: Veno occlusive disease

  • Veno occlusive disease causes intrahepatic post-sinusoidal portal hypertension.

Option C: Abdominal trauma

  • Abdominal trauma causes prehepatic presinusoidal portal hypertension, so this option is wrong.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with acute pancreatitis complaints of recurrent episodes of upper gastrointestinal bleeding and hemoglobin of 5.8 gm/dL, requiring transfusions of red cell units. Gastroscopy showed diffuse fundal gastric varices but no esophageal varices. A CT scan showed liquefactive necrosis of pancreatic parenchyma and splenomegaly with diffuse varices around the gastrosplenic and gastrohepatic ligament. Which of the following would be the appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Option A: Splenectomy

  • Acute pancreatitis causes splenic vein thrombosis and pseudo-aneurysm formation in the splenic artery.
  • This aneurysm causes splenomegaly.
  • Splenomegaly causes gastric varices, mainly along the greater curvature of the stomach and fundus.
  • Left-sided portal hypertension is also called SINISTRAL hypertension.
  • The treatment of choice is Splenectomy.

Option B: Portocaval shunt

  • The portocaval shunt is an abnormal vein connecting the blood supply from the intestine to the vein that returns blood to the heart, bypassing the liver called shunting.
  • In this clinical scenario, the patient has a problem with the spleen, so Splenectomy should be done.

Option C: Splenorenal shunt

  • This is the surgical process in which the splenic vein is detached from the portal vein and reattached to the left kidney vein, called the renal vein, to relieve pressure, causing a portal system shunt.

Option D: None of the above

  • Splenic vein thrombosis and pseudo-aneurysm formation in the splenic artery cause splenomegaly due to acute pancreatitis, so splenectomy should be done.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the hospital due to exertional dyspnea and abdominal discomfort with a positive history of alcohol abuse, peptic ulcer disease, and acute pancreatitis. On examination, the patient shows a distended abdomen with shifting dullness and ankle edema. His ascitic fluid is taken and shows the following laboratory values:

Albumin  2.5 g/dL

Neutrophils    204/μL

Lactate dehydrogenase  38 units/L

Glucose        83 mg/dL

Blood investigations show:

         Albumin    3.8 g/dL

         Potassium    3.2 mEq/L

         Sodium          130 mEq/L

        Glucose           120 mg/dL

Lactate dehydrogenase  100 units/L

Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Increased hydrostatic capillary pressure

  • This patient's SAAG (Serum ascites albumin gradient) of 1.3 g/dL (3.8-2.5) is consistent with portal hypertension, e.g., cirrhosis with increased hydrostatic pressure in hepatic capillary beds.
  • Ascitic fluid helps to rule out the cause of ascites.
  • The following colours and their cause are described below:
    • If Bloody: trauma, malignancy, TB (rarely)
    • If Milky: chylous
    • If Turbid: possible infection
    • If Straw colour: likely more benign causes
    • If neutrophils are ≥250/mm³, then peritonitis may be due to secondary or spontaneous bacteria.
    • If ascitic protein is more than 2.5 g/dL (high-protein ascites), the causes are CHF, constrictive pericarditis, peritoneal carcinomatosis, TB, Budd-Chiari syndrome, and fungal.
    • If the protein is less than 2.5 g/dL (low-protein ascites), the causes are cirrhosis and nephrotic syndrome.
    • If protein is more than 1.1 g/dL (indicates portal hypertension), the causes are Cardiac ascites, cirrhosis, and Budd-Chiari syndrome.
    • If the protein is <1.1 g/dL (absence of portal hypertension), the causes are TB, peritoneal carcinomatosis, pancreatic ascites, and nephrotic syndrome.

Option A: Decrease in liver function

  • Decreased liver function causes decreased serum albumin concentration and increased Prothrombin time.
  • Due to decreased proteins, edema occurs in end-stage liver disease, but this patient's normal serum albumin makes this option less likely.

Option C: Increased capillary permeability

  • Increased capillary permeability causes non-portal hypertension with SAAG less than 1.1g/dL, for example, malignant ascites.

Option D: Increase Glomerular filtration pressure

  • Increased glomerular filtration pressure usually increases the Glomerular filtration rate.
  • It does not cause ascites.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy came to your hospital with complaints of severe abdominal pain. On examination, several new bruises were all over the body. He gives a history of being bullied and punched in the abdomen multiple times forcefully by his classmate. His blood pressure is 140/100 mmHg, and his pulse rate is 102 per minute. The patient is afebrile. Which of the following should be the next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: CT scan of abdomen

  • This patient, with multiple new bruises on the abdomen due to multiple forceful punches, is a case of blunt abdominal injury.
  • Other causes of blunt abdominal trauma are bicycle injuries, injuries sustained during sports activities, or road traffic accidents.
  • It is the most commonly used and better investigation for abdominal trauma.
  • It is useful in blunt, penetrating trauma, pancreatic, spleen, liver, duodenal, and retroperitoneal injuries.
  • Smaller injuries and early haemoperitoneum are better detected.
  • It is noninvasive, highly specific, and highly accurate, with low false positive/ low false negative results. 

Option A: E-FAST

  • Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma (E-FAST)
  • It is an ultrasound type of investigation used if the patient is unstable (systolic BP less than 90 mmHg).
  • It is very useful in viewing the following areas: the right upper quadrant, perisplenic space in the left lower quadrant, pelvis, subcostal or cardiac view, and the parietal or visceral pleural movements.

Option B: Abdominal ultrasound

  • In blunt abdominal injury, the CT scan is the most sensitive and specific test than abdominal ultrasound.

Option D: Peritoneal lavage

  • Intraperitoneal lavage is performed if the patient is unstable (Systolic BP less than 90 mmHg) and the EFAST is not available.
  • Peritoneal lavage can be done when there is a high suspicion of intraperitoneal bleeding.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient who is a chronic smoker comes to the clinic complaining of tiredness and yellowing of skin for the past 1 month. CT scan reveals a carcinoma of the head of the pancreas. What is the median survival in carcinoma pancreas after surgery and adjuvant therapy?
questions.solution:
Option B: 22 months

  • Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas or in the tail does not have a good prognosis even after surgery and adjuvant therapy
  • The symptoms of carcinoma of the head of the pancreas are progressive, painless jaundice, and weight loss
  • The biggest risk factors are smoking and chronic pancreatitis
  • After surgical resection and adjuvant therapy for pancreatic cancer, the median survival is approximately 22 months, with a 5-year survival of 15% to 20%.
  • Most patients experience a relapse of the disease in the form of metastatic disease (85%) and, less commonly, local recurrence (40%).
  • In the absence of surgical resection, those with locally advanced disease who receive palliative chemotherapy may survive 10 to 12 months, whereas those with metastases rarely survive beyond 6 months

Option A: 12 months

  • In the absence of surgical resection and the patient is only on palliative treatment, the median survival time is 12 months

Option C: 32 months

  • The median survival time of carcinoma of the pancreas is 22 months as most patients, after even surgical resection, can have a relapse of the disease in the form of metastasis

Option D: 44 months

  • The median survival time of pancreatic cancer, even after surgical resection and adjuvant therapy, is  22 months

questions.text: A 32-year-old male came to your clinic with a complaint of headache with no other associated symptoms. On inspection of the patient, you see the following finding shown in the image and diagnose a genetic disease. What type of cancer would you expect the patient to have?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pancreatic cancer

  • This patient with hyperpigmented macules on his lips points towards a diagnosis of a genetic disease, the Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
  • Among the cancers given above, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome has a maximum risk of developing pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma
  • Pancreatic cancer
    • Pancreatic cancer is more common in older adults, with most patients being 75 to 84 years old. It is slightly more common in men than women.
    • Risk factors include family history, smoking, alcohol and coffee consumption, high fat diet, and low in fibre, fruits and vegetables, diabetes mellitus, chronic pancreatitis
    • About two-thirds of pancreatic adenocarcinomas arise within the head or uncinate process of the pancreas; 15% are in the body, and 10% are in the tail, with the remaining tumours demonstrating diffuse involvement of the gland
      • Ductal adenocarcinoma makes up 75% of nonendocrine cancers of the pancreas. Other less common types include adenosquamous carcinoma, acinic cell carcinoma
      • Genetics of pancreatic cancer
        • The K-Ras oncogene is currently thought to be the most commonly mutated gene in pancreatic cancer, with approximately 90% of tumours having a mutation. The Her2/neu oncogene is overexpressed in pancreatic cancer. Multiple tumour suppressor genes are deleted and mutated in pancreatic cancer, including p53, p16 and DPC 4 (Smad 4) and in a minority of cases, BRCA 2
        • Rare familial cancer syndromes that are associated with an increased risk of pancreatic cancer include BRCA2, the familial atypical multiple mole melanoma syndrome, hereditary pancreatitis, familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer, Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and ataxia-telangiectasia

Option B: Ganglioma

  • Ganglioma are associated with Multiple endocrine neoplasias 2B (MEN 2B), which consist of Gangliomas, Pheochromocytomas, and medullary thyroid carcinoma

Option C: Testicular cancer

  • Testicular cancer risk can increase in Klinefelter syndrome

Option D: Esophageal cancer

  • Esophageal cancer risk is not increased with Peutz-jeghers syndrome. It is increased by smoking, Barrett's esophagus, acid reflux, and alcohol.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male presents with dysphagia, vomiting, and pallor. Diagnosed with Stage III gastric carcinoma involving the body of the stomach extending into the cardia. which of the following is False about gastric carcinoma?

choices.text: More in the low socioeconomic group
H. pylori infection increases the risks
Vitamin C has a protective effect

questions.solution:
Option B: More common in young females

  • This patient is suffering from stage III gastric carcinoma in the body of the stomach extending into cardia. It is more common in older men rather than young females.

Option A: More in the low socioeconomic group

  • Stage III gastric carcinoma is more common in the low socioeconomic group due to low food quality or a higher risk of infections.

Option C: H. pylori infection increases the risks

  • H. pylori infection increases the risks of stage III gastric carcinoma.
  • Other diseases which increase the risk of gastric carcinoma include:
  • Epstein-Barr virus
  • Gastric atrophy and gastritis
  • Adenomatous polyps

Option D: Vitamin C has a protective effect

  • Vitamin C has a protective effect against stage III gastric carcinoma.
  • The following substances also decrease the risk:
  • Aspirin
  • High fresh fruit and vegetable intake

questions.text: A 53-year-old male comes to the outpatient department complaining of dysphagia and hematemesis. Dysphagia affects more solids than liquids. An endoscopic evaluation reveals a mass lesion in the gastroesophageal junction. Which of the following options is most likely associated with tumorsof the gastroesophageal junction?
questions.solution:
Option B: Siewert type II

  • Siewert classification is a system of anatomical classification used for adenocarcinoma of the esophagogastric junction.
  • In type Siewert type II, Adenocarcinoma is present in the real cardia.
  • Its exact location is 1 cm above and 2 cm below the gastroesophageal junction.

Option A: Siewert type I

  • In Siewert type I, adenocarcinoma is present in the distal esophagus.
  • It is 1-5 cm above the gastroesophageal (GE) junction.

Option C: Siewert type III

  • In Siewert type III, Adenocarcinoma is present in the Sub-Cardinal Stomach.
  • Its location is 2-5 cm below the gastroesophageal (GE) junction.

Option D: Siewert type IV

  • This classification has only three types.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to a gastrointestinal surgeon complaining of pain in the lower back, abdomen, and flanks. The pain is described as dull, poorly localized, not affected by posture or position, aggravated at night while asleep, radiates to the inguinal region, and is associated with fever, anorexia, and vomiting. He mentions pain is well controlled by Toradol injection. He also complains of new-onset painful micturition and urinary urgency associated with more frequent but decreased urine output. The physical examination reveals a BP measurement of 150/90 mmHg and bilateral lower extremities edema. An ultrasound KUB reveals bilateral hydronephrosis, bilateral encasement of renal vessels, and peri-IVC fibrotic tissue. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis without contrast reveals retroperitoneal fibrosis around IVC.  All of the following statements best describes this condition except?

choices.text: The ureter is most commonly involved
Primary idiopathic form is called Ormond’s disease
Corticosteroids are used in the management

questions.solution:
Option B: More common in females

  • The given scenario is a classic case of Retroperitoneal fibrosis (RPS).
  • RPF is a very rare disease, and the incidence is 0.1 to 1.3 cases per 100,000 persons per year.
    • The idiopathic (primary) disease is more prevalent in individuals 40-60.
    • The male-to-female predominance of RPF is 2:1 to 3:1, relatively more common in males, which is attributed to its association with exposure to asbestos and tobacco smoke - resulting in a fourfold increase in the risk.

 

Option A: The ureter is most commonly involved

  • The fibrotic tissue in RPF is localized around the infrarenal portion of the abdominal aorta and iliac arteries. Additionally, ureters are almost always involved hence resulting in hydronephrosis.
    • Owing to the consistent involvement of ureters in almost all cases, the disease has also been called periureteritis fibrosa, periureteritis plastica, or chronic periureteritis.

 

Option C:  Primary idiopathic form is called Ormond’s disease

  • The primary/idiopathic form of retroperitoneal fibrosis may or may not be IgG4-related and is also termed Ormond’s disease.

 

Option D: Corticosteroids are used in the management

  • High-dose glucocorticoids are the mainstay of therapy for idiopathic RPF.
    • The usual dose is 1mg/kg/day (maximum of 80mg per day).
    • For patients having relative contraindications to glucocorticoids, a lower dose (up to 25mg per day) of glucocorticoids is used for a shorter duration in combination with other immunosuppressive medications.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common electrolyte imbalance that causes paralytic ileus?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hypokalemia

  • Paralytic ileus is associated with hypokalemia.
  • Paralytic ileus: 
    • This may be defined as a state in which there is the failure of transmission of peristaltic waves secondary to neuromuscular failure (i.e., in the myenteric (Auerbach's) and submucous (Meissner's) plexuses).  
    • The resultant stasis leads to the accumulation of fluid and gas within the bowel, with associated distension, vomiting, absence of bowel sounds, and absolute constipation. 
    • ​​​​​​​Clinical features:
      • Paralytic ileus takes on a clinical significance if, 72 hours after laparotomy: There has been no return of bowel sounds on auscultation; There has been no passage of flatus.  
      • Abdominal distension becomes more marked and tympanitic.  
      • Colicky pain is not a feature.  
      • Distension increases pain from the abdominal wound.  
      • In the absence of gastric aspiration, effortless vomiting may occur.  
      • Radiologically, the abdomen shows gas-filled loops of the intestine with multiple fluid levels (if an erect film is felt necessary).

Option A: Hyponatremia

  • Hyponatremia is associated with neurologic symptoms.
  • It does not cause ileus.

Option B: Hypernatremia

  • Hypernatremia usually presents with neurologic symptoms.
  • Ileus is not seen in hypernatremia.

Option D: Hyperkalemia

  • Hyperkalemia leads to life-threatening arrhythmias.
  • Ileus is not seen

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman underwent a mastectomy for breast cancer, followed by axillary lymph node dissection. One week after surgery, she developed a high-grade fever and hypotension. On examination, she has erythema and warmth around the surgical site and palpable crepitus under the skin. A CT scan shows extensive gas formation in the soft tissues of the chest wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option C

  • Necrotizing fasciitis is a rare but serious complication of breast surgery that can rapidly progress to sepsis and death. It is characterized by severe pain, erythema, and crepitus in the affected area, along with fever and hypotension. Gas formation in the soft tissues is a hallmark of the disease and can be seen on imaging studies. Necrotizing fasciitis requires prompt surgical intervention and intravenous antibiotics.

Why other options are incorrect:

A) Wound dehiscence

  • Wound dehiscence is a separation of the surgical incision, which can occur after breast surgery. However, it typically presents as a wound that has opened up, rather than erythema and crepitus under the skin. Additionally, wound dehiscence is not associated with systemic symptoms such as fever and hypotension.

B) Seroma formation

  • Seroma formation is a common complication after breast surgery, but it typically presents as a painless swelling or fluid collection under the skin near the incision site. It is unlikely to cause fever, hypotension, or gas formation in the soft tissues, so this option is incorrect.

D) Fat necrosis

  • Fat necrosis is a benign complication of breast surgery that can present as a palpable lump or area of firmness under the skin. It is not typically associated with fever, hypotension, or gas formation in the soft tissues, so this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a painless, rapidly growing lump in her left breast that has been present for the last 3 months. On examination, a well-defined, mobile, and firm lump measuring 5 cm is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There are no palpable axillary lymph nodes. A core needle biopsy of the lump shows the presence of stromal and epithelial components with leaf-like projections. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what would be the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Ductal carcinoma in situ, lumpectomy and radiation therapy
Invasive ductal carcinoma, mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection
Phyllodes tumor, wide local excision and close follow-up

questions.solution:
Explanation: Option D

  • The clinical features of a painless, rapidly growing lump with well-defined borders and leaf-like projections on core needle biopsy are suggestive of Phyllodes tumor. The most appropriate management for a Phyllodes tumor is wide local excision with clear margins. Close follow-up is necessary as these tumors have a high risk of local recurrence. Therefore, option D is the correct answer.

Why Others are Wrong:

Option A) Fibroadenoma presents as a painless, rubbery, and mobile lump in the breast. Observation and follow-up are appropriate for fibroadenomas, but the clinical features and biopsy findings of this patient suggest a Phyllodes tumor. Therefore, option A is incorrect.

Option B) Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) presents as a non-palpable lesion detected on mammography or ultrasound. Lumpectomy and radiation therapy are the standard treatments for DCIS, but the clinical features and biopsy findings of this patient suggest a Phyllodes tumor. Therefore, option B is incorrect.

Option C) Invasive ductal carcinoma presents as a hard, irregularly shaped, and fixed lump in the breast. Mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection are the standard treatments for invasive ductal carcinoma, but the clinical features and biopsy findings of this patient suggest a Phyllodes tumor. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with a persistent, itchy rash on her left nipple for the past 6 months. She reports occasional discharge from the nipple, and a palpable lump is noted on examination. Mammography shows a spiculated mass in the left breast, and a biopsy confirms the presence of malignant cells in the nipple-areola complex. Immunohistochemical staining reveals that the cancer cells are positive for keratin and negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Breast-conserving surgery followed by radiation therapy
Mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection

questions.solution:
Explanation: Option C

  • The clinical presentation described in this question is consistent with Paget's disease of the breast, a rare form of breast cancer that affects the skin and nipple. Mammography and biopsy are essential for diagnosis. In this case, the immunohistochemical staining indicates that the cancer cells are negative for estrogen and progesterone receptors, which are often targeted with hormonal therapy. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is systemic chemotherapy, which is typically used for cancers that are negative for hormone receptors.

Why other options are incorrect:

A) Breast-conserving surgery followed by radiation therapy

  • Breast-conserving surgery is not recommended for Paget's disease of the breast, as the disease often involves the entire nipple-areola complex and may be associated with an underlying invasive cancer. Radiation therapy alone is not sufficient to treat Paget's disease of the breast, as it does not address the underlying cancer.

B) Mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection

  • Mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection is the standard treatment for Paget's disease of the breast. However, the question does not explicitly state that the diagnosis is Paget's disease, so it may not be the correct answer without further information.

D) Hormonal therapy

  • Hormonal therapy is typically reserved for hormone receptor-positive breast cancers, which are not present in this case. It is not indicated as the first-line treatment for Paget's disease of the breast in general, but in this case, the diagnosis is not explicitly stated, so the relevance of hormonal therapy cannot be determined without further information

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient with a history of diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents with a stage IV pressure ulcer on his sacrum. The wound measures 5 cm x 5 cm and is characterized by a full-thickness skin loss with exposed bone, tendon and muscle. There is no evidence of infection. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?

choices.text: Topical antimicrobial agents and conservative wound care
Surgical debridement and negative pressure wound therapy

questions.solution:
Explanation: Option B

  • In a stage IV pressure ulcer, full-thickness skin loss occurs, and the ulcer extends to the muscle or bone. The goal of treatment is to promote healing, prevent infection, and relieve pain. Surgical debridement involves the removal of necrotic or devitalized tissue and is a crucial step in the management of pressure ulcers. Negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) uses a vacuum dressing to promote healing and has been shown to be effective in treating pressure ulcers. It creates a negative pressure environment, which promotes wound healing by increasing blood flow, reducing edema, and removing excess fluid and bacteria. Therefore, surgical debridement and NPWT are the most appropriate management strategies for this patient.

Why Others are Wrong:

Option A) Topical antimicrobial agents and conservative wound care are not effective in the management of stage IV pressure ulcers. They may be used as an adjunct to surgical debridement and NPWT, but they cannot be used as a standalone treatment.

Option C) Hyperbaric oxygen therapy may be used in the management of some types of wounds, including pressure ulcers, but it is not the first-line treatment for a stage IV pressure ulcer. It may be considered as an adjunct therapy, but it is not the most appropriate treatment for this patient.

Option D) Skin grafting may be considered in the management of a stage IV pressure ulcer, but it is not the first-line treatment. Skin grafting may be considered after surgical debridement and NPWT have been used to promote healing and reduce the size of the ulcer. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of hypocalcemia in a patient who presents with fatigue, muscle cramps, and tingling sensations in hands and feet, four days after undergoing total parathyroidectomy for primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option B

Hungry bone syndrome is a complication that occurs after parathyroidectomy in patients with primary or secondary hyperparathyroidism. In this condition, there is a rapid uptake of calcium by bones, leading to hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia is usually severe and can last for several days to weeks. The clinical features of fatigue, muscle cramps, and tingling sensations in the hands and feet are suggestive of hypocalcemia. Therefore, option B is the correct answer.

Why Others are Wrong:

Option A) Hypoparathyroidism can also cause hypocalcemia, but the patient's history of primary hyperparathyroidism and recent parathyroidectomy suggest hungry bone syndrome as the more likely diagnosis. Therefore, option A is incorrect.

Option C) Vitamin D deficiency can cause hypocalcemia, but it is not the cause of hypocalcemia seen in hungry bone syndrome. Therefore, option C is incorrect.

Option D) Acute kidney injury can cause hyperkalemia, not hypocalcemia. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of sudden onset of severe pain and redness in his right eye. He also reports decreased vision in the affected eye. On examination, the right eye appears injected with conjunctival injection and ciliary flush. The cornea shows a hazy appearance with the presence of a small, central, white, and elevated lesion. The anterior chamber is shallow, and the pupil is semi-dilated and non-reactive. The intraocular pressure (IOP) in the affected eye is 50 mm Hg. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what would be the most appropriate diagnostic test and treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Acute angle-closure glaucoma, gonioscopy, and timolol eye drops
Corneal ulcer, fluorescein staining, and topical antibiotics
Central retinal artery occlusion, fundoscopy, and intravenous thrombolysis
Uveitis, slit-lamp examination, and oral prednisolone

questions.solution:
Explanation: Option A

  • The patient presents with a sudden onset of severe pain and redness in the right eye with decreased vision. The presence of a small, central, white, and elevated lesion in the cornea with a shallow anterior chamber, non-reactive pupil, and high IOP is suggestive of acute angle-closure glaucoma. Gonioscopy is the most appropriate diagnostic test, which can confirm the diagnosis by revealing a closed angle. The initial treatment for acute angle-closure glaucoma is to lower the IOP. Timolol eye drops are used to decrease the IOP by reducing the production of aqueous humor. Therefore, option A is the correct answer.

Why Others are Wrong:

Option B) Corneal ulcer is characterized by a painful, red eye with blurred vision and a white spot on the cornea. Fluorescein staining is used to diagnose corneal ulcer, which shows a yellow-green stain at the site of the ulcer. Topical antibiotics are used to treat corneal ulcers, but they are not the appropriate treatment for acute angle-closure glaucoma.

Option C) Central retinal artery occlusion presents with sudden, painless, and severe vision loss in one eye. Fundoscopy shows a pale retina with a cherry-red spot. Intravenous thrombolysis is used to treat central retinal artery occlusion, but it is not the appropriate treatment for acute angle-closure glaucoma.

Option D) Uveitis is characterized by a painful, red eye with photophobia and decreased vision. Slit-lamp examination is used to diagnose uveitis, which shows cells and flare in the anterior chamber. Oral prednisolone is used to treat uveitis, but it is not the appropriate treatment for acute angle-closure glaucoma

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of breast cancer presents with a suspicious lesion on her chest wall. A biopsy confirms the presence of recurrent breast cancer. The patient is scheduled for a sentinel lymph node biopsy. She has no known allergies, and her past medical history is unremarkable. What is the most common complication associated with sentinel lymph node biopsy in this patient, and what is the appropriate management of this complication?
questions.solution:
Explanation: Option C

  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy is a minimally invasive procedure used to identify the first lymph node that receives drainage from a tumor site, in order to determine the extent of cancer spread. The most common complication associated with sentinel lymph node biopsy is seroma formation, which occurs in up to 20-30% of cases. Seroma is the accumulation of fluid in the tissue space where the lymph node was removed. The clinical features of seroma include a palpable mass, swelling, and discomfort in the affected area. The appropriate management of seroma involves aspiration of the fluid and the application of a compression dressing to prevent re-accumulation of fluid. Therefore, option C is the correct answer.

Why Others are Wrong:

Option A) Lymphedema is a potential complication of axillary lymph node dissection, but it is not a common complication of sentinel lymph node biopsy. Therefore, option A is incorrect.

Option B) Hematoma can occur after any surgical procedure, but it is not the most common complication of sentinel lymph node biopsy. Observation and conservative management are appropriate if the hematoma is small and does not cause significant symptoms. However, if the hematoma is large or causing significant symptoms, it may require surgical intervention. Therefore, option B is incorrect.

Option D) Infection is a potential complication of any surgical procedure, but it is not the most common complication of sentinel lymph node biopsy. If an infection does occur, appropriate management involves antibiotics and wound care. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy comes to the emergency room complaining of chest pain, palpitations and shortness of breath. ECG shows P wave is tall in lead II and upright in V1 along with right axis deviation. Based on the information provided, what appropriate auscultatory findings will be noted?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above:

  • The first heart sound (S1 ) is usually accentuated in the early stages of the disease and slightly delayed.
  • The pulmonic component of the second heart sound (P2 ) also is often accentuated with elevated PAPs, and the two components of the second heart sound (S2 ) are closely split.
  • The mitral valve's opening snap (OS) is most readily audible in expiration at, or just medial to, the cardiac apex.
  • This sound generally follows the sound of aortic valve closure (A2 ) by 0.05–0.12 s.
  • The time interval between A2 and OS varies inversely with the severity of the MS.
  • The OS is followed by a low-pitched, rumbling, diastolic murmur, heard best at the apex with the patient in the left lateral recumbent position; it is accentuated by mild exercise (e.g., a few rapid sit-ups) carried out just before auscultation.
  • In general, this murmur's duration correlates with the stenosis's severity in patients with preserved CO.
  • The S1 sound is initially narrow split and then heard as a single sound which then progresses to reverse splitting.
  • In patients with sinus rhythm, the murmur often reappears or becomes louder during atrial systole (presystolic accentuation).
  • Soft, grade I or II/VI systolic murmurs may be heard at or medial to the apex and signify mixed mitral valve disease with regurgitation.
  • Hepatomegaly, ankle oedema, ascites, and pleural effusion may occur in patients with MS and RV failure, particularly in the right pleural cavity.

Option A: Narrow split S1

  • In the initial stages of the disease, there is a narrow splitting of S1.

Option B: Single S1

  • In moderate cases, S1 becomes single.

Option C: Reverse split S1

  • In severe MS, there is often the reverse splitting of S1.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with loss of consciousness 20 minutes ago. He regains consciousness in the ER, and GCS on admission is 12/15. CNS examination is normal, and auscultation reveals a narrow split S2 and clear lungs. ECG is shown below:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Subarachnoid hemorrhage with T wave inversion

questions.solution:
Option A: Left outflow tract obstruction

  • The ECG shows a heart rate of 60/min with a left axis deviation
  • SV1+RV5> 35 mm is suggestive of left ventricular hypertrophy (SV1 = 20mm and RV5= 30mm)
  • Narrow split S2 indicates outflow tract obstruction
  • Considering the age, the patient either suffers from HOCM or valvular aortic stenosis. Low cardiac output can lead to exertional syncope.

Option B: Right outflow tract obstruction

  • Right outflow tract obstruction will lead to RVH → R wave more than 7mm in V1 (R ≥ S wave), usually with right axis deviation

Option C: Atrial fibrillation with cerebral embolism

  • Atrial Fibrillation is characterized by Irregularly irregular heart rate, Absent P waves (replaced by fibrillating f wave), Baseline vibration

Option D: Subarachnoid haemorrhage with T wave inversion

  • T wave inversion in the anterior lead can be due to:
    1. Subarachnoid haemorrhage
    2. Pericarditis
    3. Pulmonary embolism
    4. Electrolyte abnormalities
    5. HOCM
    6. Pancreatitis
    7. Takotsubo CM

questions.text: A 20-year-old man was brought to the emergency department unconscious from a party. The patient attender informed the physician that before fainting, the patient complained of chest pain, racing heart feeling and shortness of breath. On examination, the pulse was very fast, blood pressure was 76/50 mm Hg, and ECG recording showed absent P waves and irregular QRS complexes. TTE revealed clots in the left atrium. On managing, which of the following should  be done?

choices.text: Diltiazem to reduce the heart rate
Open mitral commissurotomy and removal of the clot

questions.solution:
Option D: Cardioversion with percutaneous balloon valvotomy

Atrial fibrillation

  • The major source of thromboembolism and stroke in atrial fibrillation is the formation of a thrombus in the left atrial appendage, where flow is relatively stagnant.
  • Thromboembolism can occur soon or several days after restoration of sinus rhythm if appropriate anticoagulation measures are not taken.
  • Cardioversion within 48 hours of the onset of atrial fibrillation is common practice in patients who have not been anticoagulated, provided that they are not at high risk for stroke due to a prior history of embolic events, rheumatic mitral stenosis or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with marked left atrial enlargement.
  • If the duration of atrial fibrillation exceeds 48 hours or is unknown, there is a greater concern for thromboembolism after cardioversion, even in patients with a low risk for stroke.
  • There are two approaches to mitigate the risk: One is to anticoagulate continuously for 3 weeks before and a minimum of 4 weeks after cardioversion. The second is to start anticoagulation and perform a transesophageal echocardiogram to determine if a thrombus is present in the left atrial appendage. If a thrombus is absent, cardioversion can be performed, and anticoagulation continued for a minimum of 4 weeks to allow time for recovery.
  • If cardioversion is done in this setting, the normal sinus rhythm ensues, and the proper contraction of the atria may result in the dislodgement of clots from the atria. The PMV procedure dilates the mitral annulus, relieves the annulus and the chances of clots embolising via a bigger orifice increase.

Option A: Diltiazem to reduce the heart rate

  • Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker used to reduce heart rate in atrial flutter, SVT and atrial fibrillation.

Option B: Warfarin therapy

  • Warfarin therapy is used for the treatment of atrial flutter

Option C: Open mitral commissurotomy and removal of the clot

  • Open mitral commissurotomy and clot removal are done in atrial flutter

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother who noticed his lips turning blue whenever he cries or gets sick. She says that the squatting position relieves the bluish discoloration. Examination revealed a harsh holosystolic murmur at the left parasternal area. His complete blood count shows a hemoglobin 18 g%. What is the underlying defect?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option B: Cyanotic heart disease

  • This patient with cyanosis and a harsh holosystolic murmur of ventricular septal defect is most likely suffering from Tetralogy of Fallot.
  • In Tetralogy of Fallot, the affected child suddenly becomes increasingly cyanosed after feeding or a crying attack and may become apneic and unconscious. These attacks are called Tet spells.
  • Some children characteristically obtain relief by squatting after exertion (this increases the afterload to the left heart and decreases the right to left shunting).
  • In older children, Tet spells are uncommon, but cyanosis becomes increasingly apparent, with stunting of growth, digital clubbing, and polycythemia.

OTHER OPTIONS

Option A: Acyanotic heart disease

  • Acyanotic heart disease is an abnormality of the heart that interferes with blood flow normally, A hole in the heart's wall is one illustration.
  • As the name indicates, the patient has no episodes of cyanosis in these conditions.
  • Although the disease is present at birth, symptoms or issues may not appear until much later in life.
  • Sometimes the issue resolves itself when a child is still young.

Option C: Eisenmenger syndrome

  • Eisenmenger syndrome is caused by uncorrected left to right shunting, leading to pulmonary arterial hypertension and right ventricular hypertrophy. It raises blood pressure on the heart's side which receives less oxygen-rich blood (blue blood).
  • As a result, oxygen-rich blood and blood with low oxygen content might mix due to a hole (shunt) in the heart or blood arteries.

Option D: Lutembacher syndrome

  • Congenital atrial septal defect (ASD) exacerbated with acquired mitral stenosis is known as Lutembacher's syndrome.
  • It is an acyanotic heart disease and does not present with “squatting attacks.”

questions.text: A 65-year-old male comes to the clinic for an annual visit. He has had no significant complaints recently. His medical history is significant for a myocardial infarction one year back, for which he had to undergo stenting. He takes metoprolol, aspirin, and clopidogrel at home. His blood pressure is 150/98 mm Hg. He had a high blood pressure reading at his dentist appointment last week as well. It is decided that another antihypertensive medication should be added to his current regimen. Which of the following drugs is best suited for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Lisinopril

  • Lisinopril comes under the class of drugs known as ACE inhibitors (ACEIs.)
  • In hypertension with Concomitant heart disease, ACEIs attenuate the development of left ventricular hypertrophy(ventricular remodelling, ) improve symptoms and risk of death from C.H.F, and reduce morbidity and mortality rates in post-myocardial infarction patients.
  • Similar benefits in cardiovascular morbidity and mortality rates in patients with C.H.F have been observed with the use of ARBs.

Option A: Clonidine

  • The drug clonidine belongs to the group of drugs known as centrally acting alpha-agonist hypotensive agents. By lowering heart rate and relaxing blood vessels, clonidine lowers blood pressure and improves blood flow throughout the body.
  • Clonidine is a second-line antihypertensive and is not known to provide any cardiovascular benefits.

Option B: Thiazide

  • Thiazide diuretics prevent the reabsorption of sodium and water by blocking sodium and chloride (Na/Cl) channels in the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron.
  • Although being the first-line drug for managing hypertension, it does not prevent ventricular remodelling, due to which ACEIs are a better choice in this case.

Option C: Amlodipine

  • Amlodipine is a calcium channel blocker that can be used as the first antihypertensive medication.
  • ACEIs provide better coronary protection than calcium channel blockers, whereas calcium channel blockers provide more stroke protection than ACEI or beta blockers.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a history of progressive shortness of breath and dry cough for 2 weeks. He reports mild substernal chest pain. His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient smokes 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 12 years. On examination, he is afebrile, his blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg, his pulse is 74 beats/min, and his respiratory rate is 16 breaths/min. On chest auscultation, fine basal crackles are heard bilaterally. Heart sounds are normal. Lower limbs are edematous bilaterally up to mid-thigh, and oedema is more pronounced at the ankles. An echocardiogram is done, which reveals an ejection fraction of 25% with anterior, septal, and lateral wall motion defects. He is admitted to the ward and stabilized on furosemide, spironolactone, bisoprolol, and ramipril. What would be the best next investigation in course of his management?
questions.solution:
Option B: Angiogram

  • This patient’s presentation is consistent with heart failure secondary to ischemic heart disease.
  • An echocardiogram is a screening tool used for looking at wall motion abnormalities.
  • Angiography:
    • Angiography or arteriography is an imaging technique in which a contrast dye is used to visualize the inside of blood vessels and the heart chambers.
    • It is a gold standard investigation to assess the anatomy, and physiology of the heart.
    • Angiography is used to assess vasculature abnormalities and to evaluate the extent of severity of cardiac disease in symptomatic individuals.
    • The indications of angiography are as follows:
Indications of Angiography:
Asymptomatic or Symptomatic Ventricular tachycardia
Symptomatic Acute Coronary Syndrome
Chest pain syndromes
STEMI
Congestive Heart failure
Pericardial disease
Cardiac Transplantation

Option A: Endomyocardial biopsy

  • Endomyocardial biopsy (EMB) is a procedure that obtains small amounts of myocardial tissue percutaneously for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.
  • Endomyocardial biopsy (EMB) is used for surveillance of cardiac allograft rejection and the diagnosis of unexplained ventricular dysfunction.
  • It is not an investigation to look at vessels.

Option C: Viral titers

  • This patient’s presentation is consistent with heart failure. Heart failure can occur secondary to viral infections such as hepatitis B and C, COVID-19, and parvovirus etc.
  • However, this patient does not have any prodromal viral symptoms and his history is more consistent with heart failure in the setting of ischemic heart disease.

Option D: Exercise tolerance test(ETT)

  • ETT is contraindicated in the setting of ongoing chest pain.
  • As this patient has ongoing pain, it should not be done.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents in ED with a complaint of fever and sore throat for 2 days. Throat examination shows follicular tonsillitis. He has been prescribed penicillin. Post administration of penicillin, a patient developed facial puffiness, rash, hypotension and breathing difficulty. Chest auscultation revealed a bilateral wheeze. His BP is 70/40 mmHg, and his pulse is 128/min. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: 0.5 ml of adrenaline i.m. (1:1000) dilution

  • The patient described in the clinical vignette has anaphylactic shock secondary to penicillin injection.
  • Symptoms of anaphylaxis develop rapidly and may lead to bronchospasm, laryngeal oedema and even death.
  • The treatment of choice is 0.5ml of un-diluted adrenaline given intramuscularly.

Options B: 1 ml of adrenaline i.v. (1:10,000) dilution

  • Adrenaline must be given intramuscularly in anaphylaxis
  • Adrenaline given I/V can cause arrhythmia and cardiac arrest

Option D: 0.5 ml of adrenaline i.v. (1:1000) dilution

  • Adrenaline must be given intramuscularly in anaphylaxis
  • Adrenaline given I/V can cause arrhythmia and cardiac arrest

Option C: 1 ml of adrenaline s.c. (1:10,000) dilution

  • Subcutaneous epinephrine is not routinely recommended in the treatment of anaphylaxis due to delayed absorption

questions.text: Eight hours after undergoing a coronary artery bypass graft surgery, a 54-year-old male develops numbness around his lips and fingertips. During the surgery, his internal mammary artery got lacerated, and he received multiple blood transfusions because of the massive bleeding. The patient has had hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last 15 years. His family history is remarkable for hyperparathyroidism in his mother. The patient is a chronic smoker and alcoholic. His current medications include metformin, glyburide, and captopril. On physical examination, he appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), his pulse is 100 beats/min, and his blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Examination of the extremities shows an adducted thumb, flexion at metacarpophalangeal joints, and extension at wrists and fingers. The remainder of the review of systems shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option A: Multiple blood transfusions

  • This patient received multiple blood transfusions while managing haemorrhage, showing signs and symptoms of tetany because of hypocalcemia.
  • The citrate ions in the stored blood chelate the free calcium ions and decrease the concentration of free calcium ions, resulting in hypocalcemia.
  • Moderate to severe hypocalcemia is associated with paresthesias, usually of the fingers, toes, and circumoral regions, and is caused by increased neuromuscular irritability.
  • Trousseau's sign observed in this patient as a carpopedal spasm is a classic sign of latent tetany. It can be induced by inflation of a blood pressure cuff to 20 mmHg above the patient's systolic blood pressure for 3 minutes.
  • The image below shows the trousseau sign/carpopedal spasm in patients with hypocalcemia.

  • Chvostek's sign is another meaningful clinical sign. This sign can be elicited by the gentle tapping of the facial nerve just anterior to the ear and causes twitching of the circumoral muscles.
  • Severe hypocalcemia can induce seizures, carpopedal spasms, bronchospasm, laryngospasm, and prolongation of the QT interval.

Option B: Hypoparathyroidism

  • Hypoparathyroidism can cause tetany and features of hypocalcemia.
  • However, the sudden presentation of this patient just after a massive blood transfusion makes hypoparathyroidism a less likely diagnosis in this clinical vignette.

 

Option C: Vitamin B 12 deficiency

  • This patient is taking metformin which can result in vitamin B12 deficiency. Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to the gradual development of peripheral neuropathy, such as numbness and paresthesia.
  • However, acute presentation of this individual, along with carpopedal spasm, points towards massive blood transfusion as the underlying cause.

 

Option D: Ulnar nerve injury

  • An ulnar nerve injury may manifest with numbness and a finger deformity.
  • However, it would be just localized to the 4th and 5th fingers.
  • Moreover, this manifests as an extension of the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of the interphalangeal joints (which is precisely the opposite of this patient's clinical presentation).

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to sudden onset vomiting and nausea for the last 3 hours. It is associated with crampy abdominal pain. The patient's history is significant for an injury to the lower lumbosacral spine, making him bedridden for the last two months. On physical examination, dry mucous membranes and sensory impairment with flaccid paralysis of both lower limbs are noted. The laboratory investigations show: 


	
		
			
			Serum
			
			 
		
		
			
			Calcium
			
			
			13.9 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Parathyroid hormone
			
			
			8 pg/mL
			
		
		
			
			Thyroid-stimulating hormone
			
			
			2.5 μU/mL
			
		
		
			
			Thyroxine
			
			
			8 μg/dL
			
		
		
			
			25-Hydroxycholecalciferol
			
			
			7 ng/mL (N = 20–50)
			
		
		
			
			Creatinine
			
			
			2.2 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			Urine
			
			 
		
		
			
			Calcium
			
			
			545 mg/24 h
			
		
		
			
			Creatinine clearance
			
			
			48 mL/min
			
		
	


In addition to administering intravenous 0.9% saline, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Option D: Bisphosphonates

  • Patient with prolonged immobilization tends to develop symptomatic hypercalcemia because of excessive bone resorption by osteoclast cells.
  • The symptomatic hypercalcemia may present with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, fatigue, abdominal pain, and elevated serum calcium levels.
  • The first step in managing these patients include administering normal intravenous saline to treat dehydration. Normal saline also helps to lower blood calcium levels by diluting the serum calcium.
  • Furthermore, intravenous bisphosphonates (e.g., zoledronic acid) are the drug of choice in these cases.
  • Bisphosphonates inhibit the activity of the osteoclast cells. Hence, block bone resorption and decrease serum calcium levels.
  • It's high-yield to mention that bisphosphonates are nephrotoxic and require monitoring of renal function.

Option A: Parathyroidectomy

  • Parathyroidectomy is indicated in the case of hypercalcemia due to primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • The patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have elevated parathyroid (PTH) levels.
  • In contrast, this patient's PTH levels are low, which suggests another aetiology.

Option B: Thiazide diuretics

  • Thiazide diuretics are contraindicated in patients with hypercalcemia. These drugs increase the Ca2+ resorption, which worsens hypercalcemia.
  • Furthermore, this patient suffers from hypovolemia, so diuretics should be avoided.  

Option C: Hemodialysis

  • Hemodialysis is indicated in patients with severe hypercalcemia (serum calcium concentration > 14 mg/dL), neurologic symptoms (e.g., confusion), and renal failure.
  • This patient has moderate hypercalcemia, which can be managed with less invasive therapies.

Option E: Glucocorticoids

  • Glucocorticoids manage hypercalcemia due to granulomatous diseases (e.g., sarcoidosis) and vitamin D intoxication.

questions.text: Investigation of choice in pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Option D: Elevated plasma free metanephrines

  • Investigation of choice in pheochromocytoma.
  • The most commonly ordered blood test for pheochromocytoma is the plasma free metanephrine test. Though more convenient to obtain than a 24-hour urine collection, plasma free metanephrine testing is plagued by frequent false positive results.

other options

Option A: Serum prolactin levels

  • It is not Investigation of choice in pheochromocytoma

Option B: Early morning serum cortisol testing

  • It is not Investigation of choice in pheochromocytoma

Option C: Repeat Neck Ultrasound

  • It is not Investigation of choice in pheochromocytoma

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and bilateral lower extremity oedema. His medical history has been consistent with diabetes and hypertension for the past 20 years. He was diagnosed with CKD about 5 years ago. A thorough assessment reveals metabolic acidosis. Which is correct about the prediction of compensation in metabolic acidosis?

choices.text: pACO2 will rise by 1.25mm Hg for every mmol/ L fall in bicarbonate
pACO2 will fall by 1.25mm Hg for every mmol/ L fall in bicarbonate
Paco2 will ↑ 6 mmHg per 10 mmol/L ↑ in [HCO3 – ]
pACO2 will fall by 10mm Hg for every mmol/ L fall in bicarbonate

questions.solution:
Option B: pACO2 will fall by 1.25mm Hg for every mmol/ L fall in bicarbonate

  • Primary respiratory disturbances (immediate changes in Paco2 ) invoke compensatory metabolic responses (secondary changes in [HCO3 −]), and primary metabolic disturbances elicit predictable- The degree of respiratory compensation expected in a metabolic acidosis can be predicted from the relationship:
    Paco2 = (1.5 × [HCO3 −]) + 8 ± 2.
  • Thus, a patient with metabolic acidosis and [HCO3 −] of 12 mmol/L would be expected to have a Paco2 of ∼26 mmHg.
  • Values for Paco2 <24 or >28 mmHg define a mixed disturbance (metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis or metabolic acidosis and respiratory acidosis, respectively).

Option A: pACO2 will rise by 1.25mm Hg for every mmol/ L fall in bicarbonate

  • A decreasing bicarbonate ion would result in a compensatory fall in carbon dioxide level.

Option C: Paco2 will ↑ 6 mmHg per 10 mmol/L ↑ in [HCO3 – ]

  • This is a compensatory response for metabolic alkalosis.

Option D: pACO2 will fall by 10mm Hg for every mmol/ L fall in bicarbonate

  • A fall in bicarbonate for every mmol/L would result in a rise in pCO2 by 1.25 mmHg

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy comes to the clinic with complaints of fever, night sweats and weight loss for the past two weeks. His examination reveals a firm, mobile and painless masses in his neck. Lymph node biopsy is positive for Reed Sternberg cells. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Minimal Change Disease

  • The patient's condition of fever, night sweats, weight loss with lymphadenopathy, and Reed Sternberg cells is indicative of Hodgkin's lymphoma.
  • Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common nephrotic syndrome in children and presents with selective proteinuria.
  • It responds well to steroids and can be treated as such.
  • It is usually idiopathic but can be caused by secondary conditions, including immunisations, infections, and malignancies.
  • MCD is the most common nephropathy associated with Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

Option A: Membranous Nephropathy

  • Membranous nephropathy is the most common nephrotic syndrome in adults.
  • In addition to infections and autoimmune conditions, membranous nephropathy is usually associated with solid organ malignancies, including lung, breast, and gastrointestinal adenocarcinoma. It is not associated with Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

Option C: Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis

  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is an immune complex/complement deposition mediated condition which can present with either nephritic or nephrotic range proteinuria and hematuria.
  • It is usually associated with autoimmune conditions (e.g. SLE) or infections. (e.g. hepatitis B, hepatitis C)
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis may be associated with Nonhodgkin’s lymphoma in certain cases, not Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

Option D: IgA Nephropathy

  • IgA nephropathy occurs after a viral infection and is signified by hematuria and proteinuria.
  • The patient presents with flank pain and hematuria 3-5 days after a respiratory or gastrointestinal infection.
  • It is not associated with any malignancy.

questions.text: An 80-year-old, asymptomatic man presents with a total leucocyte count of 100,000/uL, with 80% lymphocytes and 20% polymorphonuclear cells. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Chronic lymphocytic leukaemia

  • The above-given clinical presentation points toward a diagnosis of CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia)
  • Its median age of presentation is 65 years, with 53% male presentation.
  • Most common presentation is Asymptomatic >> fatigue(anemia) > Left upper quadrant pain/mass(splenomegaly)
  • In the accelerated or blastic phase, the presentation would be unexplained fever, significant weight loss, severe fatigue, bone and joint aches, bleeding and thrombotic events, and infections.
  • The diagnosis of typical CLL is made with B-cell lymphocytosis greater than 5000/µL & co-expression of CD19 and CD5 on lymphocytes.
  • The peripheral blood smear shows "smudge" or "basket" cells.

  • Warm autoimmune hemolytic anaemia (IgG), Coombs test positive
  • Cytogenetic studies reveal trisomy 12
  • CML presents with massive splenomegaly, elevated WBC, increase in both immature and mature granulocytes.
  • At diagnosis, bone marrow cellularity is increased, with an increased myeloid-to-erythroid ratio.

Option A: Acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)

  • Normal CD4 count can vary from 500 to 1500 cells per cubic mL of blood. 
  • AIDS is diagnosed when CD4 levels drop below 200 cells per cubic mL of blood. 
  • In contrast, lymphocyte count is increased in chronic lymphocytic leukaemia.

Option B: Chronic myeloid leukaemia

  • Chronic myeloid leukaemia is a disorder of neoplastic proliferation of mature myeloid cells, especially granulocytes and their precursors; basophils are characteristically increased.
  • Lymphocyte count in chronic myeloid leukaemia does not exceed 100,000/cubic mm

Option D: Tuberculosis 

  • Tuberculosis presents symptoms such as dry fever, cough, weight loss and night sweats, whereas the presentation of the given patient is asymptomatic.
  • Moreover, lymphocyte count in tuberculosis does not exceed 100,000/cubic mm

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with sudden, severe, tearing chest pain radiating to the back. On examination, his blood pressure is elevated, and he has a new diastolic murmur. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B

  • The clinical presentation of sudden, severe, tearing chest pain radiating to the back, along with a history of hypertension, elevated blood pressure, and new diastolic murmur, raises suspicion for aortic dissection. Acute myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, and GERD are important differential diagnoses, but the clinical findings in this case point towards aortic dissection as the most likely diagnosis.

Why other options are wrong:

  • A) Acute myocardial infarction - This option is incorrect as the clinical presentation with tearing chest pain radiating to the back, elevated blood pressure, and new diastolic murmur are not typical of acute myocardial infarction. Symptoms of acute myocardial infarction include chest pain or discomfort, shortness of breath, nausea, vomiting, sweating, lightheadedness, and pain or discomfort in the arms, back, neck, jaw or stomach.
  • C) Pulmonary embolism - This option is incorrect as the clinical presentation with tearing chest pain radiating to the back, elevated blood pressure, and new diastolic murmur are not typical of pulmonary embolism. Some common symptoms of pulmonary embolism include sudden onset of shortness of breath, chest pain, coughing, and rapid or irregular heartbeat. Other symptoms may include anxiety, sweating, and fainting.
  • D) Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) - This option is incorrect as the clinical presentation with sudden, severe, tearing chest pain radiating to the back, elevated blood pressure, and new diastolic murmur are not typical of GERD. Symptoms of Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) include heartburn, acid regurgitation, difficulty swallowing, chest pain, and nausea.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old female patient presents with symptoms of exertional dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and fatigue. On physical examination, a solitary, pedunculated tumor is identified in the left atrium, attached to the border of the fossa ovalis. Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis of a sporadic tumor.

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option C

  • Atrial myxoma is a benign tumor that usually presents as a solitary, pedunculated mass in the left atrium, attached to the border of the fossa ovalis. The clinical features include exertional dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, and fatigue. Echocardiography is used to confirm the diagnosis. Atrial myxoma is a sporadic tumor that occurs in patients of all ages, and it is more common in females than males.

Why the other choices are incorrect:

  • A) Cardiac fibroma is a rare, benign tumor that typically presents in childhood or young adulthood. It is not usually associated with the clinical features described in the case, and it is not typically located in the left atrium.
  • B) Myocardial infarction is a common cardiovascular condition that presents with symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, and diaphoresis. It is not typically associated with a pedunculated tumor in the left atrium.
  • D) Pulmonary embolism is a potentially life-threatening condition that typically presents with symptoms such as sudden onset dyspnea, chest pain, and cough. It is not typically associated with a pedunculated tumor in the left atrium.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, flushing, and wheezing. She also reports a history of episodes of bronchospasm and right-sided heart failure. On physical examination, she has a telangiectasia on her lips and cheeks, and palpation reveals a small mobile mass in her abdomen. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) in her urine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D

  • The clinical presentation of the patient is consistent with a diagnosis of carcinoid tumor, which is a type of neuroendocrine tumor. The symptoms of carcinoid syndrome include abdominal pain, diarrhea, flushing, and wheezing, which are caused by the release of vasoactive substances such as serotonin and histamine from the tumor. Bronchospasm and right-sided heart failure can also occur due to the production of vasoactive peptides that bypass the liver and enter systemic circulation. The telangiectasia on the lips and cheeks, known as the "carcinoid facies," is a characteristic physical finding in patients with carcinoid syndrome. Elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine are indicative of increased serotonin production, which is a hallmark of carcinoid tumors.

Why other choices are incorrect:

  • A) Pancreatic adenocarcinoma: This is unlikely because the patient's symptoms are not consistent with pancreatic cancer, which typically presents with abdominal pain, weight loss, and jaundice.
  • B) Renal cell carcinoma: This is unlikely because renal cell carcinoma does not typically cause the symptoms described by the patient.
  • C) Gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST): This is unlikely because the symptoms of GIST are not typically associated with carcinoid syndrome. GISTs can cause abdominal pain and gastrointestinal bleeding, but not flushing or bronchospasm.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus presented to the emergency department with complaints of vomiting and abdominal pain. He was found to be in DKA. Despite aggressive treatment, his serum glucose level remains elevated at 450 mg/dL, and his serum bicarbonate level is 5 mmol/L. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for his persistent hyperglycemia?

choices.text: Insulin resistance due to a concomitant infection
Insulin resistance due to the presence of anti-insulin antibodies
Failure to adhere to prescribed insulin therapy

questions.solution:
Option C

  • This patient's persistent hyperglycemia despite aggressive treatment is most likely due to insulin resistance caused by the presence of anti-insulin antibodies. These antibodies can develop in patients with type 1 diabetes who are treated with exogenous insulin, and they can interfere with the action of exogenous insulin, resulting in persistent hyperglycemia.

Why Others are Wrong:

  • Option A) Insulin resistance due to a concomitant infection is a common cause of hyperglycemia in patients with DKA. However, the patient's persistently elevated glucose level is not likely due to an infection, as he has already received aggressive treatment.
  • Option B) Renal failure can cause hyperglycemia by impairing renal glucose excretion. However, the patient's creatinine level is not provided, and there are no other indications of renal failure.
  • Option D) Failure to adhere to prescribed insulin therapy can lead to hyperglycemia, but the patient's presentation with DKA suggests that he was likely adherent to his insulin therapy prior to the development of DKA. Furthermore, his persistent hyperglycemia despite aggressive treatment indicates that nonadherence is not the cause of his hyperglycemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is a typical endoscopic finding in Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia (GAVE)?

choices.text: Linear, cherry-red stripes radiating from the pylorus towards the antrum
Dilated and tortuous veins in the stomach

questions.solution:
Option B

  • The typical endoscopic finding in Gastric Antral Vascular Ectasia (GAVE) is linear, cherry-red stripes radiating from the pylorus towards the antrum, which gives it the characteristic "watermelon stomach" appearance.

Why other options are wrong:

  • A) Ulcerated gastric mucosa is a typical of gastric ulcers, which can be caused by H. pylori infection, NSAIDs, stress, and other factors. This option is incorrect as ulceration is not a typical finding in GAVE. 
  • C) Diffuse congestion of gastric mucosa is a typical finding of acute gastritis, which can be caused by H. pylori infection, alcohol, NSAIDs, and other factors. This option is incorrect as GAVE does not typically present with it.
  • D) Dilated and tortuous veins in the stomach are typical findings of portal hypertensive gastropathy, which is commonly seen in patients with liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension. It can also be seen in patients with non-cirrhotic portal hypertension. This option is incorrect as this finding is more suggestive of portal hypertensive gastropathy rather than GAVE.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, and palpitations during exercise. His father died of sudden cardiac arrest at the age of 40. On physical examination, a loud systolic murmur is heard over the left sternal border that increases with the Valsalva maneuver and decreases with squatting. ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy. Echocardiogram reveals asymmetrical septal hypertrophy with systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A

  • HOCM is a genetic disorder that causes hypertrophy of the left ventricle and is associated with increased risk of sudden cardiac death. Beta-blockers are the first-line treatment for HOCM and can help relieve symptoms by decreasing the contractility of the heart and reducing the outflow obstruction. Calcium channel blockers and ACE inhibitors may also be used in certain cases but are not as effective as beta-blockers. ICDs are typically reserved for patients with a history of cardiac arrest or syncope, and not used as a first-line treatment for HOCM.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • B) Calcium channel blockers may be used in certain cases but are not as effective as beta-blockers as a first-line treatment for HOCM.
  • C) ACE inhibitors may be used in certain cases but are not as effective as beta-blockers as a first-line treatment for HOCM.
  • D) ICDs are typically reserved for patients with a history of cardiac arrest or syncope, and not used as a first-line treatment for HOCM.

questions.text: A 70-year-old female with a history of primary hyperparathyroidism presents with polyuria, polydipsia, and fatigue. Her serum calcium level is elevated at 11.8 mg/dL. She has no signs of dehydration. What is the most appropriate management for this patient's hypercalcemia?

choices.text: Oral calcium and vitamin D supplementation

questions.solution:
Option C

  • The patient has primary hyperparathyroidism as the underlying cause of hypercalcemia, and the most appropriate management for this condition is parathyroidectomy, which involves the surgical removal of the overactive parathyroid gland(s).

Why Other Options are Wrong:

  • A. IV hydration with normal saline is not indicated in the absence of dehydration.
  • B. Oral calcium and vitamin D supplementation is not appropriate as it can exacerbate hypercalcemia in this case.
  • D. Calcium channel blocker therapy is not indicated for the management of hypercalcemia, as it does not address the underlying cause of elevated serum calcium levels.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with a history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN 2A) presents for routine follow-up. Genetic testing has confirmed a mutation in the RET proto-oncogene. What is the most appropriate screening test for medullary thyroid carcinoma in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C

  • Patients with MEN 2A, a hereditary syndrome associated with medullary thyroid carcinoma, should undergo screening for medullary thyroid carcinoma using serum calcitonin levels. Calcitonin is a hormone produced by C-cells, and elevated serum calcitonin levels are highly suggestive of medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Why Other Options are Wrong:

  • A. Thyroid ultrasound is a useful imaging modality for evaluating the size and characteristics of thyroid nodules, but it may not be sensitive enough to detect small medullary thyroid carcinomas.
  • B. Serum thyroglobulin is a marker for differentiated thyroid cancers such as papillary and follicular thyroid carcinoma, but it is not a reliable marker for medullary thyroid carcinoma.
  • D. Thyroid scintigraphy, also known as a thyroid scan, is not typically used as a screening test for medullary thyroid carcinoma, as it primarily evaluates the function of the thyroid gland rather than detecting tumors.

questions.text: A healthy, 26-year-old woman, recently married, is anxious to conceive and visits the physician for evaluation. She is worried that her cycles come at intervals of 28 to 32 days and not on a fixed date every month. Her clinician reassures her that such variation may be normal. Which of the following about the physiology of the menstrual cycle is INCORRECT?

choices.text: Ovulation follows 24-36 hours after the onset of LH surge
Withdrawal of endogenous progesterone results in endometrial breakdown and subsequent menstruation

questions.solution:
Correct Option B: The follicular phase is constant: This statement is incorrect. The follicular phase of the menstrual cycle is not constant. The follicular phase is the phase before ovulation and can vary in length from cycle to cycle. In the described case, the woman has menstrual cycles occurring at intervals of 28 to 32 days. The length of the follicular phase can differ between cycles and may contribute to variations in cycle length.

Other Options: 

Option A: Ovulation follows 36 hours after the onset of LH surge: This statement is generally true. In a typical menstrual cycle, ovulation occurs around 36 hours after the onset of the luteinizing hormone (LH) surge. The LH surge triggers the release of the matured egg from the dominant follicle in the ovary.

Option C : Withdrawal of endogenous progesterone results in endometrial breakdown and subsequent menstruation: This statement is true. In a typical menstrual cycle, if fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum, which forms after ovulation, stops producing progesterone. This results in a decrease in progesterone levels, leading to endometrial breakdown and subsequent menstruation.

Option D :Average cycle length is 21–35 days: This statement is generally true. The average menstrual cycle length is considered to be between 21 to 35 days. In the described case, the woman's cycles occurring at intervals of 28 to 32 days fall within this normal range.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman presents to the physician for a routine Pap smear and evaluation of her period. She has not had periods for 2 years now. She has no history of any chronic illness. She gives a history of no other abnormalities. She is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. The USG of the patient is done, which shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the major source of estrogen in this patient?

choices.text: Aromatization of androgens in theca cells of the ovary
Aromatization of androgens in granulosa cells of the ovary
Aromatization of androgens in adipose tissue

questions.solution:
Option C: Aromatization of androgens in adipose tissue

  • In this case, the patient has presented at menopause.
  • Androgen production from the ovary continues beyond the menopausal transition caused by the sparing of ovarian stroma and theca cells. However, due to the loss of granulosa cell function, the ovary does not contribute to estrogen production by the aromatization of androgens.
  • The most important source of estrogen is the peripheral conversion of androgens produced by the ovary and adrenals, principally occurring in adipose tissue.

Option A: Aromatization of androgens in theca cells of the ovary

  • Theca cells produce androgens which are then converted to estrogen in granulosa cells, this production of estrogen  doesn't occur beyond the menopausal transition.

Option B: Aromatization of androgens in granulosa cells of the ovary

  • The production of estrogen via the aromatization of androgens in granulosa cells of the ovary doesn't occur after menopause because of the loss of function of granulosa cells.

Option D: Adrenal production of estrogens

  • After menopause, the adrenal glands alone cannot produce androgen. The adrenal glands only produce androgen.
  • The androgen from the adrenal gland goes into the adipose tissues for aromatization.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a history of lower back pain and cyclical dysmenorrhea for the last 12 months. She has been married for the last 4 years and has never conceived. She is referred to the infertility clinic for further evaluation. The patient has regular cycles with dysmenorrhea. Further investigations revealed dark red to bluish vesicles surrounded by flame-like lesions on the peritoneum. Which of the following is the most common site for a lesion?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ovary

  • The most common site of endometriosis is the ovary.
  • Endometriosis is a disorder where tissue resembling the uterus lining grows in some places, such as the ovaries and fallopian tubes. Endometriosis affects women of any age.
  • The picture below shows the endometriosis in the ovary:

 

 

  • Endometriotic dysmenorrhea is classically congestive type secondary dysmenorrhea.
  • Other common sites are fallopian tubes, pelvic peritoneum, and uterosacral ligaments. Other sites are less common and occur in:
    • Bowel
    • Lung (periodic hemoptysis)
    • Nose (periodic epistaxis)
    • Eyes (periodic subconjunctival haemorrhage)
    • Previous surgical scar (scar endometriosis, periodic bleeding from a previous surgical scar)
  • Presentation of Endometriosis:
    • Infertility
    • Pain: dysmenorrhea (congestive type secondary dysmenorrhea) dyspareunia (in lesions over POD), or chronic pelvic pain
    • Pelvic mass
    • Menstrual abnormalities
    • GI symptoms: pain, nausea, vomiting, bloating, distension
    • Specific symptoms of extrapelvic endometriosis
    • Examination may reveal a cystic pelvic mass suggestive of ovarian endometriosis or a fixed retroverted uterus (suggestive of pelvic adhesions), tenderness or nodularity in POD (suggestive of peritoneal deposits)

Option A: Fallopian tube

  • It is also a site for endometriosis. However, the more common site is the ovary.

Option B: Cervix

  • It rarely harbours endometriotic deposits.

Option D: Vagina

  • It also rarely shows endometriotic deposits.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with severe refractory dysmenorrhea; she says she has been getting painkiller injections for the past 8 months for this condition. The doctor advises her diagnostic laparoscopy that reveals black-brown powder burn-like lesions on peritoneal surfaces and also covering bilateral tubes, which is sent for biopsy. The report says there is a presence of haemorrhage and the endometrial glands. Which of the following is the LEAST likely mechanism for her dysmenorrhea?

choices.text: Collection of shed menstrual blood in implants

questions.solution:
Option D : SEPTIC SEEDING OF IMPLANTS:
