History of dysmenorrhea, powder burn like lesions and biopsy with endometrial glands are all suggestive of a diagnosis of endometriosis. Endometriotic implants are aseptic in nature that cause deep peritoneal inflammation, which on healing causes adhesions and fibrosis. Possible mechanisms causing pain in patients with endometriosis include:-

  • Local peritoneal inflammation,
  • Deep infiltration with tissue damage,
  • Adhesion formation,
  • Fibrotic thickening,
  • Collection of shed menstrual blood in endometriotic implants, resulting in painful traction with the physiologic movement of tissues.

Option A : LOCAL PERITONEAL INFLAMMATION:

  • There is local peritoneal inflammation at the site of implants

Option B : DEEP INFILTRATION WITH TISSUE DAMAGE:

  • These implants infiltrate the tissues deeply which along with inflammation, is responsible for pain.

Option C :COLLECTION OF SHED MENSTRUAL BLOOD IN IMPLANTS:

  • These implants containing endometriotic glands and stroma and are therefore associated with collection of blood at each menstrual cycle.

questions.text: What is the appropriate statement regarding further treatment for a 58-year-old female with post-menopausal bleeding who is diagnosed with endometrial cancer and is on hormone replacement therapy for 1 year?

choices.text: ET less than 5 mm requires no further evaluation
ET 5 to 10 mm confers no risk of endometrial cancer
No evaluation required in women on HRT

questions.solution:
Option A : An endometrial stripe of less than 5 mm in a postmenopausal woman on HRT confers minimal risk of cancer. ET more than 10 mm correlates with a 10% to 20% risk of hyperplasia or cancer. Thus any endometrial thickness equal to or more than 5 mm in menopausal women whether or not associated with bleeding, must be evaluated. In premenopausal women, an ET of less than 12 mm is considered safe.

Option B : An ET of 5-10 mm carries risk of endometrial cancer.

Option C : Evaluation of the woman is required if ET is more than or equal to 5 mm.

Option D : A hysterectomy is not appropriate until a tissue diagnosis is obtained.

questions.text: A 52 year old woman presents with loss of appetite and weight loss. On investigation her CA-125 is markedly raised. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D : CA 125 is a tumor marker for ovarian epithelial cancers ( high molecular weight glycoprotein(220 to 1000kd)

CA 125 can also be high in

  • cancers of the endometrium, fallopian tubes, lungs, breast and gastrointestinal tract.
  • endometriosis
  • several diseases of the ovary
  • pregnancy
  • adenomyosis
  • fibroids
  • liver disease
  • pancreatitis
  • peritonitis
  • luteal phase of the menstrual cycle.

Option A : Colon cancer is rarely associated with raised CA 125.

Option B : Breast cancer may have raised CA 125 at times, but the increase is not as much as that in ovarian cancer. Also, breast cancer presents with breast lump and not with weight loss and loss of appetite.

Option C : Brain cancer is not associated with raised CA 125.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to gynecology OPD with complaints of lower abdominal pain and abdominal distension for the last 1 month. Her ultrasound report reveals bilateral solid ovarian tumors along with ascites. An upper gastrointestinal endoscopy is done, which reveals an ulcerative growth in the pyloric region of the stomach. The most likely diagnosis is:

choices.text: Malignant epithelial ovarian tumor with gastric metastasis
Germ cell ovarian tumor with concurrent gastric malignancy
Sex cord stromal tumor with concurrent gastric malignancy

questions.solution:
Option D: Carcinoma stomach with Krukenberg’s tumor

  • Krukenberg tumor is a classical description of a tumor that is 'secondary' to the ovary and is most commonly from the adenocarcinoma of the GIT tract, ca stomach being the most common cause. The features are:
    • Signet ring cells are pathognomonic for adenocarcinoma in the stomach.
    • It is a bilateral ovarian tumor in 90% of cases.
    • A solid to firm tumor in consistency.
    • The affected ovary, although maybe enlarged more than 10-fold but still maintains its shape.
  • Krukenberg tumor can present as an abdominal mass and pain in the pelvis. Other symptoms may include bloating, weight loss, and changes in the menstrual cycle.
  • Diagnosis of Krukenberg tumor is made by radiography. However, it is a rare metastatic signet ring cell tumor of the ovary, which accounts for only 1–2% of all ovarian tumors.

 

Option A: Malignant epithelial ovarian tumor with gastric metastasis.

  • A malignant ovarian epithelial tumor can be bilateral and associated with ascites; however, it rarely metastasizes to the stomach. More common sites of metastasis are the liver, lung, spleen, intestine, and brain.

Option B: Germ ovarian cell tumor with concurrent gastric malignancy

  • The concurrent occurrence of ovarian and gastric cancers is rare.

Option C: Sex cord-stromal tumor with concurrent gastric malignancy

  • Sex cord-stromal tumors are rarely bilateral and extremely rare to have concurrent gastric malignancy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with complaints of anorexia and weight loss. On ultrasound, there are bilateral ovarian malignant masses for which the gynecologist is planning for laparotomy. On exploration, the ovaries are symmetrically enlarged with firm and waxy consistency. Histopathology shows signet-ring cells. Which of the following investigation is warranted in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Gastric endoscopy

  • Bilateral tumor masses with a firm to waxy consistency with signet cells on histopathology suggest the Krukenberg tumor.
  • Krukenberg tumor:
  • Krukenberg tumor is secondaries to the ovary. It is most commonly from the CA Stomach (usual adenocarcinoma of gastric pylorus). Other primary sites are breast cancer, appendix, colon, small intestine, rectum, gall bladder, and biliary tract.
  • Firm to solid waxy consistency is bilateral in 90% of cases.
  • Signet ring cells are seen.
  • Most often present in bilateral ovaries, consistent with metastatic nature.

 

Option A: CECT brain

  • CECT brain is not indicated as brain cancers extremely rarely metastasize to ovaries.

 

Option C: AFP

 

  • AFP is a tumor marker of yolk sac tumor, embryonal tumor, and teratoma and is not raised in the Krukenberg tumor.

 

Option D: CA 125

  • It is a false option.
  • CA 125 must always be done in case of ovarian tumors to rule out epithelial ovarian cancers, the most common cancers of the ovary, and are usually bilateral. In this case, however, since a biopsy is already done suggesting a Krukenberg tumor, tumor markers for other ovarian cancers are not required.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal discomfort, bloating, and pain. On MRI bilateral ovarian tumors with involvement of pelvic lymph node and liver capsule are seen. What is the appropriate staging of this ovarian tumor?
questions.solution:
Option D : Stage 3 : one or bilateral ovarian tumor + cytologically or histologically confirmed spread to peritoneum outside pelvis (liver or spleen capsular involvement) and/or retroperitoneal lymph node involvement

NOTE: involvement of liver/spleen parenchyma is stage IV

STAGE I → OVARIAN INVOLVEMENT 

             A → One ovary involved 

             B → Both ovaries involved 

             C → A/BC →A/B± 
           C 1 →  Surgical spill
           C 2 →  Surface growth
           C 3 →  Malignant Ascites/ washings

STAGE II → PELVIS INVOLVEMENT
             IIA → Uterus, fallopian tubes
             IIB → other pelvic organs

STAGE III → ABDOMINAL VISCERAL INVOLVEMENT
             IIIA  1→ Retroperitoneal lymph node involvement
                      A1 (i) →<10 mm
                     A1 (ii) →>10 mm
             IIIA2 Microscopic abdominal visceral involvement
             IIIB Macroscopic involvement <2 cm / superficial liver & spleen involvement

             IIIC Macroscopic involvement >2 cm / superficial liver & spleen involvement

STAGE IV

             IVA malignant pleural effusion 

             IVB Deep/parenchymal liver & spleen deposits 

                    Inguinal lymph node involvements 

Highlighted ones are new changes in staging

questions.text: A patient presents with an unilocular ovarian cyst. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C

  • A unilocular ovarian cyst is a fluid-filled sac that contains only one compartment. Serous cystadenomas are benign ovarian tumors that are typically unilocular and lined with a single layer of cells. 

Why other options are incorrect

Option A) Endometrioma, also known as chocolate cysts, are cysts filled with old blood and debris and are typically multilocular. 

Option B) Dermoid cysts are typically complex cysts containing different types of tissue, including hair and teeth. 

Option D) Mucinous cystadenoma are benign ovarian tumors that are typically multilocular and lined with a layer of mucus-secreting cells.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with infertility and irregular menstrual cycles. She reports that she has been trying to conceive for the past 2 years without success. On evaluation, it is found that she has elevated levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH). Which of the following hormones is responsible for inducing ovulation in females?
questions.solution:
Option C

  • LH surge triggers ovulation in females. During the menstrual cycle, the levels of LH and FSH increase gradually, which stimulate the growth and maturation of ovarian follicles. As the follicle grows, it produces more estrogen. When estrogen levels reach a certain threshold, they trigger a sudden surge in LH levels, which causes the dominant follicle to rupture and release an egg (ovulation).

Why other options are incorrect

Option A) Progesterone: Progesterone is a hormone that is secreted by the corpus luteum after ovulation. Its main function is to prepare the uterus for pregnancy and maintain the early stages of pregnancy.

Option B) Estrogen: Estrogen plays a crucial role in the menstrual cycle by stimulating the growth of the uterine lining and promoting the growth of ovarian follicles. However, it does not directly induce ovulation.

Option D) Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH): FSH is another hormone that is involved in the menstrual cycle. It stimulates the growth and development of ovarian follicles, but it does not directly induce ovulation.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with complaints of abdominal cramping and vaginal bleeding. Which hormone(s) is/are responsible for the initiation of menstruation?
questions.solution:
Option D

  • Estrogen is responsible for the growth and proliferation of the endometrial lining of the uterus, which prepares it for implantation of a fertilized egg. When estrogen levels decline at the end of the menstrual cycle, the endometrial lining is shed during menstruation.

Why other choices are Incorrect

Option A) Progesterone: Progesterone is important for the maintenance of the endometrial lining and preparation of the uterus for pregnancy. It is not responsible for the initiation of menstruation.

Option B) Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH): FSH is responsible for the growth and development of ovarian follicles. It is not directly involved in the initiation of menstruation.

Option C) Luteinizing hormone (LH): LH is responsible for triggering ovulation. It is not directly involved in the initiation of menstruation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is true?

choices.text: HPV is a DNA virus that causes genital warts.
HPV types 16 and 18 are low-risk types associated with cervical cancer.
HPV vaccination is recommended for boys only.
HPV infection is limited to the genital area.

questions.solution:
Option A

  • Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is a DNA virus that causes genital warts. HPV is a sexually transmitted infection that can cause genital warts, which are small, bumpy growths on the skin and mucous membranes of the genitals. There are over 100 types of HPV, and some types can also cause cancer of the cervix, anus, or other areas. While HPV types 16 and 18 are high-risk types associated with cervical cancer, they do not cause genital warts. Therefore, option A is the correct statement regarding HPV.

Why other options are incorrect

Option B

HPV types 16 and 18 are high-risk types, not low-risk types. These two types are responsible for causing approximately 70% of cervical cancers worldwide. In contrast, low-risk HPV types typically cause genital warts and mild dysplasia. Therefore, option B is incorrect.

Option C. 

HPV vaccination is recommended for both boys and girls, not for boys only. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends routine HPV vaccination for all boys and girls at age 11 or 12, and for older teens and young adults who have not yet been vaccinated. Vaccination can help protect against HPV infection and related cancers, including cervical cancer, as well as other types of cancers, such as anal, penile, vaginal, and oropharyngeal cancers.

Option D

HPV infection is not limited to the genital area it can infect both genital and non-genital areas, including the mouth, throat, and anus. Additionally, some HPV types can cause non-cancerous growths, such as plantar warts, on other parts of the body. Therefore, option D is not a true statement about HPV

questions.text: Which of the following is a common cause of galactorrhea?
questions.solution:
Option C

  • Galactorrhea is a condition in which there is a spontaneous and abnormal lactation from the breasts, unrelated to pregnancy or breastfeeding. A common cause of galactorrhea is a pituitary adenoma, which is a non-cancerous tumor of the pituitary gland that secretes excess prolactin. 

Why other options are incorrect

Option A

  • Breast cancer is not a common cause of galactorrhea. Galactorrhea is a condition in which there is spontaneous, excessive milk production from the breasts that is unrelated to pregnancy or breastfeeding. It is often caused by an excess of prolactin, which can be due to a number of factors including pituitary adenomas, medications, or other medical conditions. While breast cancer can cause nipple discharge, it is not typically associated with galactorrhea.

Option B

  • PCOS is not a common cause of galactorrhea, PCOS is a hormonal disorder that affects women of reproductive age and is characterized by irregular menstrual periods, excess androgen levels, and ovarian cysts. Although PCOS can cause hormonal imbalances, it does not typically result in galactorrhea.

Option D

  • Thyroid cancer is not a common cause of galactorrhea. Galactorrhea is usually caused by increased levels of prolactin, which is secreted by the pituitary gland. Thyroid cancer does not directly affect the pituitary gland or prolactin levels. While thyroid disorders may cause some breast changes, galactorrhea is not a typical symptom. Therefore, option D is not the correct answer.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with severe menstrual pain that is not relieved by over-the-counter pain medications. Upon further investigation, it is discovered that she has a history of pelvic inflammatory disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. What is the most appropriate treatment for her dysmenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Option C

  • GnRH agonists is the most appropriate treatment for the patient in the given scenario because her dysmenorrhea is caused by scarring and adhesions in the pelvic region due to a history of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. GnRH agonists work by suppressing ovulation, which in turn reduces menstrual pain. This treatment is particularly effective for dysmenorrhea caused by scarring and adhesions. NSAIDs and combined oral contraceptive pills are commonly used to treat mild-to-moderate dysmenorrhea, but they are less effective for severe pain. Antibiotics are used to treat the underlying infection in cases of acute PID but are not effective for chronic pain caused by scarring and adhesions. Therefore, option C is the correct answer.

Why other options are incorrect

Option A

  • NSAIDs are commonly used to treat dysmenorrhea, but they are less effective for severe pain caused by scarring and adhesions in the pelvic region. In the given scenario, the patient has a history of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, which has resulted in scarring and adhesions. Therefore, NSAIDs alone are unlikely to provide significant relief for the patient's severe dysmenorrhea. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are a more appropriate treatment in this case.

Option B

  • Antibiotics are used to treat acute pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which is caused by bacterial infections like Chlamydia trachomatis, but are not effective for chronic pain caused by scarring and adhesions in the pelvic region. In the given scenario, the patient has a history of PID caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, which has resulted in scarring and adhesions, leading to severe dysmenorrhea. Antibiotics alone are unlikely to provide significant relief for the patient's chronic dysmenorrhea. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are a more appropriate treatment in this case.

Options D 

  • Combined hormonal contraceptives are effective in reducing dysmenorrhea in many women, but they are less effective for severe pain caused by scarring and adhesions in the pelvic region. In the given scenario, the patient has a history of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, which has resulted in scarring and adhesions. Therefore, combined hormonal contraceptives alone are unlikely to provide significant relief for the patient's severe dysmenorrhea. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonists are a more appropriate treatment in this case.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with severe dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. She reports that she started menstruating at the age of 10. What is a potential cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option A

  • Early onset of menstruation is a potential risk factor for endometriosis. Other risk factors include family history, prolonged menstrual cycles, and high levels of estrogen.

Why other options are incorrect

Option B) Late onset of menstruation: Late onset of menstruation is not a known risk factor for endometriosis.

Option C) Low estrogen levels: Low estrogen levels are not a known risk factor for endometriosis. In fact, high levels of estrogen are thought to contribute to the development of endometriosis.

Option D) High progesterone levels: While progesterone is involved in the menstrual cycle and can affect endometrial tissue, high levels of progesterone are not known to be a direct cause of endometriosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a sudden onset of severe lower abdominal pain, vomiting, and fever. Pelvic examination reveals cervical motion tenderness, adnexal tenderness, and a palpable pelvic mass. Imaging studies reveal a large complex cystic mass with internal echoes, peripheral vascularity, and fluid-filled spaces. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C

  • Ovarian torsion, is the correct answer because the symptoms and imaging findings described in the question are consistent with this diagnosis. Ovarian torsion occurs when the ovary twists on its vascular pedicle, compromising blood flow to the ovary and causing severe pain, nausea, vomiting, and fever. Pelvic examination may reveal adnexal tenderness and a palpable mass. Imaging studies, such as ultrasound or CT scan, may reveal a large cystic mass with internal echoes, peripheral vascularity, and fluid-filled spaces, as well as the absence of arterial and venous flow to the affected ovary. Mucinous and serous cystadenomas are benign tumors that typically do not cause acute symptoms, and corpus luteal cyst rupture typically presents with more localized pain and mild symptoms.

Why other options are incorrect

Option A 

  • Mucinous cystadenoma, is not the most likely diagnosis for the patient described in the question. Mucinous cystadenomas are benign ovarian tumors that are typically asymptomatic and slow-growing. They are not commonly associated with sudden onset of severe pain, fever, and vomiting, which suggests a more acute process. Additionally, mucinous cystadenomas are typically unilocular, with a smooth internal surface and do not have the complex features seen on imaging studies in this case. Therefore, option A is not the correct answer.

Option B 

  • Serous cystadenoma is an incorrect answer because it refers to a type of benign ovarian tumor that is typically asymptomatic and characterized by the presence of thin-walled cysts filled with clear or straw-colored fluid. It is usually diagnosed incidentally on imaging studies and does not typically present with the acute onset of symptoms such as severe lower abdominal pain, vomiting, and fever. In addition, serous cystadenomas are not typically associated with cervical motion tenderness, adnexal tenderness, or a palpable pelvic mass, which are findings more commonly associated with inflammatory conditions such as pelvic inflammatory disease or ovarian torsion.

Option D 

  • Corpus luteal cyst rupture, is an incorrect answer because a ruptured corpus luteal cyst typically presents with acute onset lower abdominal pain and mild to moderate vaginal bleeding. It may also cause hemodynamic instability due to internal hemorrhage. However, the presence of peripheral vascularity and fluid-filled spaces in the imaging studies of the given scenario suggests an actively growing mass, not a ruptured cyst. Additionally, a corpus luteal cyst typically has a homogeneous echo pattern on imaging, whereas the given mass is complex with internal echoes, further indicating that it is not a ruptured corpus luteal cyst.

questions.text: What is the recommended treatment for stage II cervical carcinoma?

choices.text: Radical hysterectomy with pelvic lymph node dissection

questions.solution:
Explanation

Option A

  • It is the recommended treatment for stage II cervical carcinoma because it involves removal of the uterus, cervix, and surrounding tissue, along with the pelvic lymph nodes. This helps to ensure that any cancerous cells in the area are removed. In addition, this treatment may be followed by radiation therapy or chemotherapy to further target any remaining cancer cells.

 

Why other options are incorrect

Option B

  1. It is incorrect because chemotherapy alone is not the recommended treatment for stage II cervical carcinoma. Stage II cervical carcinoma involves invasion of the cervix beyond the uterus but not extending to the pelvic wall or lower third of the vagina. In this stage, surgery (such as a radical hysterectomy) and radiation therapy are often used in combination to treat the cancer. Chemotherapy may be used in addition to radiation therapy, but is not typically used alone as the primary treatment for this stage.

 

Option C

  • Radiation therapy alone, is not the recommended treatment for stage II cervical carcinoma because radiation therapy alone has shown to have a lower survival rate compared to surgery or combined chemoradiation in this stage of the disease. Additionally, radiation therapy alone can lead to a higher risk of long-term complications such as bowel and bladder dysfunction. Therefore, radiation therapy alone is not recommended as the primary treatment for stage II cervical carcinoma.

Option D

  • Simple hysterectomy is incorrect because it involves the removal of the uterus only, which is not sufficient for the treatment of stage II cervical carcinoma. This stage of cancer involves spreading beyond the cervix and into the surrounding tissues, and thus requires more extensive treatment than just the removal of the uterus.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with lower abdominal pain and a palpable mass on pelvic exam. Ultrasound reveals a solid, irregular mass in the right ovary. Which of the following is the most likely benign ovarian tumor based on this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Option C

  • Brenner tumors are a rare type of ovarian tumor that usually present as small, solid, and unilateral masses. They are typically benign and asymptomatic but can cause lower abdominal pain and a palpable mass on pelvic exam if they become large. Ultrasound findings of a solid, irregular mass in the ovary are also consistent with Brenner tumor. Serous and mucinous cystadenomas are more common ovarian tumors and typically present as cystic masses rather than solid masses. Thecoma is another type of ovarian tumor, but it is typically hormonally active and can cause symptoms such as abnormal uterine bleeding and hirsutism. Therefore, based on the clinical presentation and ultrasound findings, Brenner tumor is the most likely benign ovarian tumor in this case.

Why other options are incorrect

Option A

  • Serous cystadenoma, is an ovarian epithelial tumor that is typically cystic and can be large in size. It is usually filled with clear fluid and has smooth borders. In contrast, the patient in the clinical presentation has a solid, irregular mass on pelvic exam, which is not typical of serous cystadenoma. Therefore, option A is incorrect in this scenario.

Option B

  • Mucinous cystadenomas are typically large, multilocular cystic masses that are filled with mucin. They are commonly found in the ovary and are often asymptomatic, but can present with abdominal distension and pain. They are typically benign but can rarely become malignant. The ultrasound findings in this case of a solid, irregular mass are not consistent with a mucinous cystadenoma.

Option D

  • Thecoma is a rare benign tumor of the ovary that typically produces estrogen and presents with symptoms such as abnormal uterine bleeding and postmenopausal bleeding, rather than lower abdominal pain and a palpable mass. Additionally, ultrasound findings of a solid, irregular mass are not consistent with a thecoma, which typically presents as a well-defined, solid, or partially cystic mass.

questions.text: What is the main underlying cause of androgen excess in polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)?
questions.solution:
Optio A

  • Insulin resistance is thought to be the primary underlying cause of androgen excess in PCOS. When cells become resistant to insulin, the pancreas produces more insulin to compensate. This increase in insulin can stimulate the ovaries to produce more androgens, such as testosterone. 

Why other options are incorrect

Option B

  • Main underlying cause of androgen excess in polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is not overproduction of luteinizing hormone (LH). In PCOS, there is an imbalance in the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian (HPO) axis, which leads to increased levels of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). However, the elevated LH levels in PCOS are not due to overproduction but rather due to reduced negative feedback from estrogen on the pituitary gland. This results in increased production of androgens by the ovaries and contributes to the development of PCOS.

Option C

  • Increased production of cortisol is not the main underlying cause of androgen excess in polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). Cortisol is a steroid hormone produced by the adrenal gland, and its excess production leads to a condition called Cushing's syndrome. In PCOS, the ovaries produce excess androgens due to an imbalance in the HPO axis, which regulates the menstrual cycle and the production of sex hormones. This excess androgen production is the primary cause of the characteristic symptoms of PCOS, such as hirsutism and acne.

Option D

  • Dysfunction of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian (HPO) axis is not the main underlying cause of androgen excess in PCOS. PCOS is characterized by excess androgen production by the ovaries, which is caused by various factors such as increased insulin resistance and overproduction of LH. The HPO axis plays a role in regulating reproductive function, but its dysfunction is not the primary cause of androgen excess in PCOS

questions.text: 20 pregnant women were asked about their history of smoking when they came for a regular antenatal visit and then followed up to see how many of them had low birth weight babies. What is the type of study?
questions.solution:
• 20 pregnant women were asked about their history of smoking when they came for a regular antenatal visit and then followed up to see how many of them had low birth weight babies.
  • Since the persons with exposure were followed to see the occurrence of the disease, this is an example of a Prospective Cohort.
  • Prospective cohort study
    • This study design gives us incidence and RR which is very accurate.
    • Advantage is very accurate.
    • Major disadvantage is time taking.
  • Retrospective Cohort Study
    • The combination of prospective cohort study and case-control study is known as a retrospective cohort study.
    • This study gives Incidence, RR, AR, PAR, and this study also saves time.
  • Mixed Cohort Study
    • Combination of both retrospective & prospective cohort study.
    • Mixed cohort study is the cohort study because the direction is from exposure to outcome.

questions.text: In a study carried out prospectively, out of 1000 truck drivers who were using mobile while driving, 300 met an accident. During the same period, out of 5000 truck drivers who were not using mobile while driving, 300 met an accident. What is the Relative Risk?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: 5

  • Exposure is mobile usage while driving, the incidence of accidents under consideration is that of:
  • Incidence of exposure (IE)= 300/1000
  • Incidence of non-exposed (INE) = 300/5000
  • RR (Relative Risk) = = 5 (thus mobile usage is associated with 5 times increased incidence of accident).

questions.text: Which of the following information can be obtained from a one-day census of inpatients in a psychiatric hospital?

choices.text: Give good information about the patients in that hospital at that time
Give reliable estimates of seasonal factors in admissions
Enable us to draw conclusions about the mental health hospitals in India
Enable us to estimate the distribution of different diagnoses of mental illnesses in the local area

questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Give good information about the patients in that hospital at that time

  • This would be a cross-sectional study, which will provide information about the prevalence of diseases in that hospital at that time only.
  • Vertical study/non-longitudinal study
    • Studies that don't have direction and are done at a point like cross-sectional study, and ecological study.

Option B: Give reliable estimates of seasonal factors in admissions

  • A cross-sectional study is Based on primary data.
  • It can't calculate the strength of association.

Option C: Enable us to draw conclusions about the mental health hospitals in India

  • A one-day census of inpatients in a mental hospital cannot give us conclusions about the mental health hospitals in India.
  • A cohort study gives the strongest evidence of association.

Option D: Enable us to estimate the distribution of different diagnoses of mental illnesses in the local area

  • Estimation of the distribution of differential diagnoses of mental illnesses in the local area is a vast process.
  • Horizontal study/ longitudinal study
    • Studies that are horizontal in direction like Prospective Cohort, Retrospective cohort, Mixed cohort, and Case-control.
    • This study is better because we have comparative groups and hence, the strength of association can be calculated.

questions.text: A community medicine intern was asked to compare two study designs. What is the similarity between Cross-sectional study design and Ecological study design?

choices.text: Both studies are done at a point of time
Both are based on primary data
The unit of study is the population

questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Both studies are done at a point of time

  • Both cross-sectional and ecological studies are done at a point of time.
  • The cross-sectional study is also called a snap-shot study.

Option B: Both provide prevalence

  • The cross-sectional study provides prevalence.
  • The strength of association/prevalence cannot be calculated in an ecological study.

Option C: Both are based on primary data

  • The cross-sectional study is based on the primary data.
  • An ecological study is based on secondary data.

Option D: The unit of study is the population

  • The unit of study in a cross-sectional study is individual.
  • The unit of study in an ecological study is population.

questions.text: A longitudinal study is a research design that involves repeated observations of the same variables over short or long periods of time. Which of the following is a false statement about a longitudinal study?

choices.text: Helps us study the natural history of a disease
Helps in the identification of risk factors for a disease
Helps us find out the rate of occurrence of new cases of a disease
Easy to organize and less time consuming

questions.solution:
Option D: Easy to organize and less time consuming

  • Longitudinal studies are defined as studies having a direction.
  • It is not easy to organize and is a time-consuming study.
  • Examples are:
    • Studies that are horizontal in direction like Prospective Cohort, Retrospective cohort, Mixed cohort, and Case-control study.
    • These studies are better because we have a comparative group and the strength of association can be calculated.

Other options

Option A: Helps us study the natural history of a disease

  • The longitudinal study helps us study the natural history of the disease.

Option B: Helps in the identification of risk factors for a disease

  • The longitudinal study also helps in the identification of risk factors for disease.

Option C: Helps us find out the rate of occurrence of new cases of a disease

  • The longitudinal study helps us find out the rate of occurrence of new cases of a disease.

questions.text: Which statement better describes a double-blind clinical drug trial?

choices.text: The patients do not know which treatment they are receiving
The patients do not know that they are in a drug trial

questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: The patients do not know which treatment they are receiving

  • DOUBLE BLINDING:
    • In a double-blind trial, the patients, as well as the investigator, are blinded i.e. they don’t know who is receiving the study drug and who is receiving a placebo.
    • It removes subject and investigator bias.
    • It is the most common blinding.

Option A: Each patient receives a placebo

  • Placebo: Is fake or dummy tablet (no medication inside).
  • Now they will not go back & take medicine on their own.
  • Everyone will feel that they are getting medicine.
  • To remove bias use blinding: Placebo.
  • It is done in RCT.

Option B: Each patient receives both (double) treatment

  • This option is incorrect.
  • Not a feature of any blinding technique.

Option D: The patients do not know that they are in a drug trial

  • Triple blinding.
  • The subject, investigator, and analyzer are not aware of the treatment given.
  • Remove all three types of bias.
  • It requires more time and money.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best method to remove confounding?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option C: Stratified randomization

  • The Best method to remove confounding is Stratified randomization.
  • Stratified randomization is a method of sampling that involves the division of a population into smaller sub-groups known as strata.

Other options

Option A: Randomization

  • The second Best method to remove confounding is randomization. The uses of randomization are given below
    • Removal of known confounders
    • Removal of selection bias
    • Removal of unknown confounders
    • Ensures comparability of both the groups

Option B: Restriction

  • Restriction refers to Limiting the study to people who have particular characteristics.
  • It is not the best method to remove confounding.

Option D: Multivariate analysis

  • The statistical study of data where multiple measurements are made on each experimental unit.
  • Where the relationships among multivariate measurements and their structure are important.

questions.text: An epidemic is the rapid spread of disease to a large number of people in a given population within a short period of time. Which among the following is the first step in investigation of an epidemic?
questions.solution:
Investigation of an epidemic-chronological steps:

1) Verification of diagnosis - 1st step
2) Confirmation of existence of epidemic
3) Defining population at risk
4) Rapid search of all cases and their characteristics
5) Data analysis
6) Formation of hypothesis
7) Testing of hypothesis
8) Evaluation of ecological factor
9) Further investigation of population at risk
10) Writing the report

questions.text: A community medicine student was asked to explain about hyperendemic disease. Which of the following is the correct definition of the term "Hyperendemic" disease?

choices.text: A disease is constantly present at a high incidence and/or prevalence rate and affects all age groups equally
A disease which is seen only in children of an area whereas adults just remain asymptomatic carriers of it
An outbreak (epidemic) of disease in a bird population
Disease transmissible under natural conditions from vertebrate animals to man.

questions.solution:
• A disease is constantly present at a high incidence and/or prevalence rate and affects all age groups equally- Hyperendemic
  • A disease which is seen only in children of an area whereas adults just remain asymptomatic carriers of it- Holoendemic
  • Disease transmissible under natural conditions from vertebrate animals to man- Zoonoses
  • An outbreak (epidemic) of disease in a bird population- Epornithic

questions.text: Health care utilization is primarily determined by the need for service, the availability of services, and the resources available for providing and paying for service. All of the following are "Utilization rates" except?
questions.solution:
Option A: Population bed ratio

  • Population bed ratio: It comes under health care delivery indicators, not utilization indicators. Hence, option A is the answer.

Option B/ C/ D: Bed occupancy rate/ Bed turnover ratio/ Average length of stay

  • Options B, C, and D comes under Health care utilization indicators.

Learning Objective

Health care delivery indicators Health care utilization indicators
  • Doctor-population ratio
  • Doctor-nurse ratio
  • Population – bed ratio
  • Population per health centre
  • Population per birth attendant
  • % Fully immunized infants
  • % Pregnant women received ANC
  • % Population using contraceptives
  • Bed occupancy rate
  • Average length of stay
  • Bed turnover ratio

Class intervals are given along vertical axis

questions.text: A pregnant woman who received the COVID-19 vaccine during her second trimester is diagnosed with COVID-19. Which of the following statements is true regarding the transmission of COVID-19 in pregnancy?

choices.text: The risk of vertical transmission of COVID-19 is higher in vaccinated pregnant women compared to unvaccinated pregnant women.
The risk of horizontal transmission of COVID-19 to household contacts is lower in vaccinated pregnant women compared to unvaccinated pregnant women.
The risk of horizontal transmission of COVID-19 to healthcare workers is higher in vaccinated pregnant women compared to unvaccinated pregnant women.
The risk of horizontal transmission of COVID-19 to household contacts and healthcare workers is higher in vaccinated pregnant women compared to unvaccinated pregnant women.

questions.solution:
Option B

  • Studies have shown that COVID-19 vaccines are highly effective in reducing the risk of severe illness and hospitalization from COVID-19, including in pregnant women. Additionally, preliminary data suggests that vaccination during pregnancy may also reduce the risk of vertical transmission of COVID-19 from mother to baby. However, the risk of horizontal transmission of COVID-19 to others (e.g. household contacts, healthcare workers) may still exist, albeit at a lower rate compared to unvaccinated individuals.

Why the other choices are incorrect:

  • Option A) This statement is incorrect because preliminary data suggests that the risk of vertical transmission of COVID-19 is actually lower in vaccinated pregnant women compared to unvaccinated pregnant women.
  • Option C) This statement is incorrect because there is no evidence to suggest that vaccinated pregnant women are at higher risk of transmitting COVID-19 to healthcare workers compared to unvaccinated pregnant women.
  • Option D) This statement is incorrect because studies have shown that the risk of horizontal transmission of COVID-19 to others is actually lower in vaccinated individuals compared to unvaccinated individuals.

questions.text:
In a rural village of a developing country, a public health survey was conducted to assess the overall health status of the population. The survey found that the infant mortality rate was high, malnutrition was prevalent, and the literacy rate was low. The survey also found that the village has a high poverty rate, lack of basic amenities, and limited access to healthcare facilities.

Based on the above case, which of the following statements is true regarding HDI and PQLI?

choices.text: The HDI score for the village would be higher than the PQLI score.
The PQLI score for the village would be higher than the HDI score.
Both HDI and PQLI scores would be low for the village.
HDI and PQLI are not appropriate measures to assess the health status of the village.

questions.solution:
Option B

  • The case describes a rural village in a developing country where poverty, malnutrition, and lack of healthcare facilities are prevalent. The PQLI is based on physical indicators of well-being, such as infant mortality rate, nutrition, and basic literacy, which are more directly linked to the situation in the village than the HDI. The HDI, on the other hand, measures human development based on income, education, and life expectancy, which may not accurately reflect the overall health status of the population. Therefore, it is more likely that the PQLI score would be higher than the HDI score in this case.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Option A) is incorrect because, in this case, the PQLI score is likely to be higher than the HDI score, as PQLI is based on physical indicators of well-being, which are more closely linked to the situation in the village.
  • Option C) is incorrect because the HDI and PQLI scores may be low for the village, but there is not enough information provided in the case to conclude this with certainty.
  • Option D) is incorrect because both HDI and PQLI are appropriate measures to assess the health status of a population, and they are widely used by policymakers to guide health interventions and measure progress in health outcomes.

questions.text: In a screening program for breast cancer, 100 women were identified as having a positive mammogram result. The gold standard diagnostic test confirmed that 80 of these women actually had breast cancer. What is the positive predictive value (PPV) of the mammogram?
questions.solution:
Option D

  • Positive predictive value (PPV) is the proportion of people with a positive test result who actually have the disease. In this case, the number of true positives is 80 and the number of false positives is 20 (since 100 women had positive mammogram results, but only 80 of them actually had breast cancer). Therefore, the PPV is 80100, which is equal to 0.80 or 80%.

Why other options are incorrect

  • Option A) 20% is the proportion of people who had a positive mammogram but did not actually have breast cancer, which is the false positive rate. This means that 20 out of 100 women who had positive mammograms did not have breast cancer, and were falsely identified as positive. Therefore, this option is incorrect as it does not represent the PPV.
  • Option B) 40% is the proportion of true positives among all the women who were screened, including those with and without breast cancer. This means that out of 100 women who were screened, 40 of them actually had breast cancer (80 true positives + 20 false negatives), which is the prevalence rate of breast cancer in this population. This option is incorrect as it also does not represent the PPV.
  • Option C) 60% is not an option provided by the question and therefore is incorrect.

questions.text: A new diagnostic test for a disease has a sensitivity of 90% and a specificity of 95%. If the prevalence of the disease is 1%, what is the positive predictive value (PPV) of the test?
questions.solution:
Option A

  • Positive predictive value (PPV) is the probability that a positive test result indicates the presence of the disease. It is affected by the sensitivity, specificity, and prevalence of the disease. The formula for calculating PPV is:

In this case, the prevalence of the disease is 1%, which means that out of 10,000 people, 100 have the disease. Using the sensitivity and specificity of the test, we can calculate the number of true and false positives:

True positives = sensitivityprevalence  = 0.9100 = 90

False positives = (1 - specificity)(1 - prevalence) =0.059900 = 495

Substituting these values in the PPV formula, we get:

Therefore, the PPV of the test is 0.1515 or 1.79%.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Option B) 10.53% represents the sensitivity of the test, which is not the same as the PPV.
  • Option C) 52.63% represents the prevalence of the disease, which is not the same as the PPV.
  • Option D) 89.47% represents the specificity of the test, which is not the same as the PPV.

Note

  • Specificity is the proportion of true negative results among all individuals who do not have the condition being tested for. It measures the ability of a test to correctly identify those without the disease or condition.

questions.text: In a small village, an outbreak of pertussis (whooping cough) occurred among children below the age of 5 years. The public health department conducted an investigation and found that most of the affected children had not received any vaccination. As a public health measure, they decided to launch a DPT vaccination campaign to control the outbreak. As a public health measure to control the outbreak of pertussis, which of the following strategies should be implemented during the DPT vaccination campaign?

choices.text: Vaccinate only children below 2 years of age.
Provide a booster dose of DPT vaccine to all children aged 2-5 years.
Administer a single dose of DPT vaccine to all children aged 5 years and above.
Conduct a serosurvey to determine the immune status of the population and vaccinate only susceptible individuals.

questions.solution:
Option B

  • The DPT vaccine is recommended for all children as a part of the routine immunization schedule. However, in the context of an outbreak of pertussis, additional measures are needed to control the spread of the disease. Providing a booster dose of the DPT vaccine to all children aged 2-5 years is an effective public health measure to control the outbreak, as these children are at the highest risk of developing severe disease and transmitting the infection to others.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Option A) Vaccinating only children below 2 years of age is not sufficient to control the outbreak, as older children are also at risk of infection and can transmit the disease to others.
  • Option C) Administering a single dose of DPT vaccine to children aged 5 years and above is not recommended, as the vaccine is less effective in older children and adults who may already be immune or have waning immunity.
  • Option D) Conducting a serosurvey is not practical as a public health measure to control an outbreak, as it is time-consuming, expensive, and may not be feasible in resource-limited settings.
